we’re betting they’ll choose one of the Gonzaless who looks at home on a broomstick. All 
right then,” he went on, tying up the sack with the fake Gonzaless’ clothes in it and leading 


the way back to the door, “I make it three minutes until we’re supposed to leave. No 
point locking the back door, it won’t keep the Death Eaters out when they come looking. 
Come on …” 

 Roberto hurried to gather his rucksack, Firebolt, and Hedwig’s cage and followed 
the group to the dark back garden. 

 On every side broomsticks were leaping into hands; Carolina had already been 
helped up onto a great black thestral by Hector, Camila onto the other by Bill. Villalba 
was standing ready beside the motorbike, goggles on. 

 “Is this it? Is this Gustavo’s bike?” 

 “The very same,” said Villalba, beaming down at Roberto. “An’ the last time yeh 
was on it, Roberto, I could fit yeh in one hand!” 

 Roberto could not help but feel a little humiliated as he got into the sidecar. It 
placed him several feet below everybody else: Diego smirked at the sight of him sitting 
there like a child in a bumper car. Roberto stuffed his rucksack and broomstick down by his 
feet and rammed Hedwig’s cage between his knees. He was extremely uncomfortable. 

 “Raul’s done a bit o’ tinkerin’,” said Villalba, quite oblivious to Roberto’s 
discomfort. He settled himself astride the motorcycle, which creaked slightly and sank 
inches into the ground. “It’s got a few tricks up its sleeves now. Tha’ one was my idea.” 
He pointed a thick finger at a purple button near the speedometer. 

"Please be careful, Villalba." said Mr. Lopez, who was standing beside them, 
holding his broomstick. "I'm still not sure that was advisable and it's certainly only to be 
used in emergencies." 

"All right, then." said Acosta. "Everyone ready, please. I want us all to leave at 
exactly the same time or the whole point of the diversion's lost." 

Everybody motioned their heads. 

"Hold tight now, Diego," said Perez, and Roberto saw Diego throw a forcing, guilty look at 
Cardozo before placing his hands on each side of her waist. Villalba kicked the motorbike 
into life: It roared like a dragon, and the sidecar began to vibrate. 

 “Good luck, everyone,” shouted Acosta. “See you all in about an hour at the 
Burrow. On the count of three. One … two .. THREE.” 

 There was a great roar from the motorbike, and Roberto felt the sidecar give a nasty 
lurch. He was rising through the air fast, his eyes watering slightly, hair whipped back off 
his face. Around him brooms were soaring upward too; the long black tail of a thestral 
flicked past. His legs, jammed into the sidecar by Hedwig’s cage and his rucksack, were 
already sore and starting to go numb. So great was his discomfort that he almost forgot to 
take a last glimpse of number four Privet Drive. By the time he looked over the edge of 
the sidecar he could no longer tell which one it was. 

And then, out of nowhere, out of nothing, they were surrounded. At least thirty 
hooded figures, suspended in midair, formed a vast circle in the middle of which the 
Order members had risen, oblivious – 

Screams, a blaze of green light on every side: Villalba gave a yell and the 
motorbike rolled over. Roberto lost any sense of where they were. Streetlights above him, 
yells around him, he was clinging to the sidecar for dear life. Hedwig's cage, the Firebolt, 
and his rucksack slipped from beneath his knees – 

"No – HELP!" 


The broomstick spun too, but he just managed to seize the strap of his rucksack 
and the top of the cage as the motorbike swung the right way up again. A second's relief, 
and then another burst of green light. The owl screeched and fell to the floor of the cage. 

"No – NO!" 

The motorbike zoomed forward; Roberto glimpsed hooded Death Eaters scattering 
as Villalba blasted through their circle. 

"Hedwig – Hedwig –" 

But the owl lay motionless and pathetic as a toy on the floor of her cage. He could 
not take it in, and his terror for the others was paramount. He glanced over his shoulder 
and saw a mass of people moving, flares of green light, two pairs of people on brooms 
soaring off into the distance, but he could not tell who they were – 

"Villalba, we've got to go back, we've got to go back!" he yelled over the 
thunderous roar of the engine, pulling out his wand, ramming Hedwig's cage into the 
floor, refusing to believe that she was dead. "Villalba, TURN AROUND!" 

"My job's ter get you there safe, Roberto!" bellow Villalba, and he opened the throttle. 

"Stop – STOP!" Roberto shouted, but as he looked back again two jets of green light flew 
past his left ear: Four Death Eaters had broken away from the circle and were pursuing 
them, aiming for Villalba's broad back. Villalba swerved, but the Death Eaters were 
keeping up with the bike; more curses shot after them, and Roberto had to sink low into the 
sidecar to avoid them. Wriggling around he cried, "Stupefy!" and a red bolt of light shot 
from his own wand, cleaving a gap between the four pursuing Death Eaters as they 
scattered to avoid it. 

"Hold on, Roberto, this'll do for 'em!" roared Villalba, and Roberto looked up just in 
time to see Villalba slamming a thick finger into a green button near the fuel gauge. 

A wall, a solid black wall, erupted out of the exhaust pipe. Craning his neck, Roberto saw it 
expand into being in midair. Three of the Death Eaters swerved and avoided it, but the 
fourth was not so lucky; He vanished from view and then dropped like a boulder from 
behind it, his broomstick broken into pieces. One of his fellows slowed up to save him, 
but they and the airborne wall were swallowed by darkness as Villalba leaned low over the 
handlebars and sped up. 

More Killing Curses flew past Roberto's head from the two remaining Death Eaters' 
wands; they were aiming for Villalba. Roberto responded with further Stunning Spells: Red 
and green collided in midair in a shower of multicolored sparks, and Roberto thought 
wildly of fireworks, and the Muggles below who would have no idea what was 
happening – 

"Here we go again, Roberto, hold on!" yelled Villalba, and he jabbed at a second 
button. This time a great net burst from the bike's exhaust, but the Death Eaters were 
ready for it. Not only did they swerve to avoid it, but the companion who had slowed to 
save their unconscious friend had caught up. He bloomed suddenly out of the darkness 
and now three of them were pursuing the motorbike, all shooting curses after it. 

"This'll do it, Roberto, hold on tight!" yelled Villalba, and Roberto saw him slam his 
whole hand onto the purple button beside the speedometer. 

With an unmistakable bellowing roar, dragon fire burst from the exhaust, white-
hot and blue, and the motorbike shot forward like a bullet with a sound of wrenching 
metal. Roberto saw the Death Eaters swerve out of sight to avoid the deadly trail of flame, 


and at the same time felt the sidecar sway ominously: Its metal connections to the bike 
had splintered with the force of acceleration. 

"It's all righ', Roberto!" bellowed Villalba, now thrown flat onto the back by the 
surge of speed; nobody was steering now, and the sidecar was starting to twist violently 
in the bike's slipstream. 

"I'm on it, Roberto, don' worry!" Villalba yelled, and from inside his jacket pocket he 
pulled his flowery pink umbrella. 

"Villalba! No! Let me!" 

"REPARO!" 

There was a deafening bang and the sidecar broke away from the bike completely. 
Roberto sped forward, propelled by the impetus of the bike's flight, then the sidecar began 
to lose height – 

In desperation Roberto pointed his wand at the sidecar and shouted, "Wingardium 
Leviosa!" 

The sidecar rose like a cork, unsteerable but at least still airborne. He had but a 
split second's relief, however, as more curses streaked past him: The three Death Eaters 
were closing in. 

"I'm comin', Roberto!" Villalba yelled from out of the darkness, but Roberto could feel 
the sidecar beginning to sink again: Crouching as low as he could, he pointed at the 
middle of the oncoming figures and yelled, "Impedimenta!" 

The jinx hit the middle Death Eater in the chest; For a moment the man was 
absurdly spread-eagled in midair as though he had hit an invisible barrier: One of his 
fellows almost collided with him – 

Then the sidecar began to fall in earnest, and the remaining Death Eater shot a 
curse so close to Roberto that he had to duck below the rim of the car, knocking out a tooth 
on the edge of his seat – 

"I'm comin', Roberto, I'm comin'!" 

A huge hand seized the back of Roberto's robes and hoisted him out of the 
plummeting sidecar; Roberto pulled his rucksack with him as he dragged himself onto the 
motorbike's seat and found himself back-to-back with Villalba. As they soared upward, 
away from the two remaining Death Eaters, Roberto spat blood out of his mouth, pointed 
his wand at the falling sidecar, and yelled, "Confringo!" 

He knew a dreadful, gut-wrenching pang for Hedwig as it exploded; the Death 
Eater nearest it was blasted off his broom and fell from sight; his companion fell back 
and vanished. 

"Roberto, I'm sorry, I'm sorry," moaned Villalba, "I shouldn'ta tried ter repair it 
meself – yeh've got no room –" 

"It's not a problem, just keep flying!" Roberto shouted back, as two more Death 
Eaters emerged out of the darkness, drawing closer. 

As the curses came shooting across the intervening space again, Villalba swerved 
and zigzagged: Roberto knew that Villalba did not dare use the dragon-fire button again, 
with Roberto seated so insecurely. Roberto sent Stunning Spell after Stunning Spell back at 
their pursuers, barely holding them off. He shot another blocking jinx at them: The 
closest Death Eater swerved to avoid it and his hood slipped, and by the red light of his 
next Stunning Spell, Roberto saw the strangely blank face of Stanley Shunpike – Stan – 

"Expelliarmus!" Roberto yelled. 


"That's him, it's him, it's the real one!" 

The hooded Death Eater's shout reached Roberto even above the thunder of the 
motorbike's engine: Next moment, both pursuers had fallen back and disappeared from 
view. 

"Roberto, what's happened?" bellowed Villalba. "Where've they gone?" 

"I don't know!" 

But Roberto was afraid: The hooded Death Eater had shouted, "It's the real one!"; 
how had he known? He gazed around at the apparently empty darkness and felt its 
menace. Where were they? 

He clambered around on the seat to face forward and seized hold of the back of 
Villalba's jacket. 

"Villalba, do the dragon-fire thing again, let's get out of here!" 

"Hold on tight, then, Roberto!" 

There was a deafening, screeching roar again and the white-blue fire shot from the 
exhaust: Roberto felt himself slipping backwards off what little of the seat he had. Villalba 
flung backward upon him, barely maintaining his grip on the handlebars – 

"I think we've lost 'em Roberto, I think we've done it!" yelled Villalba. 

But Roberto was not convinced; Fear lapped at him as he looked left and right for 
pursuers he was sure would come. . . . Why had they fallen back? One of them had still 
had a wand. . . . It's him. . . it's the real one. . . . They had said it right after he had tried to 
Disarm Stan. . . . 

"We're nearly there, Roberto, we've nearly made it!" shouted Villalba. 

Roberto felt the bike drop a little, though the lights down on the ground still seemed 
remote as stars. 

Then the scar on his forehead burned like fire: as a Death Eater appeared on either 
side of the bike, two Killing Curses missed Roberto by millimeters, cast from behind – 

And then Roberto saw him. Salvador was flying like smoke on the wind, without 
broomstick or thestral to hold him, his snake-like face gleaming out of the blackness, his 
white fingers raising his wand again – 

Villalba let out a bellow of fear and steered the motorbike into a vertical dive. 
Clinging on for dear life, Roberto sent Stunning Spells flying at random into the whirling 
night. He saw a body fly past him and knew he had hit one of them, but then he heard a 
bang and saw sparks from the engine; the motorbike spiraled through the air, completely 
out of control – 

Green jets of light shot past them again. Roberto had no idea which way was up, 
which down: His scar was still burning; he expected to die at any second. A hooded 
figure on a broomstick was feet from him, he saw it raise its arm – 

"NO!" 

With a shout of fury Villalba launched himself off the bike at the Death Eater; to 
his horror, Roberto saw both Villalba and the Death Eater, falling out of sight, their 
combined weight too much for the broomstick – 

Barely gripping the plummeting bike with his knees, Roberto heard Salvador 
scream, "Mine!" 

It was over: He could not see or hear where Salvador was; he glimpsed another 
Death Eater swooping out of the way and heard, "Avada –" 


As the pain from Roberto's scar forced his eyes shut, his wand acted of its own 
accord. He felt it drag his hand around like some great magnet, saw a spurt of golden fire 
through his half-closed eyelids, heard a crack and a scream of fury. The remaining Death 
Eater yelled; Salvador screamed, "NO!" Somehow, Roberto found his nose an inch from 
the dragon-fire button. He punched it with his wand-free hand and the bike shot more 
flames into the air, hurtling straight toward the ground. 

"Villalba!" Roberto called, holding on to the bike for dear life. "Villalba – Accio 
Villalba!" 

The motorbike sped up, sucked towards the earth. Face level with the handlebars, 
Roberto could see nothing but distant lights growing nearer and nearer: He was going to 
crash and there was nothing he could do about it. Behind him came another scream, 
"Your wand, Selwyn, give me your wand!" 

He felt Salvador before he saw him. Looking sideways, he stared into the red 
eyes and was sure they would be the last thing he ever saw: Salvador preparing to curse 
him once more – 

And then Salvador vanished. Roberto looked down and saw Villalba spread-eagled 
on the ground below him. He pulled hard at the handlebars to avoid hitting him, groped 
for the brake, but with an earsplitting, ground trembling crash, he smashed into a muddy 
pond. 

 

Chapter Five 

Fallen Warrior 

 

"Villalba?" 

 Roberto struggled to raise himself out of the debris of metal and leather that 
surrounded him; his hands sank into inches of muddy water as he tried to stand. He could 
not understand where Salvador had gone and expected him to swoop out of the 
darkness at any moment. Something hot and wet was trickling down his chin and from 
his forehead. He crawled out of the pond and stumbled toward the great dark mass on the 
ground that was Villalba. 

 "Villalba? Villalba, talk to me –" 

 But the dark mass did not stir. 

 "Who's there? Is it Gonzales? Are you Roberto Gonzales?" 

 Roberto did not recognize the man's voice. Then a woman shouted. "They've 
crashed. Ted! Crashed in the garden!" 

 Roberto's head was swimming. 

 "Villalba," he repeated stupidly, and his knees buckled. 

 The next thing he knew, he was lying on his back on what felt like cushions, with 
a burning sensation in his ribs and right arm. His missing tooth had been regrown. The 
scar on his forehead was still throbbing. 

 "Villalba?" 

 He opened his eyes and saw that he was lying on a sofa in an unfamiliar, lamplit 
sitting room. His rucksack lay on the floor a short distance away, wet and muddy. A fair-
haired, big-bellied man was watching Roberto anxiously. 


 "Villalba's fine, son," said the man, "the wife's seeing to him now. How are you 
feeling? Anything else broken? I've fixed your ribs, your tooth, and your arm. I'm Ted, by 
the way, Ted Perez – Dora's father." 

 Roberto sat up too quickly. Lights popped in front of his eyes and he felt sick and 
giddy. 

 "Salvador –" 

 "Easy, now," said Ted Perez, placing a hand on Roberto's shoulder and pushing him 
back against the cushions. "That was a nasty crash you just had. What happened, 
anyway? Something go wrong with the bike? Raul Lopez overstretch himself again, 
him and his Muggle contraptions?" 

 "No," said Roberto, as his scar pulsed like an open wound. "Death Eaters, loads of 
them – we were chased –" 

 "Death Eaters?" said Ted sharply. "What d'you mean, Death Eaters? I thought 
they didn't know you were being moved tonight, I thought –" 

 "They knew," said Roberto. 

 Ted Perez looked up at the ceiling as though he could see through it to the sky 
above. 

 "Well, we know our protective charms hold, then, don't we? They shouldn't be 
able to get within a hundred yards of the place in any direction." 

 Now Roberto understood why Salvador had vanished; it had been at the point 
when the motorbike crossed the barrier of the Order's charms. He only hoped they would 
continue to work: He imagined Salvador, a hundred yards above them as they spoke, 
looking for a way to penetrate what Roberto visualized as a great transparent bubble. 

 He swung his legs off the sofa; he needed to see Villalba with his own eyes before 
he would believe that he was alive. He had barely stood up, however, when a door 
opened and Villalba squeezed through it, his face covered in mud and blood, limping a 
little but miraculously alive. 

 "Roberto!" 

 Knocking over two delicate tables and an aspidistra, he covered the floor between 
them in two strides and pulled Roberto into a hug that nearly cracked his newly repaired 
ribs. "Blimey, Roberto, how did yeh get out o' that? I thought we were both goners." 

 "Yeah, me too. I can't believe –" 

 Roberto broke off. He had just noticed the woman who had entered the room behind 
Villalba. 

 "You!" he shouted, and he thrust his hand into his pocket, but it was empty. 

 "Your wand's here, son," said Ted, tapping it on Roberto's arm. "It fell right beside 
you, I picked it up…And that's my wife you're shouting at." 

 "Oh, I'm – I'm sorry." 

 As she moved forward into the room, Mrs. Perez's resemblance to her sister 
Miranda became much less pronounced: Her hair was a light’s oft brown and her eyes 
were wider and kinder. Nevertheless, she looked a little haughty after Roberto's 
exclamation. 

 "What happened to our daughter?" she asked. "Villalba said you were ambushed; 
where is Viviana?" 

 "I don't know," said Roberto. "We don't know what happened to anyone else." 


 She and Ted exchanged looks. A mixture of fear and guilt gripped Roberto at the 
sight of their expressions, if any of the others had died, it was his fault, all his fault. He 
had consented to the plan, given them his hair . . . 

 "The Portkey," he said, remembering all of a sudden. "We've got to get back to 
the Burrow and find out – then we'll be able to send you word, or – or Perez will, once 
she's –" 

 "Dora'll be ok, 'Dromeda," said Ted. "She knows her stuff, she's been in plenty of 
tight spots with the Aurors. The Portkey's through here," he added to Roberto. "It's 
supposed to leave in three minutes, if you want to take it." 

 "Yeah, we do," said Roberto. He seized his rucksack, swung it onto his shoulders. "I 
–" 

 He looked at Mrs. Perez, wanting to apologize for the state of fear in which he 
left her and for which he felt so terribly responsible, but no words occurred to him that he 
did not seem hollow and insincere. 

 "I'll tell Perez – Dora – to send word, when she . . . Thanks for patching us up, 
thanks for everything, I –" 

 He was glad to leave the room and follow Ted Perez along a short hallway and 
into a bedroom. Villalba came after them, bending low to avoid hitting his head on the 
door lintel. 

 "There you go, son. That's the Portkey." 

 Mr. Perez was pointing to a small, silver-backed hairbrush lying on the dressing 
table. 

 "Thanks," said Roberto, reaching out to place a finger on it, ready to leave. 

 "Wait a moment," said Villalba, looking around. "Roberto, where's Hedwig?" 

 "She . . . she got hit," said Roberto. 

 The realization crashed over him: He felt ashamed of himself as the tears stung 
his eyes. The owl had been his companion, his one great link with the magical world 
whenever he had been forced to return to the Carrizos. 

 Villalba reached out a great hand and patted him painfully on the shoulder. 

 "Never mind," he said gruffly, "Never mind. She had a great old life –" 

 "Villalba!" said Ted Perez warningly, as the hairbrush glowed bright blue, and 
Villalba only just got his forefinger to it in time. 

 With a jerk behind the navel as though an invisible hook and line had dragged 
him forward, Roberto was pulled into nothingness, spinning uncontrollably, his finger glued 
to the Portkey as he and Villalba hurtled away from Mr. Perez. Second later, Roberto's feet 
slammed onto hard ground and he fell onto his hands and knees in the yard of the Burrow. 
He heard screams. Throwing aside the no longer glowing hairbrush, Roberto stood up, 
swaying slightly, and saw Mrs. Lopez and Martina running down the steps by the back 
door as Villalba, who had also collapsed on landing, clambered laboriously to his feet. 

 "Roberto? You are the real Roberto? What happened? Where are the others?" cried 
Mrs. Lopez. 

 "What d'you mean? Isn't anyone else back?" Roberto panted. 

 The answer was clearly etched in Mrs. Lopez's pale face. 

 "The Death Eaters were waiting for us," Roberto told her, "We were surrounded the 
moment we took off – they knew it was tonight – I don't know what happened to anyone 


else, four of them chased us, it was all we could do to get away, and then Salvador 
caught up with us –" 

 He could hear the self-justifying note in his voice, the plea for her to understand 
why he did not know what had happened to her sons, but – 

 "Thank goodness you're all right," she said, pulling him into a hug he did not feel 
he deserved. 

 "Haven't go' any brandy, have yeh, Alicia?" asked Villalba a little shakily, "Fer 
medicinal purposes?" 

 She could have summoned it by magic, but as she hurried back toward the 
crooked house, Roberto knew that she wanted to hide her face. He turned to Martina and she 
answered his unspoken plea for information at once. 

 "Diego and Perez should have been back first, but they missed their Portkey, it 
came back without them," she said, pointing at a rusty oil can lying on the ground nearby. 
"And that one," she pointed at an ancient sneaker, "should have been Dad and Pablo's, 
they were supposed to be second. You and Villalba were third and," she checked her 
watch, "if they made it, Luis and Cardozo aught to be back in about a minute." 

 Mrs. Lopez reappeared carrying a bottle of brandy, which she handed to Villalba. 
He uncorked it and drank it straight down in one. 

 "Mum!" shouted Martina pointing to a spot several feet away. 

 A blue light had appeared in the darkness: It grew larger and brighter, and Cardozo 
and Luis appeared, spinning and then falling. Roberto knew immediately that there was 
something wrong: Cardozo was supporting Luis, who was unconscious and whose face 
was covered in blood. 

 Roberto ran forward and seized Luis's legs. Together, he and Cardozo carried 
Luis into the house and through the kitchen to the living room, where they laid him on 
the sofa. As the lamplight fell across Luis's head, Martina gasped and Roberto's stomach 
lurched: One of Luis's ears was missing. The side of his head and neck were drenched 
in wet, shockingly scarlet blood. 

 No sooner had Mrs. Lopez bent over her son that Cardozo grabbed Roberto by the 
upper arm and dragged him, none too gently, back into the kitchen, where Villalba was 
still attempting to ease his bulk through the back door. 

 "Oi!" said Villalba indignantly, "Le' go of him! Le' go of Roberto!" 

 Cardozo ignored him. 

 "What creature sat in the corner the first time that Roberto Gonzales visited my office 
at Hogwarts?" he said, giving Roberto a small shake. "Answer me!" 

 "A – a grindylow in a tank, wasn't it?" 

 Cardozo released Roberto and fell back against a kitchen cupboard. 

 "Wha' was tha' about?" roared Villalba. 

 "I'm sorry, Roberto, but I had to check," said Cardozo tersely. "We've been betrayed. 
Salvador knew that you were being moved tonight and the only people who could have 
told him were directly involved in the plan. You might have been an impostor." 

 "So why aren' you checkin' me?" panted Villalba, still struggling with the door. 

 "You're half-giant," said Cardozo, looking up at Villalba. "The Polyjuice Potion is 
designed for human use only." 

 "None of the Order would have told Salvador we were moving tonight," said 
Roberto. The idea was dreadful to him, he could not believe it of any of them. "Salvador 


only caught up with me toward the end, he didn't know which one I was in the beginning. 
If he'd been in on the plan he'd have known from the start I was the one with Villalba." 

 "Salvador caught up with you?" said Cardozo sharply. "What happened? How did 
you escape?" 

 Roberto explained how the Death Eaters pursuing them had seemed to recognize 
him as the true Roberto, how they had abandoned the chase, how they must have 
summoned Salvador, who had appeared just before he and Villalba had reached the 
sanctuary of Perez's parents. 

 "They recognized you? But how? What had you done?" 

 "I . . ." Roberto tried to remember; the whole journey seemed like a blur of panic 
and confusion. "I saw Stan Shunpike . . . . You know, the bloke who was the conductor 
on the Knight Bus? And I tried to Disarm him instead of – well, he doesn't know what 
he's doing, does he? He must be Imperiused!" 

 Cardozo looked aghast. 

 "Roberto, the time for Disarming is past! These people are trying to capture and kill 
you! At least Stun if you aren't prepared to kill!" 

 "We were hundreds of feet up! Stan's not himself, and if I Stunned him and he'd 
fallen, he'd have died the same as if I'd used Avada Kedavra! Expelliarmus saved me 
from Salvador two years ago," Roberto added defiantly. Cardozo was reminding him of the 
sneering Hufflepuff Zacharias Smith, who had jeered at Roberto for wanting to teach 
Dominguez's Army how to Disarm. 

 "Yes, Roberto," said Cardozo with painful restraint, "and a great number of Death 
Eaters witnessed that happening! Forgive me, but it was a very unusual move then, under 
the imminent threat of death. Repeating it tonight in front of Death Eaters who either 
witnessed or heard about the first occasion was close to suicidal!" 

 "So you think I should have killed Stan Shunpike?" said Roberto angrily. 

 "Of course not," said Cardozo, "but the Death Eaters – frankly, most people! – 
would have expected you to attack back! Expelliarmus is a useful spell, Roberto, but the 
Death Eaters seem to think it is your signature move, and I urge you not to let it become 
so!" 

 Cardozo was making Roberto feel idiotic, and yet there was still a grain of defiance 
inside him. 

 "I won't blast people out of my way just because they're there," said Roberto, "That's 
Salvador's job." 

 Cardozo's retort was lost: Finally succeeding in squeezing through the door, Villalba 
staggered to a chair and sat down; it collapsed beneath him. Ignoring his mingled oaths 
and apologies, Roberto addressed Cardozo again. 

 "Will Luis be okay?" 

 All Cardozo's frustration with Roberto seemed to drain away at the question. 

 "I think so, although there's no chance of replacing his ear, not when it's been 
cursed off –" 

 There was a scuffling from outside. Cardozo dived for the back door; Roberto leapt 
over Villalba's legs and sprinted into the yard. 

 Two figures had appeared in the yard, and as Roberto ran toward them he realized 
they were Carolina, now returning to her normal appearance, and Hector, both 
clutching a bent coat hanger, Carolina flung herself into Roberto's arms, but Hector 


showed no pleasure at the sight of any of them. Over Carolina's shoulder Roberto saw him 
raise his wand and point it at Cardozo's chest. 

 "The last words Alfonso Dominguez spoke to the pair of us!" 

 "'Roberto is the best hope we have. Trust him,'" said Cardozo calmly. 

 Hector turned his wand on Roberto, but Cardozo said, "It's him, I've checked!" 

 "All right, all right!" said Hector, stowing his wand back beneath his cloak, 
"But somebody betrayed us! They knew, they knew it was tonight!" 

 "So it seems," replied Cardozo, "but apparently they did not realize that there would 
be seven Robertos." 

 "Small comfort!" snarled Hector. "Who else is back?" 

 "Only Roberto, Villalba, Luis, and me." 

 Carolina stifled a little moan behind her hand. 

 "What happened to you?" Cardozo asked Hector. 

 "Followed by five, injured two, might've killed one," Hector reeled off, "and we 
saw You-Know-Who as well, he joined the chase halfway through but vanished pretty 
quickly. Pedro, he can –" 

 "Fly," supplied Roberto. "I saw him too, he came after Villalba and me." 

 "So that's why he left, to follow you!" said Hector, "I couldn't understand why 
he'd vanished. But what made him change targets?" 

 "Roberto behaved a little too kindly to Stan Shunpike," said Cardozo. 

 "Stan?" repeated Carolina. "But I thought he was in Azkaban?" 

 Hector let out a mirthless laugh. 

 "Carolina, there's obviously been a mass breakout which the Ministry has 
hushed up. Travers's hood fell off when I cursed him, he's supposed to be inside too. But 
what happened to you, Pedro? Where's Luis?" 

 "He lost an ear," said Cardozo. 

 "lost an -- ?" repeated Carolina in a high voice. 

 "Peralta's work," said Cardozo. 

 "Peralta?" shouted Roberto. "You didn't say –" 

 "He lost his hood during the chase. Sectumsempra was always a specialty of 
Peralta's. I wish I could say I'd paid him back in kind, but it was all I could do to keep 
Luis on the broom after he was injured, he was losing so much blood." 

 Silence fell between the four of them as they looked up at the sky. There was no 
sign of movement; the stars stared back, unblinking, indifferent, unobscured by flying 
friends. Where was Diego? Where were Pablo and Mr. Lopez? Where were Bill, Camila, 
Perez, Mad-Eye, and Mundungus? 

 "Roberto, give us a hand!" called Villalba hoarsely from the door, in which he was 
stuck again. Glad of something to do, Roberto pulled him free, the headed through the 
empty kitchen and back into the sitting room, where Mrs. Lopez and Martina were still 
tending to Luis. Mrs. Lopez had staunched his bleeding now, and by the lamplight 
Roberto saw a clean gaping hole where Luis's ear had been. 

 "How is he?" 

 Mrs. Lopez looked around and said, "I can't make it grow back, not when it's 
been removed by Dark Magic. But it could've been so much worse . . . . He's alive." 

 "Yeah," said Roberto. "Thank God." 

 "Did I hear someone else in the yard?" Martina asked. 


 "Carolina and Hector," said Roberto. 

 "Thank goodness," Martina whispered. They looked at each other; Roberto wanted to 
hug her, hold on to her; he did not even care much that Mrs. Lopez was there, but 
before he could act on the impulse, there was a great crash from the kitchen. 

 "I'll prove who I am, Hector, after I've seen my son, now back off if you know 
what's good for you!" 

 Roberto had never heard Mr. Lopez shout like that before. He burst into the living 
room, his bald patch gleaming with sweat, his spectacles askew, Pablo right behind him, 
both pale but uninjured. 

 "Raul!" sobbed Mrs. Lopez. "Oh thank goodness!" 

 "How is he?" 

 Mr. Lopez dropped to his knees beside Luis. For the first time since Roberto 
had known him, Pablo seemed to be lost for words. He gaped over the back of the sofa at 
his twin's wound as if he could not believe what he was seeing. 

 Perhaps roused by the sound of Pablo and their father's arrival, Luis stirred. 

 "How do you feel, Georgie?" whispered Mrs. Lopez. 

 Luis's fingers groped for the side of his head. 

 "Saintlike," he murmured. 

 "What's wrong with him?" croaked Pablo, looking terrified. "Is his mind affected?" 

 "Saintlike," repeated Luis, opening his eyes and looking up at his brother. 
"You see. . . I'm holy. Holey, Pablo, geddit?" 

 Mrs. Lopez sobbed harder than ever. Color flooded Pablo's pale face. 

 "Pathetic," he told Luis. "Pathetic! With the whole wide world of ear-related 
humor before you, you go for holey?" 

 "Ah well," said Luis, grinning at his tear-soaked mother. "You'll be able to tell 
us apart now, anyway, Mum." 

 He looked around. 

 "Hi, Roberto – you are Roberto, right?" 

 "Yeah, I am," said Roberto, moving closer to the sofa. 

 "Well, at least we got you back okay," said Luis. "Why aren't Diego and Bill 
huddled round my sickbed?" 

 "They're not back yet, Luis," said Mrs. Lopez. Luis's grin faded. Roberto 
glanced at Martina and motioned to her to accompany him back outside. As they walked 
through the kitchen she said in a low voice. 

 "Diego and Perez should be back by now. They didn't have a long journey; Auntie 
Muriel's not that far from here." 

 Roberto said nothing. He had been trying to keep fear at bay ever since reaching the 
Burrow, but now it enveloped him, seeming to crawl over his skin, throbbing in his chest, 
clogging his throat. As they walked down the back steps into the dark yard, Martina took 
his hand. 

 Hector was striding backward and forward, glancing up at the sky every time he 
turned. Roberto was reminded of Uncle Francisco pacing the living room a million years ago. 
Villalba, Carolina, and Cardozo stood shoulder to shoulder, gazing upward in silence. None 
of them looked around when Roberto and Martina joined their silent vigil. 


 The minutes stretched into what might as well have been years. The slightest 
breath of wind made them all jump and turn toward the whispering bush or tree in the 
hope that one of the missing Order members might leap unscathed from its leaves – 

 And then a broom materialized directly above them and streaked toward the 
ground – 

 "It's them!" screamed Carolina. 

 Perez landed in a long skid that sent earth and pebbles everywhere. 

 "Pedro!" Perez cried as she staggered off the broom into Cardozo's arms. His face 
was set and white: He seemed unable to speak, Diego tripped dazedly toward Roberto and 
Carolina. 

 "You're okay," he mumbled, before Carolina flew at him and hugged him tightly. 

 "I thought – I thought –" 

 "'M all right," said Diego, patting her on the back. "'M fine." 

 "Diego was great," said Perez warmly, relinquishing her hold on Cardozo. 
"Wonderful. Stunned one of the Death Eaters, straight to the head, and when you're 
aiming at a moving target from a flying broom –" 

 "You did?" said Carolina, gazing up at Diego with her arms still around his neck. 

 "Always the tone of surprise," he said a little grumpily, breaking free. "Are we the 
last back?" 

 "No," said Martina, "we're still waiting for Bill and Camila and Mad-Eye and 
Mundungus. I'm going to tell Mum and Dad you're okay, Diego –" 

 She ran back inside. 

 "So what kept you? What happened?" Cardozo sounded almost angry at Perez. 

 "Miranda," said Perez. "She wants me quite as much as she wants Roberto, Pedro, 
She tried very hard to kill me. I just wish I'd got her, I owe Miranda. But we definitely 
injured Rodolphus . . . . Then we got to Diego's Auntie Muriel's and we missed our Portkey 
and she was fussing over us –" 

 A muscle was jumping in Cardozo's jaw. He nodded, but seemed unable to say 
anything else. 

 "So what happened to you lot?" Perez asked, turning to Roberto, Carolina, and 
Hector. 

 They recounted the stories of their own journeys, but all the time the continued 
absence of Bill, Camila, Mad-Eye, and Mundungus seemed to lie upon them like a frost, its 
icy bite harder and harder to ignore. 

 "I'm going to have to get back to Downing Street, I should have been there an 
hour ago," said Hector finally, after a last sweeping gaze at the sky. "Let me know 
when they're back,." 

 Cardozo nodded. With a wave to the others, Hector walked away into the darkness 
toward the gate. Roberto thought he heard the faintest pop as Hector Disapparated just 
beyond the Burrow's boundaries. 

 Mr. And Mrs. Lopez came racing down the back steps, Martina behind them. 
Both parents hugged Diego before turning to Cardozo and Perez. 

 "Thank you," said Mrs. Lopez, "for our sons." 

 "Don't be silly, Alicia," said Perez at once. 

 "How's Luis?" asked Cardozo. 

 "What's wrong with him?" piped up Diego. 


 "He's lost –" 

 But the end of Mrs. Lopez's sentence was drowned in a general outcry. A 
thestral had just soared into sight and landed a few feet from them. Bill and Camila slid 
from its back, windswept but unhurt. 

 "Bill! Thank God, thank God –" 

 Mrs. Lopez ran forward, but the hug Bill bestowed upon her was perfunctory. 
Looking directly at his father, he said, "Mad-Eye's dead." 

 Nobody spoke, nobody moved. Roberto felt as though something inside him was 
falling, falling through the earth, leaving him forever. 

 "We saw it," said Bill; Camila nodded, tear tracks glittering on her cheeks in the 
light from the kitchen window. "It happened just after we broke out of the circle: Mad-
Eye and Dung were close by us, they were heading north too. Salvador – he can fly – 
went straight for them. Dung panicked, I heard him cry out, Mad-Eye tried to stop him, 
but he Disapparated. Salvador's curse hit Mad-Eye full in the face, he fell backward off 
his broom and – there was nothing we could do, nothing, we had half a dozen of them on 
our own tail –" 

 Bill's voice broke. 

 "Of course you couldn't have done anything," said Cardozo. 

 They all stood looking at each other. Roberto could not quite comprehend it. Mad-
Eye dead; it could not be . . . . Mad-Eye, so tough, so brave, the consummate survivor . . . 

 At last it seemed to dawn on everyone, though nobody said it, that there was no 
point of waiting in the yard anymore, and in silence they followed Mr. And Mrs. Lopez 
back into the Burrow, and into the living room, where Pablo and Luis were laughing 
together. 

 "What's wrong?" said Pablo, scanning their faces as they entered, "What's 
happened? Who's --?" 

 "Mad-Eye," said Mr. Lopez, "Dead." 

 The twins' grins turned to grimaces of shock. Nobody seemed to know what to do. 
Perez was crying silently into a handkerchief: She had been close to Mad-Eye, Roberto 
knew, his favorite and his protégée at the Ministry of Magic. Villalba, who had sat down 
on the floor in the corner where he had most space, was dabbing at his eyes with his 
tablecloth-sized handkerchief. 

 Bill walked over to the sideboard and pulled out a bottle of fire-whisky and some 
glasses. 

 "Here," he said, and with a wave of his wand, eh sent twelve full glasses soaring 
through the room to each of them, holding the thirteenth aloft. "Mad-Eye." 

 "Mad-Eye," they all said, and drank. 

 "Mad-Eye," echoed Villalba, a little late, with a hiccup. The firewhisky seared 
Roberto's throat. It seemed to burn feeling back into him, dispelling the numbness and 
sense of unreality firing him with something that was like courage. 

 "So Mundungus disappeared?" said Cardozo, who had drained his own glass in one. 

 The atmosphere changed at once. Everybody looked tense, watching Cardozo, both 
wanting him to go on, it seemed to Roberto, and slightly afraid of what they might hear. 

 "I know what you're thinking," said Bill, "and I wondered that too, on the way 
back here, because they seemed to be expecting us, didn't they? But Mundungus can't 
have betrayed us. They didn't know there would be seven Robertos, that confused them the 


moment we appeared, and in case you've forgotten, it was Mundungus who suggested 
that little bit of skullduggery. Why wouldn't he have told them the essential point? I think 
Dung panicked, it's as simple as that. He didn't want to come in the first place, but Mad-
Eye made him, and You-Know-Who went straight for them. It was enough to make 
anyone panic." 

 "You-Know-Who acted exactly as Mad-Eye expected him to," sniffed Perez. 
"Mad-Eye said he'd expect the real Roberto to be with the toughest, most skilled Aurors. He 
chased Mad-Eye first, and when Mundungus gave them away he switched to 
Hector. . . . " 

 "Yes, and zat eez all very good," snapped Camila, "but still eet does not explain 'ow 
zey know we were moving 'Arry tonight, does eet? Somebody must 'ave been careless. 
Somebody let slip ze date to an outsider. It is ze only explanation for zem knowing ze 
date but not ze 'ole plan." 

 She glared around at them all, tear tracks still etched on her beautiful face, silently 
daring any of them to contradict her. Nobody did. The only sound to break the silence 
was that of Villalba hiccupping from behind his handkerchief. Roberto glanced at Villalba, 
who had just risked his own life to save Roberto's – Villalba, whom he loved, whom he 
trusted, who had once been tricked into giving Salvador crucial information in 
exchange for a dragon's egg. . . . 

 "No," Roberto said aloud, and they all looked at him, surprised: The firewhisky 
seemed to have amplified his voice. "I mean . . . if somebody made a mistake," Roberto 
went on, "and let something slip, I know they didn't mean to do it. It's not their fault," he 
repeated, again a little louder than he would usually have spoken. "We've got to trust each 
other. I trust all of you, I don't think anyone in this room would ever sell me to 
Salvador." 

 More silence followed his words. They were all looking at him; Roberto felt a little 
hot again, and drank some more firewhisky for something to do. As he drank, he thought 
of Mad-Eye. Mad-Eye had always been scathing about Dominguez's willingness to trust 
people. 

 "Well said, Roberto," said Pablo unexpectedly. 

 "Year, 'ear, 'ear," said Luis, with half a glance at Pablo, the corner of whose 
mouth twitched. 

 Cardozo was wearing an odd expression as he looked at Roberto. It was close to 
pitying. 

 "You think I'm a fool?" demanded Roberto. 

 "No, I think you're like Ricardo," said Cardozo, "who would have regarded it as the 
height of dishonor to mistrust his friends." 

 Roberto knew what Cardozo was getting at: that his father had been betrayed by his 
friend Gonzalo Salazar. He felt irrationally angry. He wanted to argue, but Cardozo had 
turned away from him, set down his glass upon a side table, and addressed Bill, "There's 
work to do. I can ask Hector whether –" 

 "No," said Bill at once, "I'll do it, I'll come." 

 "Where are you going?" said Perez and Camila together. 

 "Mad-Eye's body," said Cardozo. "We need to recover it." 

 "Can't it -- ?" began Mrs. Lopez with an appealing look at Bill. 

 "Wait?" said Bill, "Not unless you'd rather the Death Eaters took it?" 


 Nobody spoke. Cardozo and Bill said good bye and left. 

 The rest of them now dropped into chairs, all except for Roberto, who remained 
standing. The suddenness and completeness of death was with them like a presence. 

 "I've got to go too," said Roberto. 

 Ten pairs of startled eyes looked at him. 

 "Don't be silly, Roberto," said Mrs. Lopez, "What are you talking about?" 

 "I can't stay here." 

 He rubbed his forehead; it was prickling again, he had not hurt like this for more 
than a year. 

 "You're all in danger while I'm here. I don't want –" 

 "But don't be so silly!" said Mrs. Lopez. "The whole point of tonight was to get 
you here safely, and thank goodness it worked. And Camila's agreed to get married here 
rather than in France, we've arranged everything so that we can all stay together and look 
after you –" 

 She did not understand; she was making him feel worse, not better. 

 "If Salvador finds out I'm here –" 

 "But why should he?" asked Mrs. Lopez. 

 "There are a dozen places you might be now, Roberto," said Mr. Lopez. "He's got 
no way of knowing which safe house you're in." 

 "It's not me I'm worried for!" said Roberto. 

 "We know that," said Mr. Lopez quietly, but it would make our efforts tonight 
seem rather pointless if you left." 

 "Yer not goin' anywhere," growled Villalba. "Blimey, Roberto, after all we wen' 
through ter get you here?" 

 "Yeah, what about my bleeding ear?" said Luis, hoisting himself up on his 
cushions. 

 "I know that –" 

 "Mad-Eye wouldn't want –" 

 "I KNOW!" Roberto bellowed. 

 He felt beleaguered and blackmailed: Did they think he did not know what they 
had done for him, didn't they understand that it was for precisely that reason that he 
wanted to go now, before they had to suffer any more on his behalf? There was a long 
and awkward silence in which his scar continued to prickle and throb, and which was 
broken at last by Mrs. Lopez. 

 "Where's Hedwig, Roberto?" she said coaxingly. "We can put her up with 
Pidwidgeon and give her something to eat." 

 His insides clenched like a fist. He could not tell her the truth. He drank the last of 
his firewhisky to avoid answering. 

 "Wait till it gets out yeh did it again, Roberto," said Villalba. "Escaped him, fought 
him off when he was right on top of yeh!" 

 "It wasn't me," said Roberto flatly. "It was my wand. My wand acted of its own 
accord." 

 After a few moments, Carolina said gently, "But that's impossible, Roberto. You 
mean that you did magic without meaning to; you reacted instinctively." 


 "No," said Roberto. "The bike was falling, I couldn't have told you where 
Salvador was, but my wand spun in my hand and found him and shot a spell at him, and 
it wasn't even a spell I recognized. I've never made gold flames appear before." 

 "Often," said Mr. Lopez, "when you're in a pressured situation you can produce 
magic you never dreamed of. Small children often find, before they're trained –" 

 "It wasn't like that," said Roberto through gritted teeth. His scar was burning. He felt 
angry and frustrated; he hated the idea that they were all imagining him to have power to 
match Salvador's. 

 No one said anything. He knew that they did not believe him. Now that he came 
to think of it, he had never heard of a wand performing magic on its own before. 

 His scar seared with pain, it was all he could do not to moan aloud. Muttering 
about fresh air, he set down his glass and left the room. 

 As he crossed the yard, the great skeletal thestral looked up – rustled its enormous 
batlike wings, then resumed its grazing. Roberto stopped at the gate into the garden, staring 
out at its overgrown plants, rubbing his pounding forehead and thinking of Dominguez. 

 Dominguez would have believed him, he knew it. Dominguez would have 
known how and why Roberto's wand had acted independently, because Dominguez always 
had the answers; he had known about wands, had explained to Roberto the strange 
connection that existed between his wand and Salvador's . . . . But Dominguez, like 
Mad-Eye, like Gustavo, like his parents, like his poor owl, all were gone where Roberto could 
never talk to them again. He felt a burning in his throat that had nothing to do with 
firewhisky. . . . 

 And then, out of nowhere, the pain in his scar peaked. As he clutched his forehead 
and closed his eyes, a voice screamed inside his head. 

 "You told me the problem would be solved by using another's wand!" 

 And into his mind burst the vision of an emaciated old man lying in rags upon a 
stone floor, screaming, a horrible drawn-out scream, a scream of unendurable agony. . . . 

 "No! No! I beg you, I beg you. . . ." 

 "You lied to Lord Salvador, Ollivander!" 

 "I did not. . . . I swear I did not. . . ." 

 "You sought to help Gonzales, to help him escape me!" 

 "I swear I did not. . . . I believed a different wand would work. . . ." 

 "Explain, then, what happened. Mariano's wand is destroyed!" 

 "I cannot understand. . . . The connection . . . exists only . . between your two 
wands. . . ." 

 "Lies!" 

 "Please . . . I beg you. . . ." 

 And Roberto saw the white hand raise its wand and felt Salvador's surge of 
vicious anger, saw the frail old main on the floor writhe in agony – 

 "Roberto?" 

 It was over as quickly as it had come: Roberto stood shaking in the darkness, 
clutching the gate into the garden, his heart racing, his scar still tingling. It was several 
moments before he realized that Diego and Carolina were at his side. 

 "Roberto, come back in the house," Carolina whispered, "You aren't still thinking 
of leaving?" 

 "Yeah, you've got to stay, mate," said Diego, thumping Roberto on the back. 


 "Are you all right?" Carolina asked, close enough now to look into Roberto's face. 
"You look awful!" 

 "Well," said Roberto shakily, "I probably look better than Ollivander. . . ." 

 When he had finished telling them what he had seen, Diego looked appalled, but 
Carolina downright terrified. 

 "But it was supposed to have stopped! Your scar – it wasn't supposed to do this 
anymore! You mustn't let that connection open up again – Dominguez wanted you to 
close your mind!" 

 When he did not reply, she gripped his arm. 

 "Roberto, he's taking over the Ministry and the newspapers and half the Wizarding 
world! Don't let him inside your head too!" 

 

Chapter Six 

The Ghoul in Pajamas 

 

The shock of losing Mad-Eye hung over the house in the days that followed; 
Roberto kept expecting to see him stumping in through the back door like the other Order 
members, who passed in and out to relay news. Roberto felt that nothing but action would 
assuage his feelings of guilt and grief and that he ought to set out on his mission to find 
and destroy Horcruxes as soon as possible. 

“Well, you can’t do anything about the” – Diego mouthed the word Horcruxes – 
“till you’re seventeen. You’ve still got the Trace on you. And we can plan here as well as 
anywhere, can’t we? Or,” he dropped his voice to a whisper, “d’you reckon you already 
know where the You-Know-Whats are?” 

“No,” Roberto admitted. 

“I think Carolina’s been doing a bit of research,” said Diego. “She said she was 
saving it for when you got here.” 

They were sitting at the breakfast table; Mr. Lopez and Bill had just left for 
work. Mrs. Lopez had gone upstairs to wake Carolina and Martina, while Camila had 
drifted off to take a bath. 

“The Trace’ll break on the thirty-first,” said Roberto. “That means I only need to 
stay here four days. Then I can –“ 

“Five days,” Diego corrected him firmly. “We’ve got to stay for the wedding. 
They’ll kill us if we miss it.” 

Roberto understood “they” to mean Camila and Mrs. Lopez. 

“It’s one extra day,” said Diego, when Roberto looked mutinous. 

“Don’t they realize how important –?” 

“’Course they don’t,” said Diego. “They haven’t got a clue. And now you mention 
it, I wanted to talk to you about that.” 

Diego glanced toward the door into the hall to check that Mrs. Lopez was not 
returning yet, then leaned in closer to Roberto. 

“Mum’s been trying to get it out of Carolina and me. What we’re off to do. 
She’ll try you next, so brace yourself. Dad and Cardozo’ve both asked as well, but when we 


said Dominguez told you not to tell anyone except us, they dropped it. Not Mum, though. 
She’s determined.” 

Diego’s prediction came true within hours. Shortly before lunch, Mrs. Lopez 
detached Roberto from the others by asking him to help identify a lone man’s sock that she 
thought might have come out of his rucksack. Once she had him cornered in the tiny 
scullery off the kitchen, she started. 

“Diego and Carolina seem to think that the three of you are dropping out of 
Hogwarts,” she began in a light, casual tone. 

“Oh,” said Roberto. “Well, yeah. We are.” 

The mangle turned of its own accord in a corner, wringing out what looked like 
one of Mr. Lopez’s vests. 

“May I ask why you are abandoning your education?” said Mrs. Lopez. 

“Well, Dominguez left me . . . stuff to do,” mumbled Roberto. “Diego and Carolina 
know about it, and they want to come too.” 

“What sort of ‘stuff’?” 

“I’m sorry, I can’t –“ 

“Well, frankly, I think Raul and I have a right to know, and I’m sure Mr. And 
Mrs. Fernandez would agree!” said Mrs. Lopez. Roberto had been afraid of the “concerned 
parent” attack. He forced himself to look directly into her eyes, noticing as he did so that 
they were precisely the same shade of brown as Martina’s. This did not help. 

“Dominguez didn’t want anyone else to know, Mrs. Lopez. I’m sorry. Diego and 
Carolina don’t have to come, it’s their choice –“ 

“I don’t see that you have to go either!” she snapped, dropping all pretense now. 
“You’re barely of age, any of you! It’s utter nonsense, if Dominguez needed work doing, 
he had the whole Order at his command! Roberto, you must have misunderstood him. 
Probably he was telling you something he wanted done, and you took it to mean that he 
wanted you–“ 

“I didn’t misunderstand,” said Roberto flatly. “It’s got to be me.” 

He handed her back the single sock he was supposed to be identifying, which was 
patterned with golden bulrushes. 

“And that’s not mine. I don’t support Puddlemere United.” 

“Oh, of course not,” said Mrs. Lopez with a sudden and rather unnerving return 
to her casual tone. “I should have realized. Well, Roberto, while we’ve still got you here, 
you won’t mind helping with the preparations for Bill and Camila’s wedding, will you? 
There’s still so much to do.” 

“No – I – of course not,” said Roberto, disconcerted by this sudden change of 
subject. 

“Sweet of you,” she replied, and she smiled as she left the scullery. 

From that moment on, Mrs. Lopez kept Roberto, Diego and Carolina so busy with 
preparations for the wedding that they hardly had any time to think. The kindest 
explanation of this behavior would have been that Mrs. Lopez wanted to distract them 
all from thoughts of Mad-Eye and the terrors of their recent journey. After two days of 
nonstop cutlery cleaning, of color-matching favors, ribbons, and flowers, of de-gnoming 
the garden and helping Mrs. Lopez cook vast batches of canapés, however, Roberto 
started to suspect her of a different motive. All the jobs she handed out seemed to keep 
him, Diego, and Carolina away from one another; he had not had a chance to speak to the 


two of them alone since the first night, when he had told them about Salvador torturing 
Ollivander. 

“I think Mum thinks that if she can stop the three of you getting together and 
planning, she’ll be able to delay you leaving,” Martina told Roberto in an undertone, as they 
laid the table for dinner on the third night of his stay. 

“And then what does she think’s going to happen?” Roberto muttered. “Someone 
else might kill off Salvador while she’s holding us here making vol-au-vents?” 

He had spoken without thinking, and saw Martina’s face whiten. 

“So it’s true?” she said. “That’s what you’re trying to do?” 

“I – not – I was joking,” said Roberto evasively. 

They stared at each other, and there was something more than shock in Martina’s 
expression. Suddenly Roberto became aware that this was the first time that he had been 
alone with her since those stolen hours in secluded corners of the Hogwarts grounds. He 
was sure she was remembering them too. Both of them jumped as the door opened, and 
Mr. Lopez, Hector, and Bill walked in. 

They were often joined by other Order members for dinner now, because the 
Burrow had replaced number twelve, Grimmauld Place as the headquarters. Mr. Lopez 
had explained that after the death of Dominguez, their Secret-Keeper, each of the people 
to whom Dominguez had confided Grimmauld Place’s location had become a Secret-
Keeper in turn. 

“And as there are around twenty of us, that greatly dilutes the power of the 
Fidelius Charm. Twenty times as many opportunities for the Death Eaters to get the 
secret out of somebody. We can’t expect it to hold much longer.” 

“But surely Peralta will have told the Death Eaters the address by now?” asked 
Roberto. 

“Well, Mad-Eye set up a couple of curses against Peralta in case he turns up there 
again. We hope they’ll be strong enough both to keep him out and to bind his tongue if he 
tries to talk about the place, but we can’t be sure. It would have been insane to keep using 
the place as headquarters now that its protection has become so shaky.” 

The kitchen was so crowded that evening it was difficult to maneuver knives and 
forks. Roberto found himself crammed beside Martina; the unsaid things that had just passed 
between them made him wish they had been separated by a few more people. He was 
trying so hard to avoid brushing her arm he could barely cut his chicken. 

“No news about Mad-Eye?” Roberto asked Bill. 

“Nothing,” replied Bill. 

They had not been able to hold a funeral for Acosta, because Bill and Cardozo had 
failed to recover his body. It had been difficult to know where he might have fallen, given 
the darkness and the confusion of the battle. 

“The Daily Prophet hasn’t said a word about him dying or about finding the 
body,” Bill went on. “But that doesn’t mean much. It’s keeping a lot quiet these days.” 

“And they still haven’t called a hearing about all the underage magic I used 
escaping the Death Eaters?” Roberto called across the table to Mr. Lopez, who shook his 
head. 

“Because they know I had no choice or because they don’t want me to tell the 
world Salvador attacked me?” 


“The latter, I think. Scrimgeour doesn’t want to admit that You-Know-Who is as 
powerful as he is, nor that Azkaban’s seen a mass breakout.” 

“Yeah, why tell the public the truth?” said Roberto, clenching his knife so tightly 
that the faint scars on the back of his right hand stood out, white against his skin: I must 
not tell lies. 

“Isn’t anyone at the Ministry prepared to stand up to him?” asked Diego angrily. 

“Of course, Diego, but people are terrified,” Mr. Lopez replied, “terrified that 
they will be next to disappear, their children the next to be attacked! There are nasty 
rumors going around; I for one don’t believe the Muggle Studies professor at Hogwarts 
resigned. She hasn’t been seen for weeks now. Meanwhile Scrimgeour remains shut up in 
his office all day; I just hope he’s working on a plan.” 

There was a pause in which Mrs. Lopez magicked the empty plates onto the 
work surface and served apple tart. 

“We must decide ‘ow you will be disguised, ‘Arry,” said Camila, once everyone 
had pudding. “For ze wedding,” she added, when he looked confused. “Of course, none 
of our guests are Death Eaters, but we cannot guarantee zat zey will not let something 
slip after zey ‘ave ‘ad champagne.” 

From this, Roberto gathered that she still suspected Villalba. 

“Yes, good point,” said Mrs. Lopez from the top of the table where she sat, 
spectacles perched on the end of her nose, scanning an immense list of jobs that she had 
scribbled on a very long piece of parchment. “Now, Diego, have you cleaned out your 
room yet?” 

“Why?” exclaimed Diego, slamming his spoon down and glaring at his mother. 
“Why does my room have to be cleaned out? Roberto and I are fine with it the way it is!” 

“We are holding your brother’s wedding here in a few days’ time, young man –“ 

“And are they getting married in my bedroom?” asked Diego furiously. “No! So 
why in the name of Merlin’s saggy left –“ 

“Don’t talk to your mother like that,” said Mr. Lopez firmly. “And do as you’re 
told.” 

Diego scowled at both his parents, then picked up his spoon and attacked the last 
few mouthfuls of his apple tart. 

“I can help, some of it’s my mess.” Roberto told Diego, but Mrs. Lopez cut across 
him. 

“No, Roberto, dear, I’d much rather you helped Raul much out the chickens, and 
Carolina, I’d be ever so grateful if you’d change the sheets for Monsieur and Madame 
Saenz; you know they’re arriving at eleven tomorrow morning.” 

But as it turned out, there was very little to do for the chickens. “There’s no need 
to, er, mention it to Alicia,” Mr. Lopez told Roberto, blocking his access to the coop, “but, 
er, Ted Perez sent me most of what was left of Gustavo’s bike and, er, I’m hiding – that’s 
to say, keeping – it in here. Fantastic stuff: There’s an exhaust gaskin, as I believe it’s 
called, the most magnificent battery, and it’ll be a great opportunity to find out how 
brakes work. I’m going to try and put it all back together again when Alicia’s not – I 
mean, when I’ve got time.” 

When they returned to the house, Mrs. Lopez was nowhere to be seen, so Roberto 
slipped upstairs to Diego’s attic bedroom. 


“I’m doing it, I’m doing – ! Oh, it’s you,” said Diego in relief, as Roberto entered the 
room. Diego lay back down on the bed, which he had evidently just vacated. The room was 
just as messy as it had been all week; the only chance was that Carolina was now sitting 
in the far corner, her fluffy ginger cat, Crookshanks, at her feet, sorting books, some of 
which Roberto recognized as his own, into two enormous piles. 

“Hi, Roberto,” she said, as he sat down on his camp bed. 

“And how did you manage to get away?” 

“Oh, Diego’s mum forgot that she asked Martina and me to change the sheets 
yesterday,” said Carolina. She threw Numerology and Grammatica onto one pile and 
The Rise and Fall of the Dark Arts onto the other. 

“We were just talking about Mad-Eye,” Diego told Roberto. “I reckon he might have 
survived.” 

“But Bill saw him hit by the Killing Curse,” said Roberto. 

“Yeah, but Bill was under attack too,” said Diego. “How can he be sure what he 
saw?” 

“Even if the Killing Curse missed, Mad-Eye still fell about a thousand feet,” said 
Carolina, now weight Quidditch Teams of Britain and Ireland in her hand. 

“He could have used a Shield Charm –“ 

“Camila said his wand was blasted out of his hand,” said Roberto. 

“Well, all right, if you want him to be dead,” said Diego grumpily, punching his 
pillow into a more comfortable shape. 

“Of course we don’t want him to be dead!” said Carolina, looking shocked. “It’s 
dreadful that he’s dead! But we’re being realistic!” 

For the first time, Roberto imagined Mad-Eye’s body, broken as Dominguez’s had 
been, yet with that one eye still whizzing in its socket. He felt a stab of revulsion mixed 
with a bizarre desire to laugh. 

“The Death Eaters probably tidied up after themselves, that’s why no one’s found 
him,” said Diego wisely. 

“Yeah,” said Roberto. “Like Barty Crouch, turned into a bone and buried in 
Villalba’s front garden. They probably transfigured Acosta and stuffed him –“ 

“Don’t!” squealed Carolina. Startled, Roberto looked over just in time to see her 
burst into tears over her copy of Spellman’s Syllabary. 

“Oh no,” said Roberto, struggling to get up from the old camp bed. “Carolina, I 
wasn’t trying to upset –“ 

But with a great creaking of rusty bedsprings, Diego bounded off the bed and got 
there first. One arm around Carolina, he fished in his jeans pocket and withdrew a 
revolting-looking handkerchief that he had used to clean out the oven earlier. Hastily 
pulling out his wand, he pointed it at the rag and said, “Tergeo.” 

The wand siphoned off most of the grease. Looking rather pleased with himself, 
Diego handed the slightly smoking handkerchief to Carolina. 

“Oh . . . thanks, Diego. . . . I’m sorry. . . .” She blew her nose and hiccupped. “It’s 
just so awf-ful, isn’t it? R-right after Dominguez . . . I j-just n-never imagined Mad-Eye 
dying, somehow, he seemed so tough!” 

“Yeah, I know,” said Diego, giving her a squeeze. “But you know what he’d say to 
us if he was here?” 

“’C-constant vigilance,’” said Carolina, mopping her eyes. 


“That’s right,” said Diego, nodding. “He’d tell us to learn from what happened to 
him. And what I’ve learned is not to trust that cowardly little squit, Mundungus.” 

Carolina gave a shaky laugh and leaned forward to pick up two more books. A 
second later, Diego had snatched his arm back from around her shoulders; she had dropped 
The Monster of Monsters on his foot. The book had broken free from its restraining belt 
and snapped viciously at Diego’s ankle. 

“I’m sorry, I’m sorry!” Carolina cried as Roberto wrenched the book from Diego’s 
leg and retied it shit. 

“What are you doing with all those books anyway?” Diego asked, limping back to 
his bed. 

“Just trying to decide which ones to take with us,” said Carolina, “When we’re 
looking for the Horcruxes.” 

“Oh, of course,” said Diego, clapping a hand to his forehead. “I forgot we’ll be 
hunting down Salvador in a mobile library.” 

“Ha ha,” said Carolina, looking down at Spellman’s Syllabary. “I wonder . . . 
will we need to translate runes? It’s possible. . . . I think we’d better take it, to be safe.” 

She dropped the syllabary onto the larger of the two piles and picked up Hogwarts, 
A History. 

“Listen,” said Roberto. 

He had sat up straight. Diego and Carolina looked at him with similar mixtures of 
resignation and defiance. 

“I know you said after Dominguez’s funeral that you wanted to come with me,” 
Roberto began. 

“Here he goes,” Diego said to Carolina, rolling his eyes. 

“As we knew he would,” he sighed, turning back to the books. “You know, I 
think I will take Hogwarts, A History. Even if we’re not going back there, I don’t think 
I’d feel right if I didn’t have it with –“ 

“Listen!” said Roberto again. 

“No, Roberto, you listen,” said Carolina. “We’re coming with you. That was 
decided months ago – years, really.” 

“But –“ 

“Shut up,” Diego advised him. 

“– are you sure you’ve thought this through?” Roberto persisted. 

“Let’s see,” said Carolina, slamming Travels with Trolls onto the discarded pile 
with a rather fierce look. “I’ve been packing for days, so we’re ready to leave at a 
moment’s notice, which for your information has included doing some pretty difficult 
magic, not to mention smuggling Mad-Eye’s whole stock of Polyjuice Potion right under 
Diego’s mum’s nose. 

“I’ve also modified my parents’ memories so that they’re convinced they’re really 
called Wendell and Monica Wilkins, and that their life’s ambition is to move to Australia, 
which they have now done. That’s to make it more difficult for Salvador to track them 
down and interrogate them about me – or you, because unfortunately, I’ve told them quite 
a bit about you. 

“Assuming I survive our hunt for the Horcruxes, I’ll find Mum and Dad and lift 
the enchantment. If I don’t – well, I think I’ve cast a good enough charm to keep them 


safe and happy. Wendell and Monica Wilkins don’t know that they’ve got a daughter, 
you see.” 

Carolina’s eyes were swimming with tears again. Diego got back off the bed, put 
his arm around her once more, and frowned at Roberto as though reproaching him for lack 
of tact. Roberto could not think of anything to say, not least because it was highly unusual 
for Diego to be teaching anyone else tact. 

“I – Carolina, I’m sorry – I didn’t –“ 

“Didn’t realize that Diego and I know perfectly well what might happen if we come 
with you? Well, we do. Diego, show Roberto what you’ve done.” 

“Nah, he’s just eaten,” said Diego. 

“Go on, he needs to know!” 

“Oh, all right. Roberto, come here.” 

For the second time Diego withdrew his arm from around Carolina and stumped 
over to the door. 

“C’mon.” 

“Why?” Roberto asked, following Diego out of the room onto the tiny landing. 

“Descendo,” muttered Diego, pointing his wand at the low ceiling. A hatch opened 
right over their heads and a ladder slid down to their feet. A horrible, half-sucking, half-
moaning sound came out of the square hole, along with an unpleasant smell like open 
drains. 

“That’s your ghoul, isn’t it?” asked Roberto, who had never actually met the 
creature that sometimes disrupted the nightly silence. 

“Yeah, it is,” said Diego, climbing the ladder. “Come and have a look at him.” 

Roberto followed Diego up the few short steps into the tiny attic space. His head and 
shoulders were in the room before he caught sight of the creature curled up a few feet 
from him, fast asleep in the gloom with its large mouth wide open. 

“But it . . . it looks . . . do ghouls normally wear pajamas?” 

“No,” said Diego. “Nor have they usually got red hair or that number of pustules.” 

Roberto contemplated the thing, slightly revolted. It was human in shape and size, 
and was wearing what, now that Roberto’s eyes became used to the darkness, was clearly 
an old pair of Diego’s pajamas. He was also sure that ghouls were generally rather slimy 
and bald, rather than distinctly hairy and covered in angry purple blisters. 

“He’s me, see?” said Diego. 

“No,” said Roberto. “I don’t.” 

“I’ll explain it back in my room, the smell’s getting to me,” said Diego. They 
climbed back down the ladder, which Diego returned to the ceiling, and rejoined Carolina, 
who was still sorting books. 

“Once we’ve left, the ghoul’s going to come and live down here in my room,” 
said Diego. “I think he’s really looking forward to it – well, it’s hard to tell, because all he 
can do is moan and drool – but he nods a lot when you mention it. Anyway, he’s going to 
be me with spattergroit. Good, eh?” 

Roberto merely looked his confusion. 

“It is!” said Diego, clearly frustrated that Roberto had not grasped the brilliance of the 
plan. “Look, when we three don’t turn up at Hogwarts again, everyone’s going to think 
Carolina and I must be with you, right? Which means the Death Eaters will go straight 
for our families to see if they’ve got information on where you are.” 


“But hopefully it’ll look like I’ve gone away with Mum and Dad; a lot of Muggle-
borns are talking about going into hiding at the moment,” said Carolina. 

“We can’t hide my whole family, it’ll look too fishy and they can’t all leave their 
jobs,” said Diego. “So we’re going to put out the story that I’m seriously ill with 
spattergroit, which is why I can’t go back to school. If anyone comes calling to 
investigate, Mum or Dad can show them the ghoul in my bed, covered in pustules. 
Spattergroit’s really contagious, so they’re not going to want to go near him. It won’t 
matter that he can’t say anything, either, because apparently you can’t once the fungus 
has spread to your uvula.” 

“And your mum and dad are in on this plan?” asked Roberto. 

“Dad is. He helped Pablo and Luis transform the ghoul. Mum . . . well, you’ve 
seen what she’s like. She won’t accept we’re going till we’re gone.” 

There was silence in the room, broken only by gentle thuds as Carolina 
continued to throw books onto one pile or the other. Diego sat watching her, and Roberto 
looked from one to the other, unable to say anything. The measure they had taken to 
protect their families made him realize, more than anything else could have done, that 
they really were going to come with him and that they knew exactly how dangerous that 
would be. He wanted to tell them what that meant to him, but he simply could not find 
words important enough. 

Through the silence came the muffled sounds of Mrs. Lopez shouting from four 
floors below. 

“Martina’s probably left a speck of dust on a poxy napkin ring,” said Diego. “I dunno 
why the Saenzs have got to come two days before the wedding.” 

“Camila’s sister’s a bridesmaid, she needs to be here for the rehearsal, and she’s too 
young to come on her own,” said Carolina, as she pored indecisively over Break with a 
Banshee. 

“Well, guests aren’t going to help Mum’s stress levels,” said Diego. 

“What we really need to decide,” said Carolina, tossing Defensive Magical 
Theory into the bin without a second glance and picking up An Appraisal of Magical 
Education in Europe, “is where we’re going after we leave here. I know you said you 
wanted to go to Godric’s Hollow first, Roberto, and I understand why, but . . . well . . . 
shouldn’t we make the Horcruxes our priority?” 

“If we knew where any of the Horcruxes were, I’d agree with you,” said Roberto, 
who did not believe that Carolina really understood his desire to return to Godric’s 
Hollow. His parents’ graves were only part of the attraction: He had a strong, though 
inexplicable, feeling that the place held answers for him. Perhaps it was simply because it 
was there that he had survived Salvador’s Killing Curse; now that he was facing the 
challenge of repeating the feat, Roberto was drawn to the place where it had happened, 
wanting to understand. 

“Don’t you think there’s a possibility that Salvador’s keeping a watch on 
Godric’s Hollow?” Carolina asked. “He might expect you to go back and visit your 
parents’ graves once you’re free to go wherever you like?” 

This had not occurred to Roberto. While he struggled to find a counterargument, 
Diego spoke up, evidently following his own train of thought. 

“This R.A.B. person,” he said. “You know, the one who stole the real locket?” 

Carolina nodded. 


“He said in his note he was going to destroy it, didn’t he?” 

Roberto dragged his rucksack toward him and pulled out the fake Horcrux in which 
R.A.B.’s note was still folded. 

“’I have stolen the real Horcrux and intend to destroy it as soon as I can.’” Roberto 
read out. 

“Well, what if he did finish it off?” said Diego. 

“Or she.” Interposed Carolina. 

“Whichever,” said Diego. “it’d be one less for us to do!” 

“Yes, but we’re still going to have to try and trace the real locket, aren’t we?” said 
Carolina, “to find out whether or not it’s destroyed.” 

“And once we get hold of it, how do you destroy a Horcrux?” asked Diego. 

“Well,” said Carolina, “I’ve been researching that.” 

“How?” asked Roberto. “I didn’t think there were any books on Horcruxes in the 
library?” 

“There weren’t,” said Carolina, who had turned pink. “Dominguez removed 
them all, but he – he didn’t destroy them.” 
Diego sat up straight, wide-eyed. 

“How in the name of Merlin’s pants have you managed to get your hands on those 
Horcrux books?” 

“It – it wasn’t stealing!” said Carolina, looking from Roberto to Diego with a kind of 
desperation. “They were still library books, even if Dominguez had taken them off the 
shelves. Anyway, if he really didn’t want anyone to get at them, I’m sure he would have 
made it much harder to –“ 

“Get to the point!” said Diego. 

“Well . . . it was easy,” said Carolina in a small voice. “I just did a Summoning 
Charm. You know – Accio. And – they zoomed out of Dominguez’s study window right 
into the girls’ dormitory.” 

“But when did you do this?” Roberto asked, regarding Carolina with a mixture of 
admiration and incredulity. 

“Just after his – Dominguez’s – funeral,” said Carolina in an even smaller voice. 
“Right after we agreed we’d leave school and go and look for the Horcruxes. When I 
went back upstairs to get my things it – it just occurred to me that the more we knew 
about them, the better it would be . . . and I was alone in there . . . so I tried . . . and it 
worked. They flew straight in through the open window and I – I packed them.” 

She swallowed and then said imploringly, “I can’t believe Dominguez would 
have been angry, it’s not as though we’re going to use the information to make a Horcrux, 
is it?” 

“Can you hear us complaining?” said Diego. “Where are these books anyway?” 

Carolina rummaged for a moment and then extracted from the pile a large 
volume, bound in faded black leather. She looked a little nauseated and held it as gingerly 
as if it were something recently dead. 

“This is the one that gives explicit instructions on how to make a Horcrux. Secrets 
of the Darkest Art – it’s a horrible book, really awful, full of evil magic. I wonder when 
Dominguez removed it from the library. . . . if he didn’t do it until he was headmaster, I 
bet Salvador got all the instruction he needed from here.” 


“Why did he have to ask Ramirez how to make a Horcrux, then, if he’d already 
read that?” asked Diego. 

“He only approached Ramirez to find out what would happen if you split your 
soul into seven,” said Roberto. “Dominguez was sure Castillo already knew how to make a 
Horcrux by the time he asked Ramirez about them. I think you’re right, Carolina, that 
could easily have been where he got the information.” 

“And the more I’ve read about them,” said Carolina, “the more horrible they 
seem, and the less I can believe that he actually made six. It warns in this book how 
unstable you make the rest of your soul by ripping it, and that’s just by making one 
Horcrux!” 

Roberto remembered what Dominguez had said about Salvador moving beyond 
“usual evil.” 

“Isn’t there any way of putting yourself back together?” Diego asked. 

“Yes,” said Carolina with a hollow smile, “but it would be excruciatingly 
painful.” 

“Why? How do you do it?” asked Roberto. 

“Remorse,” said Carolina. “You’ve got to really feel what you’ve done. There’s 
a footnote. Apparently the pain of it can destroy you. I can’t see Salvador attempting it 
somehow, can you?” 

“No,” said Diego, before Roberto could answer. “So does it say how to destroy 
Horcruxes in that book?” 

“Yes,” said Carolina, now turning the fragile pages as if examining rotting 
entrails, “because it warns Dark wizards how strong they have to make the enchantments 
on them. From all that I’ve read, what Roberto did to Castillo’s diary was one of the few 
really foolproof ways of destroying a Horcrux.” 

“What, stabbing it with a basilisk fang?” asked Roberto. 

“Oh well, lucky we’ve got such a large supply of basilisk fangs, then,” said Diego. 
“I was wondering what we were going to do with them.” 

“It doesn’t have to be a basilisk fang,” said Carolina patiently. “It has to be 
something so destructive that the Horcrux can’t repair itself. Basilisk venom only has one 
antidote, and it’s incredibly rare –“ 

“– phoenix tears,” said Roberto, nodding. 

“Exactly,” said Carolina. “Our problem is that there are very few substances as 
destructive as basilisk venom, and they’re all dangerous to carry around with you. That’s 
a problem we’re going to have to solve, though, because ripping, smashing, or crushing a 
Horcrux won’t do the trick. You’ve got to put it beyond magical repair.” 

“But even if we wreck the thing it lives in,” said Diego, “why can’t the bit of soul in 
it just go and live in something else?” 

“Because a Horcrux is the complete opposite of a human being.” 

Seeing that Roberto and Diego looked thoroughly confused, Carolina hurried on. 
“Look, if I picked up a sword right now, Diego, and ran you through with it, I wouldn’t 
damage your soul at all.” 

”Which would be a real comfort to me, I’m sure,” said Diego. Roberto laughed. 

“It should be, actually! But my point is that whatever happens to your body, your 
soul will survive, untouched,” said Carolina. “But it’s the other way round with a 


Horcrux. The fragment of soul inside it depends on its container, its enchanted body, for 
survival. It can’t exist without it.” 

“That diary sort of died when I stabbed it,” said Roberto, remembering ink pouring 
like blood from the punctured pages, and the screams of the piece of Salvador’s soul as 
it vanished. 

“And once the diary was properly destroyed, the bit of soul trapped in it could no 
longer exist. Martina tried to get rid of the diary before you did, flushing it away, but 
obviously it came back good as new.” 

“Hang on,” said Diego, frowning. “The bit of soul in that diary was possessing 
Martina, wasn’t it? How does that work, then?” 

“While the magical container is still intact, the bit of soul inside it can flit in and 
out of someone if they get too close to the object. I don’t mean holding it for too long, it’s 
nothing to do with touching it,” she added before Diego could speak. “I mean close 
emotionally. Martina poured her heart out into that diary, she made herself incredibly 
vulnerable. You’re in trouble if you get too fond of or dependent on the Horcrux.”
