“I wonder how Dominguez destroyed the ring?” said Roberto. “Why didn’t I ask 
him? I never really . . .” 

His voice trailed away: He was thinking of all the things he should have asked 
Dominguez, and of how, since the headmaster had died, it seemed to Roberto that he had 
wasted so many opportunities when Dominguez had been alive, to find out more . . . to 
find out everything. . . . 

The silence was shattered as the bedroom door flew open with a wall-shaking 
crash. Carolina shrieked and dropped Secrets of the Darkest Art; Crookshanks streaked 
under the bed, hissing indignantly; Diego jumped off the bed, skidded on a discarded 
Paulacolate Frog wrapper, and smacked his head on the opposite wall; and Roberto 
instinctively dived for his wand before realizing that he was looking up at Mrs. Lopez, 
whose hair was disheveled and whose face was contorted with rage. 

“I’m so sorry to break up this cozy little gathering,” she said, her voice trembling. 
“I’m sure you all need your rest . . . but there are wedding presents stacked in my room 
that need sorting out and I was under the impression that you had agreed to help.” 

“Oh yes,” said Carolina, looking terrified as she leapt to her feet, sending books 
flying in every direction. “we will . . . we’re sorry . . .” 

With an anguished look at Roberto and Diego, Carolina hurried out of the room after 
Mrs. Lopez. 

“it’s like being a house-elf,” complained Diego in an undertone, still massaging his 
head as he and Roberto followed. “Except without the job satisfaction. The sooner this 
wedding’s over, the happier, I’ll be.” 

“Yeah,” said Roberto, “then we’ll have nothing to do except find Horcruxes. . . . 
It’ll be like a holiday, won’t it?” 

Diego started to laugh, but at the sight of the enormous pile of wedding presents 
waiting for them in Mrs. Lopez’s room, stopped quite abruptly. 

The Saenzs arrived the following morning at eleven o’ clock. Roberto, Diego, 
Carolina and Martina were feeling quite resentful toward Camila’s family by this time; and 
it was with ill grace that Diego stumped back upstairs to put on matching socks, and Roberto 
attempted to flatten his hair. Once they had all been deemed smart enough, they trooped 
out into the sunny backyard to await the visitors. 


Roberto had never seen the place looking so tidy. The rusty cauldrons and old 
Wellington boots that usually littered the steps by the back door were gone, replaced by 
two new Flutterby bushes standing either side of the door in large pots; though there was 
no breeze, the leaves waved lazily, giving an attractive rippling effect. The chickens had 
been shut away, the yard had been swept, and the nearby garden had been pruned, 
plucked, and generally spruced up, although Roberto, who liked it in its overgrown state, 
thought that it looked rather forlorn without its usual contingent of capering gnomes. 

He had lost track of how many security enchantments had been placed upon the 
Burrow by both the Order and the Ministry; all he knew was that it was no longer 
possible for anybody to travel by magic directly into the place. Mr. Lopez had 
therefore gone to meet the Saenzs on top of a nearby hill, where they were to arrive by 
Portkey. The first sound of their approach was an unusually high-pitched laugh, which 
turned out to be coming from Mr. Lopez, who appeared at the gate moments later, 
laden with luggage and leading a beautiful blonde woman in long, leaf green robes, who 
could be Camila’s mother. 

“Maman!” cried Camila, rushing forward to embrace her. “Papa!” 

Monsieur Saenz was nowhere near as attractive as his wife; he was a head 
shorter and extremely plumb, with a little, pointed black beard. However, he looked 
good-natured. Bouncing towards Mrs. Lopez on high-heeled boots, he kissed her twice 
on each cheek, leaving her flustered. 

“You ‘ave been so much trouble,” he said in a deep voice. “Camila tells us you ‘ave 
been working very ‘ard.” 

“Oh, it’s been nothing, nothing!” trilled Mrs. Lopez. “No trouble at all!” 

Diego relieved his feelings by aiming a kick at a gnome who was peering out from 
behind one of the new Flutterby bushes. 

“Dear lady!” said Monsieur Saenz, still holding Mrs. Lopez’s hand between 
his own two plump ones and beaming. “We are most honored at the approaching union of 
our two families! Let me present my wife, Apolline.” 

Madame Saenz glided forward and stooped to kiss Mrs. Lopez too. 

“Enchantée,” she said. “Your ‘usband ‘as been telling us such amusing stories!” 

Mr. Lopez gave a maniacal laugh; Mrs. Lopez threw him a look, upon which 
he became immediately silent and assumed an expression appropriate to the sickbed of a 
close friend. 

“And, of course, you ‘ave met my leetle daughter, Gabrielle!” said Monsieur 
Saenz. Gabrielle was Camila in miniature; eleven years old, with waist-length hair of 
pure, silvery blonde, she gave Mrs. Lopez a dazzling smile and hugged her, then threw 
Roberto a glowing look, batting her eyelashes. Martina cleared her throat loudly. 

“Well, come in, do!” said Mrs. Lopez brightly, and she ushered the Saenzs 
into the house, with many “No, please!”s and “After you!”s and “Not at all!”s. 

The Saenzs, it soon transpired, were helpful, pleasant guests. They were 
pleased with everything and keen to assist with the preparations for the wedding. 
Monsieur Saenz pronounced everything from the seating plan to the bridesmaids’ 
shoes “Charmant!” Madame Saenz was most accomplished at household spells and 
had the oven properly cleaned in a trice; Gabrielle followed her elder sister around, trying 
to assist in any way she could and jabbering away in rapid French. 


On the downside, the Burrow was not built to accommodate so many people. Mr. 
and Mrs. Lopez were now sleeping in the sitting room, having shouted down Monsieur 
and Madame Saenz’s protests and insisted they take their bedroom. Gabrielle was 
sleeping with Camila in Miguel’s old room, and Bill would be sharing with Charlie, his best 
man, once Charlie arrived from Romania. Opportunities to make plans together became 
virtually nonexistent, and it was in desperation that Roberto, Diego and Carolina took to 
volunteering to feed the chickens just to escape the overcrowded house. 

“But she still won’t leave us alone!” snarled Diego, and their second attempt at a 
meeting in the yard was foiled by the appearance of Mrs. Lopez carrying a large basket 
of laundry in her arms. 

“Oh, good, you’ve fed the chickens,” she called as she approached them. “We’d 
better shut them away again before the men arrive tomorrow . . . to put up the tent for the 
wedding,” she explained, pausing to lean against the henhouse. She looked exhausted. 
“Millamant’s Magic Marquees . . . they’re very good. Bill’s escorting them. . . . You’d 
better stay inside while they’re here, Roberto. I must say it does complicate organizing a 
wedding, having all these security spells around the place.” 

“I’m sorry,” said Roberto humbly. 

“Oh, don’t be silly, dear!” said Mrs. Lopez at once. “I didn’t mean – well, your 
safety’s much more important! Actually, I’ve been wanting to ask you how you want to 
celebrate your birthday, Roberto. Seventeen, after all, it’s an important day. . . .” 

“I don’t want a fuss,” said Roberto quickly, envisaging the additional strain this 
would put on them all. “Really, Mrs. Lopez, just a normal dinner would be fine. . . . It’s 
the day before the wedding. . . .” 

“Oh, well, if you’re sure, dear. I’ll invite Pedro and Perez, shall I? And how 
about Villalba?” 

“That’d be great,” said Roberto. “But please, don’t go to loads of trouble.” 

“Not at all, not at all . . . It’s no trouble. . . .” 

She looked at him, a long, searching look, then smiled a little sadly, straightened 
up, and walked away. Roberto watched as she waved her wand near the washing line, and 
the damp clothes rose into the air to hang themselves up, and suddenly he felt a great 
wave of remorse for the inconvenience and the pain he was giving her. 

 

 

Chapter Seven 

 The Will of Alfonso Dominguez 

 

He was walking along a mountain road in the cool blue light of dawn. Far below, 
swathed in mist, was the shadow of a small town. Was the man he sought down there, the 
man he needed so badly he could think of little else, the man who held the answer, the 
answer to his problem...? 

"Oi, wake up." 

Roberto opened his eyes. He was lying again on the camp bed in Diego's dingy attic 
room. The sun had not yet risen and the room was still shadowy. Pigwidgeon was asleep 
with his head under his tiny wing. The scar on Roberto's forehead was prickling. 


"You were muttering in your sleep." 

"Was I?" 

"Yeah. 'Gregorovitch.' You kept saying 'Gregorovitch.'" 

Roberto was not wearing his glasses; Diego's face appeared slightly blurred. 

"Who's Gregorovitch?" 

 

"I dunno, do I?" You were the one saying it." 

Roberto rubbed his forehead, thinking. He had a vague idea he had heard the name 
before, but he could not think where. 

"I think Salvador's looking for him." 

"Poor bloke," said Diego fervently. 

Roberto sat up, still rubbing his scar, now wide awake. He tried to remember 
exactly what he had seen in the dream, but all that came back was a mountainous horizon 
and the outline of the little village cradled in a deep valley. 

"I think he's abroad." 

"Who, Gregorovitch?" 

"Salvador. I think he's somewhere abroad, looking for Gregorovitch. It didn't 
look like anywhere in Britain." 

"You reckon you were seeing into his mind again?" 

Diego sounded worried. 

"Do me a favor and don't tell Carolina," said Roberto. "Although how she expects 
me to stop seeing stuff in my sleep..." 

He gazed up at little Pigwidgeon's cage, thinking...Why was the name 
"Gregorovitch" familiar? 

"I think," he said slowly, "he's got something to do with Quidditch. There's some 
connection, but I can't--I can't think what it is." 

"Quidditch?" said Diego. "Sure you're not thinking of Gorgovitch?" 

"Who?" 

"Dragomir Gorgovitch, Chaser, transferred to the Chudley Cannons for a record 
fee two years ago. Record holder for most Quaffle drops in a season." 

"No," said Roberto. "I'm definitely not thinking of Gorgovitch." 

 

"I try not to either," said Diego. "Well, happy birthday anyway." 

"Wow -- that's right, I forgot! I'm seventeen!" 

Roberto seized the wand lying beside his camp bed, pointed it at the cluttered desk 
where he had left his glasses, and said, "Accio Glasses!" Although they were only around 
a foot away, there was something immensely satisfying about seeing them zoom toward 
him, at least until they poked him in the eye. 

"Slick," snorted Diego. 

Reveling in the removal of his Trace, Roberto sent Diego's possessions flying around 
the room, causing Pigwidgeon to wake up and flutter excitedly around his cage. Roberto 
also tried tying the laces of his trainers by magic (the resultant knot took several minutes 
to untie by hand) and, purely for the pleasure of it, turned the orange robes on Diego's 
Chudley Cannons posters bright blue. 


"I'd do your fly by hand, though," Diego advised Roberto, sniggering when Roberto 
immediately checked it. "Here's your present. Unwrap it up here, it's not for my mother's 
eyes." 

"A book?" said Roberto as he took the rectangular parcel. "Bit of a departure from 
tradition, isn't it?" 

"This isn't your average book," said Diego. "It'd pure gold: Twelve Fail-Safe Ways 
to Charm Witches. Explains everything you need to know about girls. If only I'd had this 
last year I'd have known exactly how to get rid of Lavender and I would've known how to 
get going with... Well, Pablo and Luis gave me a copy, and I've learned a lot. You'd be 
surprised, it's not all about wandwork, either." 

When they arrived in the kitchen they found a pile of presents waiting on the table. 
Bill and Monsieur Saenz were finishing their breakfasts, while Mrs. Lopez stood 
chatting to them over the frying pan. 

 

"Raul told me to wish you a happy seventeenth, Roberto," said Mrs. Lopez, 
beaming at him. "He had to leave early for work, but he'll be back for dinner. That's our 
present on top." 

Roberto sat down, took the square parcel she had indicated, and unwrapped it. 
Inside was a watch very like the one Mr. and Mrs. Lopez had given Diego for his 
seventeenth; it was gold, with stars circling around the race instead of hands. 

"It's traditional to give a wizard a watch when he comes of age," said Mrs. 
Lopez, watching him anxiously from beside the cooker. "I'm afraid that one isn't new 
like Diego's, it was actually my brother Fabian's and he wasn't terribly careful with his 
possessions, it's a bit dented on the back, but--" 

The rest of her speech was lost; Roberto had got up and hugged her. He tried to put 
a lot of unsaid things into the hug and perhaps she understood them, because she patted 
his cheek clumsily when he released her, then waved her wand in a slightly random way, 
causing half a pack of bacon to flop out of the frying pan onto the floor. 

"Happy birthday, Roberto!" said Carolina, hurrying into the kitchen and adding her 
own present to the top of the pile. "It's not much, but I hope you like it. What did you get 
him?" she added to Diego, who seemed not to hear her. 

"Come on, then, open Carolina's!" said Diego. 

She had bought him a new Sneakoscope. The other packages contained an 
enchanted razor from Bill and Camila ("Ah yes, zis will give you ze smoothest shave you 
will ever 'ave," Monsieur Saenz assured him, "but you must tell it clearly what you 
want...ozzerwise you might find you 'ave a leetle less hair zan you would like..."), 
chocolates from the Saenzs, and an enormous box of the latest Lopezs' Wizard 
Wheezes merchandise from Pablo and Luis. 

 

Roberto, Diego, and Carolina did not linger at the table, as the arrival of Madame 
Saenz, Camila, and Gabrielle made the kitchen uncomfortably crowded. 

"I'll pack these for you," Carolina said brightly, taking Roberto's presents out of his 
arms as the three of them headed back upstairs. "I'm nearly done, I'm just waiting for the 
rest of your underpants to come out of the wash, Diego--" 

Diego's splutter was interrupted by the opening of a door on the first-floor landing. 

"Roberto, will you come in here a moment?" 


It was Martina. Diego came to an abrupt halt, but Carolina took him by the elbow 
and tugged him on up the stairs. Feeling nervous, Roberto followed Martina into her room. 

He had never been inside it before. It was small, but bright. There was a large 
poster of the Wizarding band the Weird Sisters on one wall, and a picture of Gwenog 
Jones, Captain of the all-witch Quidditch team the Holyhead Harpies, on the other. A 
desk stood facing the open window, which looked out over the orchard where he and 
Martina had once played a two-a-side Quidditch with Diego and Carolina, and which now 
housed a large, pearly white marquee. The golden flag on top was level with Martina's 
window. 

Martina looked up into Roberto's face, took a deep breath, and said, "Happy 
seventeenth." 

"Yeah...thanks." 

She was looking at him steadily; he however, found it difficult to look back at her; 
it was like gazing into a brilliant light. 

"Nice view," he said feebly, pointing toward with window. 

She ignored this. He could not blame her. 

"I couldn't think what to get you," she said. 

 

"You didn't have to get me anything." 

She disregarded this too. 

"I didn't know what would be useful. Nothing too big, because you wouldn't be 
able to take it with you." 

He chanced a glance at her. She was not tearful; that was one of the many 
wonderful things about Martina, she was rarely weepy. He had sometimes thought that 
having six brothers must have toughened her up. 

She took a step closer to him. 

"So then I thought, I'd like you to have something to remember me by, you know, 
if you meet some veela when you're off doing whatever you're doing." 

"I think dating opportunities are going to be pretty thin on the ground, to be 
honest." 

"There's the silver lining I've been looking for," she whispered, and then she was 
kissing him as she had never kissed him before, and Roberto was kissing her back, and it 
was blissful oblivion better than firewhisky; she was the only real thing in the world, 
Martina, the feel of her, one hand at her back and one in her long, sweet-smelling hair-- 

The door banged open behind them and they jumped apart. 

"Oh," said Diego pointedly. "Sorry." 

"Diego!" Carolina was just behind him, slight out of breath. There was a strained 
silence, then Martina had said in a flat little voice, 

"Well, happy birthday anyway, Roberto." 

Diego's ears were scarlet; Carolina looked nervous. Roberto wanted to slam the door 
in their faces, but it felt as though a cold draft had entered the room when the door 
opened, and his shining moment had popped like a soap bubble. All the reasons for 
ending his relationship with Martina, for staying well away from her, seemed to have slunk 
inside the room with Diego, and all happy forgetfulness was gone. 


He looked at Martina, wanting to say something, though he hardly knew what, but 
she had turned her back on him. He thought that she might have succumbed, for once, to 
tears. He could not do anything to comfort her in front of Diego. 

"I'll see you later," he said, and followed the other two out of the bedroom. 

Diego marched downstairs, though the still-crowded kitchen and into the yard, and 
Roberto kept pace with him all the way, Carolina trotting along behind them looking 
scared. 

Once he reached the seclusion of the freshly mown lawn, Diego rounded on Roberto. 

"You ditched her. What are you doing now, messing her around?" 

"I'm not messing her around," said Roberto, as Carolina caught up with them. 

"Diego--" 

But Diego held up a hand to silence her. 

"She was really cut up when you ended it--" 

"So was I. You know why I stopped it, and it wasn't because I wanted to." 

"Yeah, but you go snogging her now and she's just going to get her hopes up 
again--" 

"She's not an idiot, she knows it can't happen, she's not expecting us to--to end up 
married, or--" 

As he said it, a vivid picture formed in Roberto's mind of Martina in a white dress, 
marrying a tall, faceless, and unpleasant stranger. 

 

In one spiraling moment it seemed to hit him: Her future was free and 
unencumbered, whereas his...he could see nothing but Salvador ahead. 

"If you keep groping her every chance you get--" 

"It won't happen again," said Roberto harshly. The day was cloudless, but he felt as 
though the sun had gone in. "Okay?" 

Diego looked half resentful, half sheepish; he rocked backward and forward on his 
feet for a moment, then said, "Right then, well, that's...yeah." 

Martina did not seek another one-to-one meeting with Roberto for the rest of the day, 
nor by any look or gesture did she show that they had shared more than polite 
conversation in her room. Nevertheless, Charlie's arrival came as a relief to Roberto. It 
provided a distraction, watching Mrs. Lopez force Charlie into a chair, raise her wand 
threateningly, and announce that he was about to get a proper haircut. 

As Roberto's birthday dinner would have stretched the Burrow's kitchen to breaking 
point even before the arrival of Charlie, Cardozo, Perez, and Villalba, several tables were 
placed end to end in the garden. Pablo and Luis bewitched a number of purple lanterns 
all emblazoned with a large number 17, to hang in midair over the guests. Thanks to Mrs. 
Lopez's ministrations, Luis's wound was neat and clean, but Roberto was not yet used 
to the dark hole in the side of his head, despite the twins' many jokes about it. 

Carolina made purple and gold streamers erupt from the end of her wand and 
drape themselves artistically over the trees and bushes. 

"Nice," said Diego, as with one final flourish of her wand, Carolina 

 

turned the leaves on the crabapple tree to gold. "You've really got an eye for that sort of 
thing." 


"Thank you, Diego!" said Carolina, looking both pleased and a little confused. 
Roberto turned away, smiling to himself. He had a funny notion that he would find a 
chapter on compliments when he found time to peruse his copy of Twelve Fail-Safe 
Ways to Charm Witches; he caught Martina's eye and grinned at her before remembering 
his promise to Diego and hurriedly striking up a conversation with Monsieur Saenz. 

"Out of the way, out of the way!" sang Mrs. Lopez, coming through the gate 
with what appeared to be a giant, beach-ball-sized Snitch floating in front of her. Seconds 
later Roberto realized that it was his birthday cake, which Mrs. Lopez was suspending 
with her wand, rather than risk carrying it over the uneven ground. When the cake had 
finally landed in the middle of the table, Roberto said, 

"That looks amazing, Mrs. Lopez." 

"Oh, it's nothing, dear," she said fondly. Over her shoulder, Diego gave Roberto the 
thumbs-up and mouthed, Good one. 

By seven o'clock all the guests had arrived, led into the house by Pablo and Luis, 
who had waited for them at the end of the lane. Villalba had honored the occasion by 
wearing his best, and horrible, hairy brown suit. Although Cardozo smiled as he shook 
Roberto's hand, Roberto thought he looked rather unhappy. It was all very odd; Perez, beside 
him, looked simply radiant. 

"Happy birthday, Roberto," she said, hugging him tightly. 

"Seventeen, eh!" said Villalba as he accepted a bucket-sized glass of wine from 
Pablo. "Six years ter the day since we met, Roberto, d'yeh remember it?" 

 

"Vaguely," said Roberto, grinning up at him. "Didn't you smash down the front door, 
give Leonardo a pig's tail, and tell me I was a wizard?" 

"I forge' the details," Villalba chortled. "All righ', Diego, Carolina?" 

"We're fine," said Carolina. "How are you?" 

"Ar, not bad. Bin busy, we got some newborn unicorns. I'll show yeh when yeh 
get back--" Roberto avoided Diego's and Carolina's gazes as Villalba rummaged in his pocket. 
"Here. Roberto -- couldn't think what ter get teh, but then I remembered this." He pulled out 
a small, slightly furry drawstring pouch with a long string, evidently intended to be worn 
around the neck. "Mokeskin. Hide anythin' in there an' no one but the owner can get it out. 
They're rare, them." 

"Villalba, thanks!" 

"'S'nothin'," said Villalba with a wave of a dustbin-lid-sized hand. "An' there's 
Charlie! Always liked him -- hey! Charlie!" 

Charlie approached, running his hand slightly ruefully over his new, brutally short 
haircut. He was shorter than Diego, thickset, with a number of burns and scratches up his 
muscley arms. 

"Hi, Villalba, how's it going?" 

"Bin meanin' ter write fer ages. How's Norbert doin'?" 

"Norbert?" Charlie laughed. "The Norwegian Ridgeback? We call her Norberta 
now." 

"Wha -- Norbert's a girl?" 

"Oh yeah," said Charlie. 

"How can you tell?" asked Carolina. 


"They're a lot more vicious," said Charlie. He looked over his shoulder and 
dropped his voice. "Wish Dad would hurry up and get here. Mum's getting edgy." 

 

They all looked over at Mrs. Lopez. She was trying to talk to Madame Saenz 
while glancing repeatedly at the gate. 

"I think we'd better start without Raul," she called to the garden at large after a 
moment or two. "He must have been held up at -- oh!" 

They all saw it at the same time: a streak of light that came flying across the yard 
and onto the table, where it resolved itself into a bright silver weasel, which stood on its 
hind legs and spoke with Mr. Lopez's voice. 

"Minister of Magic coming with me." 

The Patronus dissolved into thin air, leaving Camila's family peering in 
astonishment at the place where it had vanished. 

"We shouldn't be here," said Cardozo at once. "Roberto -- I'm sorry -- I'll explain some 
other time--" 

He seized Perez’s wrist and pulled her away; they reached the fence, climbed 
over it, and vanished from sight. Mrs. Lopez looked bewildered. 

"The Minister -- but why--? I don't understand--" 

But there was no time to discuss the matter; a second later, Mr. Lopez had 
appeared out of thin air at the gate, accompanied by Rufus Scrimgeour, instantly 
recognizable by his mane of grizzled hair. 

The two newcomers marched across the yard toward the garden and the lantern-lit 
table, where everybody sat in silence, watching them draw closer. As Scrimgeour came 
within range of the lantern light. Roberto saw that he looked much older than the last time 
that had met, scraggy and grim. 

"Sorry to intrude," said Scrimgeour, as he limped to a halt before the table. 
"Especially as I can see that I am gate-crashing a party." 

 

His eyes lingered for a moment on the giant Snitch cake. 

"Many happy returns." 

"Thanks," said Roberto. 

"I require a private word with you," Scrimgeour went on. "Also with Mr. Diegoald 
Lopez and Miss Carolina Fernandez." 

"Us?" said Diego, sounding surprised. "Why us?" 

"I shall tell you that when we are somewhere more private," said Scrimgeour. "Is 
there such a place?' he demanded of Mr. Lopez. 

"Yes, of course," said Mr. Lopez, who looked nervous. "The, er, sitting room, 
why don't you use that?" 

"You can lead the way," Scrimgeour said to Diego. "There will be no need for you 
to accompany us, Raul." 

Roberto saw Mr. Lopez exchange a worried look with Mrs. Lopez as he, Diego, 
and Carolina stood up. As they led the way back to the house in silence, Roberto knew 
that the other two were thinking the same as he was; Scrimgeour must, somehow, had 
learned that the three of them were planning to drop out of Hogwarts. 

Scrimgeour did not speak as they all passed through the messed kitchen and into 
the Burrow's sitting room. Although the garden had been full of soft golden evening light, 


it was already dark in here; Roberto flicked his wand at the oil lamps as he entered and they 
illuminated the shabby but cozy room. Scrimgeour sat himself in the sagging armchair 
that Mr. Lopez normally occupied, leaving Roberto, Diego, and Carolina to squeeze side 
by side onto the sofa. Once they had done so, Scrimgeour spoke. 

"I have some questions for the three of you, and I think it will be best if we do it 
individually. If you two" -- he pointed at Roberto and Carolina -- "can wait upstairs, I will 
start with Diegoald." 

 

"We're not going anywhere," said Roberto, while Carolina nodded vigorously. 
"You can speak to us together, or not at all." 

Scrimgeour gave Roberto a cold, appraising look. Roberto had the impression that the 
Minister was wondering whether it was worthwhile opening hostilities this early. 

"Very well then, together," he said, shrugging. He cleared his throat. "I am here, 
as I'm sure you know, because of Alfonso Dominguez's will." 

Roberto, Diego, and Carolina looked at one another. 

"A surprise, apparently! You were not aware then that Dominguez had left you 
anything?" 

"A-all of us?" said Diego, "Me and Carolina too?" 

"Yes, all of --" 

But Roberto interrupted. 

"Dominguez died over a month ago. Why has it taken this long to give us what 
he left us?" 

"Isn't it obvious?" said Carolina, before Scrimgeour could answer. "They wanted 
to examine whatever he's left us. You had no right to do that!" she said, and her voice 
trembled slightly. 

"I had every right," said Scrimgeour dismissively. "The Decree for Justifiable 
Confiscation gives the Ministry the power the confiscate the contents of a will--" 

"That law was created to stop wizards passing on Dark artifacts," said Carolina, 
"and the Ministry is supposed to have powerful evidence that the deceased's possessions 
are illegal before seizing them! Are you telling me that you thought Dominguez was 
trying to pass us something cursed?" 

"Are you planning to follow a career in Magical Law, Miss Fernandez?" asked 
Scrimgeour. 

"No, I'm not," retorted Carolina. "I'm hoping to do some good in the world!" 

Diego laughed. Scrimgeour's eyes flickered toward him and away again as Roberto 
spoke. 

"So why have you decided to let us have our things now? Can't think of a pretext 
to keep them?" 

"No, it'll be because thirty-one days are up," said Carolina at once. "They can't 
keep the objects longer than that unless they can prove they're dangerous. Right?" 

"Would you say you were close to Dominguez, Diegoald?" asked Scrimgeour, 
ignoring Carolina. Diego looked startled. 

"Me? Not -- not really... It was always Roberto who..." 

Diego looked around at Roberto and Carolina, to see Carolina giving him a stop-
talking-now! sort of look, but the damage was done; Scrimgeour looked as though he had 


heard exactly what he had expected, and wanted, to hear. He swooped like a bird of prey 
upon Diego's answer. 

"If you were not very close to Dominguez, how do you account for the fact that 
he remembered you in his will? He made exceptionally few personal bequests. The vast 
majority of his possessions -- his private library, his magical instruments, and other 
personal effects -- were left to Hogwarts. Why do you think you were singled out?" 

"I...dunno," said Diego. "I...when I say we weren't close...I mean, I think he liked 
me..." 

"You're being modest, Diego," said Carolina. "Dominguez was very fond of you." 

This was stretching the truth to breaking point; as far as Roberto knew, Diego and 
Dominguez had never been alone together, and direct contact between them had been 
negligible. However, Scrimgeour did not seem to be listening. He put his hand inside his 
cloak and drew out a drawstring pouch much larger than the one Villalba had given Roberto. 
From it, he removed a scroll of parchment which he unrolled and read aloud. 

"'The Last Will and Testament of Alfonso Percival Wulfric Brian Dominguez'... 
Yes, here we are... 'To Diegoald Bilius Lopez, I leave my Deluminator, in the hope that 
he will remember me when he uses it.'" 

Scrimgeour took from the bag an object that Roberto had seen before: It looked 
something like a silver cigarette lighter, but it had, he knew, the power to suck all light 
from a place, and restore it, with a simple click. Scrimgeour leaned forward and passed 
the Deluminator to Diego, who took it and turned it over in the fingers looking stunned. 

"That is a valuable object," said Scrimgeour, watching Diego. "It may even be 
unique. Certainly it is of Dominguez's own design. Why would he have left you and item 
so rare?" 

Diego shook his head, looking bewildered. 

"Dominguez must have taught thousands of students," Scrimgeour persevered. 
"Yet the only ones he remembered in his will are you three. Why is that? To what use did 
he think you would put to the Deluminator, Mr. Lopez?" 

"Put out lights, I s'pose," mumbled Diego. "What else could I do with it?" 

Evidently Scrimgeour had no suggestions. After squinting at Diego for a moment or 
tow, he turned back to Dominguez's will. 

"'To Miss Carolina Jean Fernandez, I leave my copy of The Tales of Beedle the 
Bard, in the hope that she will find it entertaining and instructive.'" 

Scrimgeour now pulled out of the bag a small book that looked as ancient as the 
copy of Secrets of the Darkest Art upstairs. Its binding was stained and peeling in places. 
Carolina took it from Scrimgeour without a word. She held the book in her lap and 
gazed at it. Roberto saw that the title was in runes; he had never learned to read them. As he 
looked, a tear splashed onto the embossed symbols. 

"Why do you think Dominguez left you that book, Miss Fernandez?" asked 
Scrimgeour. 

"He... he knew I liked books," said Carolina in a thick voice, mopping her eyes 
with her sleeve. 

"But why that particular book?" 

"I don't know. He must have thought I'd enjoy it." 

"Did you ever discuss codes, or any means of passing secret messages, with 
Dominguez?" 


"No, I didn't," said Carolina, still wiping her eyes on her sleeve. "And if the 
Ministry hasn't found any hidden codes in this book in thirty-one days, I doubt that I 
will." 

She suppressed a sob. They were wedged together so tightly that Diego had 
difficulty extracting his arm to put it around Carolina's shoulders. Scrimgeour turned 
back to the will. 

"'To Roberto Ricardo Gonzales,'" he read, and Roberto's insides contracted with a sudden 
excitement, "'I leave the Snitch he caught in his first Quidditch match at Hogwarts, as a 
reminder of the rewards of perseverance and skill.'" 

As Scrimgeour pulled out the tiny, walnut-sized golden ball, its silver wings 
fluttered rather feebly, and Roberto could not help feeling a definite sense of anticlimax. 

"Why did Dominguez leave you this Snitch?" asked Scrimgeour. 

"No idea," said Roberto. "For the reasons you just read out, I suppose... to remind 
me what you can get if you... persevere and whatever it was." 

"You think this a mere symbolic keepsake, then?" 

"I suppose so," said Roberto. "What else could it be?" 

"I'm asking the questions," said Scrimgeour, shifting his chair a little closer to the 
sofa. Dusk was really falling outside now; the marquee beyond the windows towered 
ghostly white over the hedge. 

"I notice that your birthday cake is in the shape of a Snitch," Scrimgeour said to 
Roberto. "Why is that?" 

Carolina laughed derisively. 

"Oh, it can't be a reference to the fact Roberto's a great Seeker, that's way too 
obvious," she said. "There must be a secret message from Dominguez hidden in the 
icing!" 

"I don't think there's anything hidden in the icing," said Scrimgeour, "but a Snitch 
would be a very good hiding place for a small object. You know why, I'm sure?" 

Roberto shrugged, Carolina, however, answered: Roberto thought that answering 
questions correctly was such a deeply ingrained habit she could not suppress the urge. 

"Because Snitches have flesh memories," she said. 

"What?" said Roberto and Diego together; both considered Carolina's Quidditch 
knowledge negligible. 

"Correct," said Scrimgeour. "A Snitch is not touched by bare skin before it is 
released, not even by the maker, who wears gloves. It carries an enchantment by which it 
can identify the first human to lay hands upon it, in case of a disputed capture. This 
Snitch" -- he held up the tiny golden ball -- "will remember your touch, Gonzales. 

It occurs to me that Dominguez, who had prodigious magical skill, whatever his 
other faults, might have enchanted this Snitch so that it will open only for you." 

Roberto's heart was beating rather fast. He was sure that Scrimgeour was right. How 
could he avoid taking the Snitch with his bare hand in front of the Minister? 

"You don't say anything," said Scrimgeour. "Perhaps you already know what the 
Snitch contains?" 

"No," said Roberto, still wondering how he could appear to touch the Snitch without 
really doing so. If only he knew Legilimency, really knew it, and could read Carolina's 
mind; he could practically hear her brain whizzing beside him. 

"Take it," said Scrimgeour quietly. 


Roberto met the Minister's yellow eyes and knew he had no option but to obey. He 
held out his hand, and Scrimgeour leaned forward again and place the Snitch, slowly and 
deliberately, into Roberto's palm. 

Nothing happened. As Roberto's fingers closed around the Snitch, its tired wings 
fluttered and were still. Scrimgeour, Diego, and Carolina continued to gaze avidly at the 
now partially concealed ball, as if still hoping it might transform in some way. 

"That was dramatic," said Roberto coolly. Both Diego and Carolina laughed. 

"That's all, then, is it?" asked Carolina, making to raise herself off the sofa. 

"Not quite," said Scrimgeour, who looked bad tempered now. "Dominguez left 
you a second bequest, Gonzales." 

"What is it?" asked Roberto, excitement rekindling. 

Scrimgeour did not bother to read from the will this time. 

"The sword of Godric Gryffindor," he said. Carolina and Diego both stiffened. 
Roberto looked around for a sign of the ruby-encrusted hilt, but Scrimgeour did not pull the 
sword from the leather pouch, which in any case looked much too small to contain it. 

"So where is it?" Roberto asked suspiciously. 

"Unfortunately," said Scrimgeour, "that sword was not Dominguez's to give 
away. The sword of Godric Gryffindor is an important historical artifact, and as such, 
belongs--" 

"It belongs to Roberto!" said Carolina hotly. "It chose him, he was the one who 
found it, it came to him out of the Sorting Hat--" 

"According to reliable historical sources, the sword may present itself to any 
worthy Gryffindor," said Scrimgeour. "That does not make it the exclusive property of 
Mr. Gonzales, whatever Dominguez may have decided." Scrimgeour scratched his badly 
shaven cheek, scrutinizing Roberto. "Why do you think--?" 

"--Dominguez wanted to give me the sword?" said Roberto, struggling to keep his 
temper. "Maybe he thought it would look nice on my wall." 

"This is not a joke, Gonzales!" growled Scrimgeour. "Was it because Dominguez 
believed that only the sword of Godric Gryffindor could defeat the Heir of Slytherin? Did 
he wish to give you that sword, Gonzales, because he believed, as do many, that you are the 
one destined to destroy He-Who-Must-Not-Be-Named?" 

"Interesting theory," said Roberto. "Has anyone ever tried sticking a sword in 
Salvador? Maybe the Ministry should put some people onto that, instead of wasting 
their time stripping down Deluminators or covering up breakouts from Azkaban. So this 
is what you've been doing, Minister, shut up in your office, trying to break open a Snitch? 
People are dying – I was nearly one of them – Salvador chased me across three 
countries, he killed Mad-Eye Acosta, but there's no word about any of that from the 
Ministry, has there? And you still expect us to cooperate with you!" 

"You go too far!" shouted Scrimgeour, standing up: Roberto jumped to his feet too. 
Scrimgeour limped toward Roberto and jabbed him hard in the chest with the point of his 
wand; It singed a hole in Roberto's T-shirt like a lit cigarette. 

"Oi!" said Diego, jumping up and raising his own wand, but Roberto said, 

"No! D'you want to give him an excuse to arrest us?" 

"Remembered you're not at school, have you?" said Scrimgeour breathing hard 
into Roberto's face. "Remembered that I am not Dominguez, who forgave your insolence 


and insubordination? You may wear that scar like a crown, Gonzales, but it is not up to a 
seventeen-year-old boy to tell me how to do my job! It's time you learned some respect!" 

"It's time you earned it." said Roberto. 

The floor trembled; there was a sound of running footsteps, then the door to the 
sitting room burst open and Mr. and Mrs. Lopez ran in. 

"We --- we thought we heard --" began Mr. Lopez, looking thoroughly alarmed 
at the sight of Roberto and the Minister virtually nose to nose. 

"—raised voices," panted Mrs. Lopez. 

Scrimgeour took a couple of steps back from Roberto, glancing at the hole he had 
made in Roberto's T-shirt. He seemed to regret his loss of temper. 

"It – it was nothing," he growled. "I … regret your attitude," he said, looking 
Roberto full in the face once more. "You seem to think that the Ministry does not desire 
what you – what Dominguez – desired. We ought to work together." 

"I don't like your methods, Minister," said Roberto. "Remember?" 

For the second time, he raised his right fist and displayed to Scrimgeour the scar 
that still showed white on the back of it, spelling I must not tell lies . Scrimgeour's 
expression hardened. He turned away without another word and limped from the room. 
Mrs. Lopez hurried after him; Roberto heard her stop at the back door. After a minute or 
so she called, "He's gone!" 

What did he want?" Mr. Lopez asked, looking around at Roberto, Diego, and 
Carolina as Mrs. Lopez came hurrying back to them. 

"To give us what Dominguez left us," said Roberto. "They've only just released the 
content of his will." 

Outside in the garden, over the dinner tables, the three objects Scrimgeour had 
given them were passed from hand to hand. Everyone exclaimed over the Deluminator 
and The Tales of Beedle the Bard and lamented the fact that Scrimgeour had refused to 
pass on the sword, but none of them could offer any suggestion as to why Dominguez 
would have left Roberto an old Snitch. As Mr. Lopez examined the Deluminator for the 
third of fourth time, Mrs. Lopez said tentatively, "Roberto, dear, everyone's awfully 
hungry we didn't like to start without you… Shall I serve dinner now?" 

They all ate rather hurriedly and then after a hasty chorus of "Happy Birthday" 
and much gulping of cake, the party broke up. Villalba, who was invited to the wedding 
the following day, but was far too bulky to sleep in the overstretched Burrow, left to set 
up a tent for himself in a neighboring field. 

"Meet us upstairs," Roberto whispered to Carolina, while they helped Mrs. 
Lopez restore the garden to its normal state. "After everyone's gone to bed." 

Up in the attic room, Diego examined his Deluminator, and Roberto filled Villalba's 
mokeskin purse, not with gold, but with those items he most prized, apparently worthless 
though some of them were the Marauder's Map, the shard of Gustavo's enchanted mirror, 
and R.A.B.'s locket. He pulled the string tight and slipped the purse around his neck, then 
sat holding the old Snitch and watching its wings flutter feebly. At last, Carolina tapped 
on the door and tiptoed inside. 

"Muffiato," she whispered, waving her wand in the direction of the stairs. 

"Thought you didn't approve of that spell?" said Diego. 

"Times change," said Carolina. "Now, show us that Deluminator." 


Diego obliged at once. Holding I up in front of him, he clicked it. The solitary lamp 
they had lit went out at once. 

"The thing is," whispered Carolina through the dark, "we could have achieved 
that with Peruvian Instant Darkness Powder." 

There was a small click, and the ball of light from the lamp flew back to the 
ceiling and illuminated them all once more. 

"Still, it's cool," said Diego, a little defensively. "And from what they said, 
Dominguez invented it himself!" 

"I know but, surely he wouldn't have singled you out in his will just to help us 
turn out the lights!" 

"D'you think he knew the Ministry would confiscate his will and examine 
everything he'd left us?" asked Roberto. 

"Definitely," said Carolina. "He couldn't tell us in the will why he was leaving 
us these things, but that will doesn't explain…" 

"… why he couldn't have given us a hint when he was alive?" asked Diego. 

"Well, exactly," said Carolina, now flicking through The Tales of Beedle the 
Bard. "If these things are important enough to pass on right under the nose of the 
Ministry, you'd think he'd have left us know why… unless he thought it was obvious?" 

"Thought wrong, then, didn't he?" said Diego. "I always said he was mental. 
Brilliant and everything, but cracked. Leaving Roberto an old Snitch – what the hell was 
that about?" 

"I've no idea," said Carolina. "When Scrimgeour made you take it, Roberto, I was 
so sure that something was going to happen!" 

"Yeah, well," said Roberto, his pulse quickened as he raised the Snitch in his fingers. 
"I wasn't going to try too hard in front of Scrimgeour was I?" 

"What do you mean?" asked Carolina. 

"The Snitch I caught in my first ever Quidditch match?" said Roberto. "Don't you 
remember?" 

Carolina looked simply bemused. Diego, however, gasped, pointing frantically 
from Roberto to the Snitch and back again until he found his voice. 

"That was the one you nearly swallowed!" 

"Exactly," said Roberto, and with his heart beating fast, he pressed his mouth to the 
Snitch. 

It did not open. Frustration and bitter disappointment welled up inside him: He 
lowered the golden sphere, but then Carolina cried out. 

"Writing! There's writing on it, quick, look!" 
He nearly dropped the Snitch in surprise and excitement. Carolina was quite right. 
Engraved upon the smooth golden surface, where seconds before there had been nothing, 
were five words written in the thin, slanted handwriting that Roberto recognized as 
Dominguez's 

I open at the close. 

He had barely read them when the words vanished again. 

"I open at the close…." What's that supposed to mean?" 

Carolina and Diego shook their heads, looking blank. 

"I open at the close… at the close… I open at the close…" 


But no matter how often they repeated the words, with many different inflections, 
they were unable to wring any more meaning from them. 

"And the sword," said Diego finally, when they had at last abandoned their attempts 
to divine meaning in the Snitch's inscription. 

"Why did he want Roberto to have the sword?" 

"And why couldn't he just have told me?" Roberto said quietly. "I was there, it was 
right there on the wall of his office during all our talks last year! If he wanted me to have 
it, why didn't he just give it to me then?" 

He felt as thought he were sitting in an examination with a question he ought to 
have been able to answer in front of him, his brain slow and unresponsive. Was there 
something he had missed in the long talks with Dominguez last year? Ought he to know 
what it all meant? Had Dominguez expected him to understand? 

"And as for this book." Said Carolina, "The Tales of Beedle the Bard … I've 
never even heard of them!" 

"You've never heard of The Tales of Beedle the Bard?" said Diego incredulously. 
"You're kidding, right?" 

"No, I'm not," said Carolina in surprise. "Do you know them then?" 

"Well, of course I do!" 

Roberto looked up, diverted. The circumstance of Diego having read a book that 
Carolina had not was unprecedented. Diego, however, looked bemused by their surprise. 

"Oh come on! All the old kids' stories are supposed to be Beedle's aren't they? 
'The Fountain of Fair Fortune' … 'The Wizard and the Hopping Pot'… 'Babbitty Rabbitty 
and her Cackling Stump'…" 

"Excuse me?" said Carolina giggling. "What was the last one?" 

"Come off it!" said Diego, looking in disbelief from Roberto to Carolina. "You 
must've heard of Babbitty Rabbitty –" 

"Diego, you know full well Roberto and I were brought up by Muggles!" said 
Carolina. "We didn't hear stories like that when we were little, we heard 'Snow White 
and the Seven Dwarves' and 'Cinderella' –" 

"What's that, an illness?" asked Diego. 

"So these are children's stories?" asked Carolina, bending against over the runes. 

"Yeah." Said Diego uncertainly. "I mean, just what you hear, you know, that all 
these old stories came from Beedle. I dunno what they're like in the original versions." 

"But I wonder why Dominguez thought I should read them?" 

Something cracked downstairs. 

"Probably just Charlie, now Mum's asleep, sneaking off to regrow his hair," said 
Diego nervously. 

"All the same, we should get to bed," whispered Carolina. "It wouldn't do to 
oversleep tomorrow." 

"No," agreed Diego. "A brutal triple murder by the bridegroom's mother might put a 
bit of damper on the wedding. I'll get the light." 

And he clicked the Deluminator once more as Carolina left the room. 


Chapter Eight 

The Wedding 

Three o’clock on the following afternoon found Roberto, Diego, Pablo and Luis 
standing outside the great white marquee in the orchard, awaiting the arrival of the 
wedding guests. Roberto had taken a large dose of Polyjuice Potion and was now the 
double of a redheaded Muggle boy from the local village, Ottery St. Catchpole, from 
whom Pablo had stolen hairs using a Summoning Charm. The plan was to introduce 
Roberto as “Cousin Barny” and trust to the great number of Lopez relatives to 
camouflage him. 

 All four of them were clutching seating plans, so that they could help show people 
to the right seats. A host of white-robed waiters had arrived an hour earlier, along with a 
golden jacketed band, and all of these wizards were currently sitting a short distance 
away under a tree. Roberto could see a blue haze of pipe smoke issuing from the spot. 
Behind Roberto, the entrance to the marquee revealed rows and rows of fragile golden 
chairs set on either side of a long purple carpet. The supporting poles were entwined with 
white and gold flowers. Pablo and Luis had fastened an enormous bunch of golden 
balloons over the exact point where Bill and Camila would shortly become husband and 
wife. Outside, butterflies and bees were hovering lazily over the grass and hedgerow. 
Roberto was rather uncomfortable. The Muggle boy whose appearance he was affecting 
was slightly fatter than him and his dress robes felt hot and tight in the full glare of a 
summer’s day. 

“When I get married,” said Pablo, tugging at the collar of his own robes, “I won’t 
be bothering with any of this nonsense. You can all wear what you like, and I’ll put a full 
Body Bird Curse on Mum until it’s all over.” 

 “She wasn’t too bad this morning, considering,” said Luis. “Cried a bit about 
Miguel not being here, but who wants him. Oh blimey, brace yourselves, here they come, 
look.” 

 Brightly colored figures were appearing, one by one out of nowhere at the distant 
boundary of the yard. Within minutes a procession had formed, which began to snake its 
way up through the garden toward the marquee. Exotic flowers and bewitched birds 
fluttered on the witches’ hats, while precious gems glittered from many of the wizards’ 
cravats; a hum of excited chatter grew louder and louder, drowning the sound of the bees 
as the crowd approached the tent. 

 “Excellent, I think I see a few veela cousins,” said Luis, craning his neck for a 
better look. “They’ll need help understanding our English customs, I’ll look after 
them….” 

 “Not so fast, Your Holeyness,” said Pablo, and darting past the gaggle of middle-
aged witches heading for the procession, he said, “Here – permetiez moi to assister 
vous,” to a pair of pretty French girls, who giggled and allowed him to escort them inside. 
Luis was left to deal with the middle-aged witches and Diego took charge of Mr. 
Lopez’s old Ministry-colleague Perkins, while a rather deaf old couple fell to Roberto’s 
lot. 

 “Wotcher,” said a familiar voice as he came out of the marquee again and found 
Perez and Cardozo at the front of the queue. She had turned blonde for the occasion. 
“Raul told us you were the one with the curly hair. Sorry about last night,” she added 


in a whisper as Roberto led them up the aisle. “The Ministry’s being very anti-werewolf at 
the museum and we thought our presence might not do you any favors.” 

 “It’s fine, I understand,” said Roberto, speaking more to Cardozo than Perez. Cardozo 
gave him a swift smile, but as they turned away Roberto saw Cardozo’s face fall again into 
lines of misery. He did not understand it, but there was no time to dwell on the matter. 
Villalba was causing a certain amount of disruption. Having misunderstood Pablo’s 
directions as he had sat himself, not upon the magically enlarged and reinforced seat set 
aside for him in the back row, but on five sets that now resembled a large pile of golden 
matchsticks. 

 While Mr. Lopez repaired the damage and Villalba shouted apologies to 
anybody who would listen, Roberto hurried back to the entrance to find Diego face-to-face 
with a most eccentric-looking wizard. Slightly cross-eyed, with shoulder-length white 
hair the texture of candyfloss, he wore a cap whose tassel dangled in front of his nose and 
robes of an eye-watering shade of egg-yolk yellow. An odd symbol, rather like a 
triangular eye, glistened from a golden chain around his neck. 

 “Xenophilius Ortiz,” he said, extending a hand to Roberto, “my daughter and I 
live just over the hill, so kind of the good Lopezs to invite us. But I think you know 
my Gabriela?” he added to Diego. 

 “Yes,” said Diego. “Isn’t she with you?” 

 “She lingered in that charming little garden to say hello to the gnomes, such a 
glorious infestation! How few wizards realize just how much we can learn from the wise 
little gnomes – or, to give them their correct name, the Gernumbli gardensi.” 

 “Ours do know a lot of excellent swear words,” said Diego, “but I think Pablo and 
Luis taught them those.” 

 He led a party of warlocks into the marquee as Gabriela rushed up. 

 “Hello, Roberto!” she said. 

 “Er – my name’s Barry,” said Roberto, flummoxed. 

 “Oh, have you changed that too?” she asked brightly. 

 “How did you know -?” 

 “Oh, just your expression,” she said. 

 Like her father, Gabriela was wearing bright yellow robes, which she had 
accessorized with a large sunflower in her hair. Once you get over the brightness of it all, 
the general effect was quite pleasant. At least there were no radishes dangling from her 
ears. 

 Xenophilius, who was deep in conversation with an acquaintance, had missed the 
exchange between Gabriela and Roberto. Biding the wizard farewell, he turned to his daughter, 
who held up her finger and said, “Daddy, look – one of the gnomes actually bit me.” 

 “How wonderful! Gnome saliva is enormously beneficial.” Said Mr. Ortiz, 
seizing Gabriela’s outstretched fingers and examining the bleeding puncture marks. “Gabriela, 
my love, if you should feel any burgeoning talent today – perhaps an unexpected urge to 
sing opera or to declaims in Mermish – do not repress it! You may have been gifted by 
the Gernumblies!” 

 Diego, passing them in the opposite direction let out a loud snort. 

 “Diego can laugh,” said Gabriela serenely as Roberto led her and Xenophilius toward 
their seats, “but my father has done a lot of research on Gernumbli magic.” 


 “Really?” said Roberto, who had long since decided not to challenge Gabriela or her 
father’s peculiar views. “Are you sure you don’t want to put anything on that bite, 
though?” 

 “Oh, it’s fine,” said Gabriela, sucking her finger in a dreamy fashion and looking 
Roberto up and down. “You look smart. I told Daddy most people would probably wear 
dress robes, but he believes you ought to wear sun colors to a wedding, for luck, you 
know.” 

 As she drifted off after her father, Diego reappeared with an elderly witch clutching 
his arm. Her beaky nose, red-rimmed eyes, and leathery pink hat gave her the look of a 
bad-tempered flamingo. 

 “…and your hair’s much too long, Diegoald, for a moment I thought you were 
Ginevra. Merlin’s beard, what is Xenophilius Ortiz wearing? He looks like an 
omelet. And who are you?” she barked at Roberto. 

 “Oh yeah, Auntie Muriel, this is our cousin Barny.” 

 “Another Lopez? You breed like gnomes. Isn’t Roberto Gonzales here? I was 
hoping to meet him. I thought he was a friend of yours, Diegoald, or have you merely been 
boasting?” 

 “No – he couldn’t come –“ 

 “Hmm. Made an excuse, did he? Not as gormless as he looks in press 
photographs, then. I’ve just been instructing the bride on how best to wear my tiara,” she 
shouted at Roberto. “Goblin-made, you know, and been in my family for centuries. She’s a 
good-looking girl, but still – French. Well, well, find me a good seat, Diegoald, I am a 
hundred and seven and I ought not to be on my feet too long.” 

 Diego gave Roberto a meaningful look as he passed and did not reappear for some 
time. When next they met at the entrance, Roberto had shown a dozen more people to their 
places. The Marquee was nearly full now and for the first time there was no queue 
outside. 

 “Nightmare, Muriel is,” said Diego, mopping his forehead on his sleeve. “She used 
to come for Christmas every year, then, thank God, she took offense because Pablo and 
Luis set off a Dungbomb under her chair at diner. Dad always says she’ll have written 
them out of her will – like they care, they’re going to end up richer than anyone in the 
family, rate they’re going… Wow,” he added, blinking rather rapidly as Carolina came 
hurrying toward them. “You look great!” 

 “Always the tone of surprise,” said Carolina, though she smiled. She was 
wearing a floaty, lilac-colored dress with matching high heels; her hair was sleek and 
shiny. “Your Great-Aunt Muriel doesn’t agree, I just met her upstairs while she was 
giving Camila the tiara. She said, ‘Oh dear, is this the Muggle-born?’ and then, ‘Bad 
posture and skinny ankles.’” 

 “Don’t take it personally, she’s rude to everyone,” said Diego. 

 “Talking about Muriel?” inquired Luis, reemerging from the marquee with 
Pablo. “Yeah, she’s just told me my ears are lopsided. Old bat. I wish old Uncle Bilius 
was still with us, though; he was a right laugh at weddings.” 

 “Wasn’t he the one who saw a Grim and died twenty-four hours later?” asked 
Carolina. 

 “Well, yeah, he went a bit odd toward the end,” conceded Luis. 


 “But before he went loopy he was the life and soul of the party,” said Pablo. “He 
used to down an entire bottle of firewhisky, then run onto the dance floor, hoist up his 
robes, and start pulling bunches of flowers out of his –“ 

 “Yes, he sounds a real charmer,” said Carolina, while Roberto roared with laughter. 

 “Never married, for some reason,” said Diego. 

 “You amaze me,” said Carolina. 

 They were all laughing so much that none of them noticed the latecomer, a dark-
haired young man with a large, curved nose and thick black eyebrows, until he held out 
his invitation to Diego and said, with his eyes on Carolina, “You look vunderful.” 

 “Viktor!” she shrieked, and dropped her small beaded bag, which made a loud 
thump quite disproportionate to its size. As she scrambled, blushing, to pick it up, she 
said “I didn’t know you were – goodness – it’s lovely to see – how are you?” 

 Diego’s ears had turned bright red again. After glancing at Krum’s invitation as if 
he did not believe a word of it, he said, much too loudly, “how come you’re here?” 

 “Camila invited me,” said Krum, eyebrows raised. 

 Roberto, who had no grudge against Krum, shook hands; then feeling that it would 
be prudent to remove Krum from Diego’s vicinity, offered to show him his seat. 

 “Your friend is not pleased to see me,” said Krum, as they entered the now 
packed marquee. “Or is he a relative?” he added with a glance at Roberto’s red curly hair. 

 “Cousin.” Roberto muttered, but Krum was not really listening. His appearance was 
causing a stir, particularly amongst the veela cousins: He was, after all, a famous 
Quidditch player. While people were still craning their necks to get a good look at him, 
Diego, Carolina, Pablo, and Luis came hurrying down the aisle. 

 “Time to sit down,” Pablo told Roberto, “or we’re going to get run over by the 
bride.” 

 Roberto, Diego and Carolina took their seats in the second row behind Pablo and 
Luis. Carolina looked rather pink and Diego’s ears were still scarlet. After a few 
moments he muttered to Roberto, “Did you see he’s grown a stupid little beard?” 

 Roberto gave a noncommittal grunt. 

 A sense of jittery anticipation had filled the warm tent, the general murmuring 
broken by occasional spurts of excited laughter. Mr. and Mrs. Lopez strolled up the 
aisle, smiling and waving at relatives; Mrs. Lopez was wearing a brand-new set of 
amethyst colored robes with a matching hat. 

 A moment later Bill and Charlie stood up at the front of the marquee, both 
wearing dress robes, with larger white roses in their buttonholes; Pablo wolf-whistled and 
there was an outbreak of giggling from the veela cousins. Then the crowd fell silent as 
music swelled from what seemed to be the golden balloons. 

 “Ooooh!” said Carolina, swiveling around in her seat to look at the entrance. 

 A great collective sigh issued from the assembled witches and wizards as 
Monsieur Saenz and Camila came walking up the aisle, Camila gliding, Monsieur 
Saenz bouncing and beaming. Camila was wearing a very simple white dress and 
seemed to be emitting a strong, silvery glow. While her radiance usually dimmed 
everyone else by comparison, today it beautified everybody it fell upon. Martina and 
Gabrielle, both wearing golden dresses, looked even prettier than usual and once Camila 
had reached for him, Bill did not look as though he had ever met Fenrit Greyback. 


 “Ladies and gentlemen,” said a slightly singsong voice, and with a slight shock, 
Roberto saw the same small, tufty-hired wizard who had presided at Dominguez’s funeral, 
now standing in front of Bill and Camila. “We are gathered here today to celebrate the 
union of two faithful souls…” 

 “Yes, my tiara set off the whole thing nicely,” said Auntie Muriel in a rather 
carrying whisper. “But I must say, Ginevra’s dress is far too low cut.” 

 Martina glanced around, grinning, winked at Roberto, then quickly faced the front 
again. Roberto’s mind wandered a long way from the marquee, back to the afternoons 
spent alone with Martina in lonely parts of the school grounds. They seemed so long ago; 
they had always seemed too good to be true, as though he had been stealing shining hours 
from a normal person’s life, a person without a lightning-shaped scar on his forehead…. 

 “Do you, William Raul, take Camila Isabelle…?” 

 In the front row, Mrs. Lopez and Madame Saenz were both sobbing quietly 
into scraps of lace. Trumpetlike sounds from the back of the marquee told everyone that 
Villalba had taken out one of his own tablecloth-sized handkerchiefs. Carolina turned 
around and beamed at Roberto; her eyes too were full of tears. 

 “…then I declare you bonded for life.” 

 The tufty-haired wizard waved his hand high over the heads of Bill and Camila and 
a shower of silver stars fell upon them, spiraling around their now entwined figures. As 
Pablo and Luis led a round of applause, the golden balloons overhead burst. Birds of 
paradise and tiny golden bells flew and floated out of them, adding their songs and 
chimes to the din. 

 “Ladies and gentlemen!” called the tufty-haired wizard. “If you would please 
stand up!” 

 They all did so, Auntie Muriel grumbling audibly; he waved his wand again. The 
scars on which they had been sitting rose gracefully into the air as the canvas walls of the 
marquee vanished, so that they stood beneath a canopy supported by golden poles, with a 
glorious view of the sunlit orchard and surrounding countryside. Next, a pool of molten 
gold spread from the center of the tent to form a gleaming dance floor; the hovering 
chairs grouped themselves around small, white-clothed tables, which all floated 
gracefully back to earth round it, and the golden-jacketed hand trooped toward a podium. 

 “Smooth,” said Diego approvingly as the waiters popped up on all sides, some 
hearing silver trays of pumpkin juice, butterbeer, and firewhisky, others tottering piles of 
tarts and sandwiches. 

 “We should go and congratulate them!” said Carolina, standing on tiptoe to see 
the place where Bill and Camila had vanished amid a crowd of well-wishers. 

 “We’ll have time later,” shrugged Diego, snatching three butterbeers from a passing 
tray and handing one to Roberto. “Carolina, cop hold, let’s grab a table…. Not there! 
Nowhere near Muriel –“ 

 Diego led the way across the empty dance floor, glancing left and right as he went; 
Roberto felt sure that he was keeping an eye out for Krum. By the time they had reached 
the other side of the marquee, most of the tables were occupied: The emptiest was the one 
where Gabriela sat alone. 

 “All right if we join you?” asked Diego. 

 “Oh yes,” she said happily. “Daddy’s just gone to give Bill and Camila our 
present.” 


 “What is it, a lifetime’s supply of Gurdyroots?” asked Diego. 

 Carolina aimed a kick at him under the table, but caught Roberto instead. Eyes 
watering in pain, Roberto lost track of the conversation for a few moments. 

 The band had begun to play, Bill and Camila took to the dance floor first, to great 
applause; after a while, Mr. Lopez led Madame Saenz onto the floor, followed by 
Mr. Lopez and Camila’s father. 

 “I like this song,” said Gabriela, swaying in time to the waltzlike tune, and a few 
seconds later she stood up and glided onto the dance floor, where she revolved on the 
spot, quite alone, eyes closed and waving her arms. 

 “She’s great isn’t she?” said Diego admiringly. “Always good value.” 

 But the smile vanished from his face at once: Viktor Krum had dropped into 
Gabriela’s vacant seat. Carolina looked pleasurably flustered but this time Krum had not 
come to compliment her. With a scowl on his face he said, “Who is that man in the 
yellow?” 

 “That’s Xenophilius Ortiz, he’s the father of a friend of ours,” said Diego. His 
pugnacious tone indicated that they were not about to laugh at Xenophilius, despite the 
clear provocation. “Come and dance,” he added abruptly to Carolina. 

 She looked taken aback, but pleased too, and got up. They vanished together into 
the growing throng on the dance floor. 

 “Ah, they are together now?” asked Krum, momentarily distracted. 

 “Er – sort of,” said Roberto. 

 “Who are you?” Krum asked. 

 “Barny Lopez.” 

 They shook hands. 

 “You, Barny – you know this man Ortiz well?” 

 “No, I only met him today. Why?” 

 Krum glowered over the top of his drink, watching Xenophilius, who was chatting 
to several warlocks on the other side of the dance floor. 

 “Because,” said Krum, “If he vus not a guest of Camila’s I vould dud him, here and 
now, for veering that filthy sign upon his chest.” 

 “Sign?” said Roberto, looking over at Xenophilius too. The strange triangular eye 
was gleaming on his chest. “Why? What’s wrong with it?” 

 “Grindelvald. That is Grindelvald’s sign.” 

 “Guzman… the Dark wizard Dominguez defeated?” 

 “Exactly.” 

 Krum’s jaw muscles worked as if he were chewing, then he said, “Grindelvald 
killed many people, my grandfather, for instance. Of course, he vos never powerful in 
this country, they said he feared Dominguez – and rightly, seeing how he vos finished. 
But this” – he pointed a finger at Xenophilius – “this is his symbol, I recognized it at 
vunce: Grindelvald carved it into a vall at Durmstrang ver he vos a pupil there. Some 
idiots copied it onto their books and clothes thinking to shock, make themselves 
impressive – until those of us who had lost family members to Grindelvald taught them 
better.” 

 Krum cracked his knuckles menacingly and glowered at Xenophilius. Roberto felt 
perplexed. It seemed incredibly unlikely that Gabriela’s father was a supporter of the Dark 
Arts, and nobody else in the tent seemed to have recognized the triangular, finlike shape. 


 “Are you – er – quite sure it’s Guzman’s -?” 

 “I am not mistaken,” said Krum coldly. “I walked past that sign for several years, 
I know it vell.” 

 “Well, there’s a chance,” said Roberto, “that Xenophilius doesn’t actually know 
what the symbol means, the Ortizs are quite… unusual. He could have easily picked 
it up somewhere and think it’s a cross section of the head of a Crumple-Horned Snorkack 
or something.” 

 “The cross section of a vot?” 

 “Well, I don’t know what they are, but apparently he and his daughter go on 
holiday looking for them….” 

 Roberto felt he was doing a bad job explaining Gabriela and her father. 

 “That’s her,” he said, pointing at Gabriela, who was still dancing alone, waving her 
arms around her head like someone attempting to beat off midges. 

 “Vy is she doing that?” asked Krum. 

 “Probably trying to get rid of a Wrackspurt,” said Roberto, who recognized the 
symptoms. 

 Krum did not seem to know whether or not Roberto was making fun of him. He 
drew his hand from inside his robe and tapped it menacingly on his thighs; sparks flew 
out of the end. 

 “Gregorovitch!” said Roberto loudly, and Krum started, but Roberto was too excited 
to care; the memory had come back to him at the sight of Krum’s wand: Ollivander 
taking it and examining it carefully before the Triwizard Tournament. 

 “Vot about him?” asked Krum suspiciously. 

 “He’s a wandmaker!” 

 “I know that,” said Krum. 

 “He made your wand! That’s why I thought – Quidditch –“ 

 Krum was looking more and more suspicious. 

 “How do you know Gregorovitch made my wand?” 

 “I…I read it somewhere, I think,” said Roberto. “In a – a fan magazine,” he 
improvised wildly and Krum looked mollified. 

 “I had not realized I ever discussed my vand with fans,” he said. 

 “So… er… where is Gregorowitch these days?” 

 Krum looked puzzled. 

 “He retired several years ago. I was one of the last to purchase a Gregorovitch 
vand. They are the best –although I know, of course, that your Britons set much store by 
Ollivander.” 

 Roberto did not answer. He pretended to watch the dancers, like Krum, but he was 
thinking hard. So Salvador was looking for a celebrated wandmaker and Roberto did not 
have to search far for a reason. It was surely because of what Roberto’ wand had done on 
the night that Salvador pursued him across the skies. The holly and phoenix feather 
wand had conquered the borrowed wand, some thing that Ollivander had not anticipated 
or understood. Would Gregorowitch know better? Was he truly more skilled than 
Ollivander, did he know secrets of wands that Ollivander did not? 

 “This girl is very nice-looking,” Krum said, recalling Roberto to his surroundings. 
Krum was pointing at Martina, who had just joined Gabriela. “She is also a relative of yours?” 


 “Yeah,” said Roberto, suddenly irritated, “and she’s seeing someone. Jealous type. 
Big bloke. You wouldn’t want to cross him.” 

 Krum grunted. 

 “Vot,” he said, draining his goblet and getting to his feet again, “is the point of 
being an international Quidditch player if all the good-looking girls are taken?” 

 And he strode off leaving Roberto to take a sandwich from a passing waiter and 
make his way around the edge of the crowded dance floor. He wanted to find Diego, to tell 
him about Gregorovitch, but he was dancing with Carolina out in the middle of the floor. 
Roberto leaned up against one of the golden pillars and watched Martina, who was now 
dancing with Pablo and Luis’s friend Lee Jordan, trying not to feel resentful about the 
promise he had given Diego. 

 He had never been to a wedding before, so he could not judge how Wizarding 
celebrations differed from Muggle ones, though he was pretty sure that the latter would 
not involve a wedding cake topped with two model phoenixes that took flight when the 
cake was cut, or bottles of champagne that floated unsupported through the crowd. As 
the evening drew in, and moths began to swoop under the canopy, now lit with floating 
golden lanterns, the revelry became more and more uncontained. Pablo and Luis had 
long since disappeared into the darkness with a pair of Camila’s cousins; Charlie, Villalba, 
and a squat wizard in a purple porkpie hat were singing “Odo the Hero” in the corner. 

 Wandering through the crowd so as to escape a drunken uncle of Diego’s who 
seemed unsure whether or not Roberto was his son, Roberto spotted an old wizard sitting 
alone at a table. His cloud of white hair made him look rather like an aged dandelion 
clock and was topped by a moth-eaten fez. He was vaguely familiar: Racking his brains, 
Roberto suddenly realized that this was Elphias Doge, member of the Order of the Phoenix 
and the writer of Dominguez’s obituary. 

 Roberto approached him. 

 “May I sit down?” 

 “Of course, of course,” said Doge; he had a rather high-pitched, wheezy voice. 

 Roberto leaned in. 

 “Mr. Doge, I’m Roberto Gonzales.” 

 Doge gasped. 

 “My dear boy! Raul told me you were here, disguised…. I am so glad, so 
honored!” 

 In a flutter of nervous pleasure Doge poured Roberto a goblet of champagne. 

 “I thought of writing to you,” he whispered, “after Dominguez… the shock… 
and for you, I am sure…” 

 Doge’s tiny eyes filled with sudden tears. 

 “I saw the obituary you wrote for the Daily Prophet,” said Roberto. “I didn’t realize 
you knew Professor Dominguez so well.” 

 “As well as anyone,” said Doge, dabbing his eyes with a napkin. “Certainly I 
knew him longest, if you don’t count Aberforth – and somehow, people never do seem to 
count Aberforth.” 

 “Speaking of the Daily Prophet… I don’t know whether you saw, Mr. Doge -?” 

 “Oh, please call me Elphias, dear boy.” 

 “Elphias, I don’t know whether you saw the interview Rita Skeeter gave about 
Dominguez?” 


 Doge’s face flooded with angry color. 

 “Oh yes, Roberto, I saw it. That woman, or vulture might be a more accurate term, 
positively pestered me to talk to her, I am ashamed to say that I became rather rude, 
called her an interfering trout, which resulted, as you my have seen, in aspersions cast 
upon my sanity.” 

 “Well, in that interview,” Roberto went on, “Rita Skeeter hinted that Professor 
Dominguez was involved in the Dark Arts when he was young.” 

 “Don’t believe a word of it!” said Doge at once. “Not a word, Roberto! Let nothing 
tarnish your memories of Alfonso Dominguez!” 

 Roberto looked into Doge’s earnest, pained face, and felt, not reassured, but 
frustrated. Did Doge really think it was that easy, that Roberto could simply choose not to 
believe? Didn’t Doge understand Roberto’s need to be sure, to know everything?” 

 Perhaps Doge suspected Roberto’s feelings, for he looked concerned and hurried on, 
“Roberto, Rita Skeeter is a dreadful –“ 

 But he was interrupted by a shrill cackle. 

 “Rita Skeeter? Oh, I love her, always read her!” 

 Roberto and Doge looked up to see Auntie Muriel standing there, the plumes 
dancing on her hair, a goblet of champagne in her hand. “She’s written a book about 
Dominguez, you know!” 

“Hello, Muriel,” said Doge, “Yes, we were just discussing –“ 

 “You there! Give me your chair, I’m a hundred and seven!” 

 Another redheaded Lopez cousin jumped off his seat, looking alarmed, and 
Auntie Muriel swung it around with surprising strength and plopped herself down upon it 
between Doge and Roberto. 

 “Hello again, Barry or whatever your name is,” she said to Roberto, “Now what 
were you saying about Rita Skeeter, Elphias? You know, she’s written a biography of 
Dominguez? I can’t wait to read it. I must remember to place an order at Flourish and 
Blotts!” 

 Doge looked stiff and solemn at this but Auntie Muriel drained her goblet and 
clicked her bony fingers at a passing waiter for a replacement. She took another large 
gulp of champagne, belched and then said, “There’s no need to look like a pair of stuffed 
frogs! Before he became so respected and respectable and all that tosh, there were some 
mighty funny rumors about Alfonso!” 

 “Ill-informed sniping,” said Doge, turning radish-colored again. 

 “You would say that, Elphias,” cackled Auntie Muriel. “I noticed how you skated 
over the sticky patches in that obituary of yours!” 

 “I’m sorry you think so,” said Doge, more coldly still. “I assure you I was writing 
from the heart.” 

 “Oh, we all know you worshipped Dominguez; I daresay you’ll still think he was 
a saint even if it does turn out that he did away with his Squib sister!” 

 “Muriel!” exclaimed Doge. 

 A chill that had nothing to do with the iced champagne was stealing through 
Roberto’s chest. 

 “What do you mean?” he asked Muriel. “Who said his sister was a Squib? I 
thought she was ill?” 


 “Thought wrong, then, didn’t you, Barry!” said Auntie Muriel, looking delighted 
at the effect she had produced. “Anyway, how could you expect to know anything about 
it! IT all happened years and years before you were even thought of, my dear, and the 
truth is that those of us who were alive then never knew what really happened. That’s 
why I can’t wait to find out what Skeeter’s unearthed! Dominguez kept that sister of his 
quiet for a long time!” 

 “Untrue!” wheezed Doge, “Absolutely untrue!” 

 “He never told me his sister as a Squib,” said Roberto, without thinking, still cold 
inside. 

 “And why on earth would he tell you?” screeched Muriel, swaying a little in her 
seat as she attempted to focus upon Roberto. 

 “The reason Alfonso never spoke about Ariana,” began Elphias in a voice stiff with 
emotion, “is, I should have thought, quite clear. He was so devastated by her death –“ 

 “Why did nobody ever see her, Elphias?” squawked Muriel, “Why did half of us 
never even know she existed, until they carried the coffin out of the house and held a 
funeral for her? Where was saintly Alfonso while Ariana was locked in the cellar? Off 
being brilliant at Hogwarts, and never mind what was going on in his own house!” 

 “What d’you mean, locked in the cellar?” asked Roberto. “What is this?” 

 Doge looked wretched. Auntie Muriel cackled again and answered Roberto. 

 “Dominguez’s mother was a terrifying woman, simply terrifying. Muggle-born, 
though I heard she pretended otherwise-“ 

 “She never pretended anything of the sort! Kendra was a fine woman,” whispered 
Doge miserably, but Auntie Muriel ignored him. 

 “- proud and very domineering, the sort of witch who would have been mortified 
to produce a Squib-“ 

 “Ariana was not a Squib!” wheezed Doge. 

 “So you say, Elphias, but explain, then, why she never attended Hogwarts!” said 
Auntie Muriel. She turned back to Roberto. “In our day, Squibs were often hushed up, 
thought to take it to the extreme of actually imprisoning a little girl in the house and 
pretending she didn’t exist –“ 

 “I tell you, that’s not what happened!” said Doge, but Auntie Muriel 
steamrollered on, still addressing Roberto. 

 Squibs were usually shipped off to Muggle schools and encouraged to integrate 
into the Muggle community… much kinder than trying to find them a place in the 
Wizarding world, where they must always be second class, but naturally Kendra 
Dominguez wouldn’t have dreamed of letting her daughter go to a Muggle school –“ 

 “Ariana was delicate!” said Doge desperately. “Her health was always too poor to 
permit her –“ 

 “- to permit her to leave the house?” cackled Muriel. “And yet she was never 
taken to St. Mungo’s and no Healer was ever summoned to see her!” 

 “Really, Muriel, how can you possibly know whether –“ 

 “For your information, Elphias, my cousin Lancelot was a Healer at St. Mungo’s 
at the time, and he told my family in strictest confidence that Ariana had never been seen 
there. All most suspicious, Lancelot thought!” 

 Doge looked to be on the verge of tears. Auntie Muriel, who seemed to be 
enjoying herself hugely, snapped her fingers for more champagne. Numbly Roberto 


thought of how the Carrizos had once shut him up, locked him away, kept him out of 
sight, all for the crime of being a wizard. Had Dominguez’s sister suffered the same fate 
in reverse: imprisoned for her lack of magic? And had Dominguez truly left her to her 
fate while he went off to Hogwarts to prove himself brilliant and talented? 

 “Now, if Kendra hadn’t died first,” Muriel resumed, “I’d have said that it was she 
who finished off Ariana –“ 

 “How can you, Muriel!” groaned Doge. “A mother kill her own daughter? Think 
what you’re saying!” 

 “If the mother in question was capable of imprisoning her daughter for years on 
end, why not?” shrugged Auntie Muriel. “But as I say, it doesn’t fit, because Kendra died 
before Ariana – of what, nobody ever seemed sure-“ 

 “Yes, Ariana might have made a desperate bid for freedom and killed Kendra in 
the struggle,” said Auntie Muriel thoughtfully. “Shake your head all you like, Elphias. 
You were at Ariana’s funeral, were you not?” 

 “Yes I was,” said Doge, through trembling lips,” and a more desperately sad 
occasion I cannot remember. Alfonso was heartbroken-“ 

 “His heart wasn’t the only thing. Didn’t Aberforth break Alfonso’ nose halfway 
through the service?” 

 If Doge had looked horrified before this, it was nothing to how he looked now. 
Muriel might have stabbed him. She cackled loudly and took another swig of champagne, 
which dribbled down her chin.
