 “How do you -?” croaked Doge. 

 “My mother was friendly with old Bathilda Bagshot,” said Auntie Muriel happily. 
“Bathilda described the whole thing to mother while I was listening at the door. A 
coffin-side brawl. The way Bathilda told it, Aberforth shouted that it was all Alfonso’ fault 
that Ariana was dead and then punched him in the face. According to Bathilda, Alfonso did 
not even defend himself, and that’s odd enough in itself. Alfonso could have destroyed 
Aberforth in a duel with both hands tied behind his back. 

 Muriel swigged yet more champagne. The recitation of those old scandals 
seemed to elate her as much as they horrified Doge. Roberto did not know what to think, 
what to believe. He wanted the truth and yet all Doge did was sit there and bleat feebly 
that Ariana had been ill. Roberto could hardly believe that Dominguez would not have 
intervened if such cruelty was happening inside his own house, and yet there was 
undoubtedly something odd about the story. 

 “And I’ll tell you something else,” Muriel said, hiccupping slightly as she lowered 
her goblet. “I think Bathilda has spilled the beans to Rita Skeeter. All those hints in 
Skeeter’s interview about an important source close to the Dominguezs – goodness 
knows she was there all through the Ariana business, and it would fit!” 

 “Bathilda, would never talk to Rita Skeeter!” whispered Doge. 

 “Bathilda Bagshot?” Roberto said. “The author of A History of Magic?” 

 The name was printed on the front of one of Roberto’s textbooks, though admittedly 
not one of the ones he had read more attentively. 

 “Yes,” said Doge, clutching at Roberto’s question like a drowning man at a life heir. 
“A most gifted magical historian and an old friend of Alfonso’s.” 

 “Quite gaga these days, I’ve heard,” said Auntie Muriel cheerfully. 


 “If that is so, it is even more dishonorable for Skeeter to have taken advantage of 
her,” said Doge, “and no reliance can be placed on anything Bathilda may have said!” 

 “Oh, there are ways of bringing back memories, and I’m sure Rita Skeeter knows 
them all,” said Auntie Muriel “But even if Bathilda’s completely cuckoo, I’m sure she’d 
still have old photographs, maybe even letters. She knew the Dominguezs for years…. 
Well worth a trip to Godric’s Hollow, I’d have thought.” 

 Roberto, who had been taking a sip of butterbeer, choked. Doge banged him on the 
back as Roberto coughed, looking at Auntie Muriel through streaming eyes. Once he had 
control of his voice again, he asked, “Bathilda Bagshot lives in Godric’s Hollow?” 

 “Oh yes, she’s been there forever! The Dominguezs moved there after Percival 
was imprisoned, and she was their neighbor.” 

 “The Dominguezs lived in Godric’s Hollows?” 

 “Yes, Barry, that’s what I just said,” said Auntie Muriel testily. 

 Roberto felt drained, empty. Never once, in six years, had Dominguez told Roberto 
that they had both lived and lost loved ones in Godric’s Hollow. Why? Were Sofia and 
Ricardo buried close to Dominguez’s mother and sister? Had Dominguez visited their 
graves, perhaps walked past Sofia’s and Ricardo’s to do so? And he had never once told 
Roberto … never bothered to say… 

 And why it was so important, Roberto could not explain even to himself, yet he felt 
it had been tantamount to a lie not to tell him that they had this place and these 
experiences in common. He stared ahead of him, barely noticing what was going on 
around him, and did not realize that Carolina had appeared out of the crowd until she 
drew up a chair beside him. 

 “I simply can’t dance anymore,” she panted, slipping of one of her shoes and 
rubbing the sole of her foot. “Diego’s gone looking to find more butterbeers. It’s a bit odd. 
I’ve just seen Viktor storming away from Gabriela’s father, it looked like they’d been 
arguing –“ She dropped her voice, staring at him. “Roberto, are you okay?” 

 Roberto did not know where to begin, but it did not matter, at that moment, 
something large and silver came falling through the canopy over the dance floor. 
Graceful and gleaming, the lynx landed lightly in the middle of the astonished dancers. 
Heads turned, as those nearest it froze absurdly in mid-dance. Then the Patronus’s mouth 
opened wide and it spoke in the loud, deep, slow voice of Hector Maldonado. 

 “The Ministry has fallen. Scrimgeour is dead. They are coming.” 

Chapter Nine 

A Place to Hide 

 

Everything seemed fuzzy, slow. Roberto and Carolina jumped to their feet and 
drew their wands. Many people were only just realizing that something strange had 
happened; heads were still turning toward the silver cat as it vanished. Silence spread 
outward in cold ripples from the place where the Patronus had landed. Then somebody 
screamed. 

 Roberto and Carolina threw themselves into the panicking crowd. Guests were 
sprinting in all directions; many were Disapparating; the protective enchantments around 
the Burrow had broken. 


 “Diego!” Carolina cried. “Diego, where are you?” 

 As they pushed their way across the dance floor, Roberto saw cloaked and masked 
figures appearing in the crowd; then he saw Cardozo and Perez, their wands raised, and 
heard both of them shout, “Protego!”, a cry that was echoed on all sides – 

 “Diego! Diego!” Carolina called, half sobbing as she and Roberto were buffered by 
terrified guests: Roberto seized her hand to make sure they weren’t separated as a streak of 
light whizzed over their heads, whether a protective charm or something more sinister he 
did not know – 

 And then Diego was there. He caught hold of Carolina’s free arm, and Roberto felt 
her turn on the spot; sight and sound were extinguished as darkness pressed in upon him; 
all he could feel was Carolina’s hand as he was squeezed through space and time, away 
from the Burrow, away from the descending Death Eaters, away, perhaps, from 
Salvador himself. . . . 

 “Where are we?” said Diego’s voice. 

 Roberto opened his eyes. For a moment he thought they had not left the wedding 
after all; They still seemed to be surrounded by people. 

 “Tottenham Court Road,” panted Carolina. “Walk, just walk, we need to find 
somewhere for you to change.” 

 Roberto did as she asked. They half walked, half ran up the wide dark street 
thronged with late-night revelers and lined with closed shops, stars twinkling above them. 
A double-decker bus rumbled by and a group of merry pub-goers ogled them as they 
passed; Roberto and Diego were still wearing dress robes. 

 “Carolina, we haven’t got anything to change into,” Diego told her, as a young 
woman burst into raucous giggles at the sight of him. 

 “Why didn’t I make sure I had the Invisibility Cloak with me?” said Roberto, 
inwardly cursing his own stupidity. “All last year I kept it on me and –“ 

 “It’s okay, I’ve got the Cloak, I’ve got clothes for both of you,” said Carolina, 
“Just try and act naturally until – this will do.” 

 She led them down a side street, then into the shelter of a shadowy alleyway. 

 “When you say you’ve got the Cloak, and clothes . . .” said Roberto, frowning at 
Carolina, who was carrying nothing except her small beaded handbag, in which she was 
now rummaging. 

 “Yes, they’re here,” said Carolina, and to Roberto and Diego’s utter astonishment, 
she pulled out a pair of jeans, a sweatshirt, some maroon socks, and finally the silvery 
Invisibility Cloak. 

 “How the ruddy hell – ?” 

 “Undetectable Extension Charm,” said Carolina. “Tricky, but I think I’ve done it 
okay; anyway, I managed to fit everything we need in here.” She gave the fragile-looking 
bag a little shake and it echoed like a cargo hold as a number of heavy objects rolled 
around inside it. “Oh, damn, that’ll be the books,” she said, peering into it, “and I had 
them all stacked by subject. . . . Oh well. . . . Roberto, you’d better take the Invisibility 
Cloak. Diego, hurry up and change. . . .” 

 “When did you do all this?” Roberto asked as Diego stripped off his robes. 

 “I told you at the Burrow, I’ve had the essentials packed for days, you know, in 
case we needed to make a quick getaway. I packed your rucksack this morning, Roberto, 
after you changed, and put it in here. . . . I just had a feeling. . . .” 


 “You’re amazing, you are,” said Diego, handing her his bundled-up robes. 

 “Thank you,” said Carolina, managing a small smile as she pushed the robes into 
the bag. “Please, Roberto, get that Cloak on!” 

 Roberto threw his Invisibility Cloak around his shoulders and pulled it up over his 
head, vanishing from sight. He was only just beginning to appreciate what had happened. 

 “The others – everybody at the wedding –“ 

 “We can’t worry about that now,” whispered Carolina. “It’s you they’re after, 
Roberto, and we’ll just put everyone in even more danger by going back.” 

 “She’s right,” said Diego, who seemed to know that Roberto was about to argue, even 
if he could not see his face. “Most of the Order was there, they’ll look after everyone.” 

 Roberto nodded, then remembered that they could not see him, and said, “Yeah.” 
But he thought of Martina, and fear bubbled like acid in his stomach. 

 “Come on, I think we ought to keep moving,” said Carolina. 

 They moved back up the side street and onto the main road again, where a group 
of men on the opposite side was singing and weaving across the pavement. 

 “Just as a matter of interest, why Tottenham Court Road?” Diego asked Carolina. 

 “I’ve no idea, it just popped into my head, but I’m sure we’re safer out in the 
Muggle world, it’s not where they’ll expect us to be.” 

 “True,” said Diego, looking around, “but don’t you feel a bit – exposed?” 

 “Where else is there?” asked Carolina, cringing as the men on the other side of 
the road started wolf-whistling at her. “We can hardly book rooms at the Leaky Cauldron, 
can we? And Grimmauld Place is out if Peralta can get in there. . . . I suppose we could try 
my parents’ home, though I think there’s a chance they might check there. . . . Oh, I wish 
they’d shut up!” 

 “All right, darling?” the drunkest of the men on the other pavement was yelling. 
“Fancy a drink? Ditch ginger and come and have a pint!” 

 “Let’s sit down somewhere,” Carolina said hastily as Diego opened his mouth to 
shout back across the road. “Look, this will do, in here!” 

 It was a small and shabby all-night café. A light layer of grease lay on all the 
Formica-topped tables, but it was at least empty. Roberto slipped into a booth first and Diego 
sat next to him opposite Carolina, who had her back to the entrance and did not like it: 
She glanced over her shoulder so frequently she appeared to have a twitch. Roberto did not 
like being stationary; walking had given the illusion that they had a goal. Beneath the 
Cloak he could feel the last vestiges of Polyjuice leaving him, his hands returning to their 
usual length and shape. He pulled his glasses out of his pocket and put them on again. 

 After a minute or two, Diego said, “You know, we’re not far from the Leaky 
Cauldron here, it’s only in Charing Cross –“ 

 “Diego, we can’t!” said Carolina at once. 

 “Not to stay there, but to find out what’s going on!” 

 “We know what’s going on! Salvador’s taken over the Ministry, what else do 
we need to know?” 

 “Okay, okay, it was just an idea!” 
They relapsed into a prickly silence. The gum-chewing waitress shuffled over and 
Carolina ordered two cappuccinos: As Roberto was invisible, it would have looked odd to 
order him one. A pair of burly workmen entered the café and squeezed into the next 
booth. Carolina dropped her voice to a whisper. 


 “I say we find a quiet place to Disapparate and head for the countryside. Once 
we’re there, we could send a message to the Order.” 

 “Can you do that talking Patronus thing, then?” asked Diego. 

 “I’ve been practicing and I think so,” said Carolina. 

 “Well, as long as it doesn’t get them into trouble, though they might’ve been 
arrested already. God, that’s revolting,” Diego added after one sip of the foamy, grayish 
coffee. The waitress had heard; she shot Diego a nasty look as she shuffled off to take the 
new customers’ orders. The larger of the two workmen, who was blond and quite huge, 
now that Roberto came to look at him, waved her away. She stared, affronted. 

 “Let’s get going, then, I don’t want to drink this muck,” said Diego. “Carolina, 
have you got Muggle money to pay for this?” 

 “Yes, I took out all my Building Society savings before I came to the Burrow. I’ll 
bet all the change is at the bottom,” sighed Carolina, reaching for her beaded bag. 

 The two workmen made identical movements, and Roberto mirrored them without 
conscious thought: All three of them drew their wands. Diego, a few seconds late in 
realizing what was going on, lunged across the table, pushing Carolina sideways onto 
her bench. The force of the Death Eaters’ spells shattered the tiled wall where Diego’s head 
had just been, as Roberto, still invisible, yelled, “Stupefy!” 

 The great blond Death Eater was hit in the face by a jet of red light: He slumped 
sideways, unconscious. His companion, unable to see who had cast the spell, fired 
another at Diego: Shining black ropes flew from his wand-tip and bound Diego head to foot – 
the waitress screamed and ran for the door – Roberto sent another Stunning Spell at the 
Death Eater with the twisted face who had tied up Diego, but the spell missed, rebounded 
on the window, and hit the waitress, who collapsed in front of the door. 

 “Expulso!” bellowed the Death Eater, and the table behind which Roberto was 
standing blew up: The force of the explosion slammed him into the wall and he felt his 
wand leave his hand as the Cloak slipped off him. 

 “Petrificus Totalus!” screamed Carolina from out of sight, and the Death Eater 
fell forward like a statue to land with a crunching thud on the mess of broken china, table, 
and coffee. Carolina crawled out from underneath the bench, shaking bits of glass 
ashtray out of her hair and trembling all over. 

 “D-diffindo,” she said, pointing her wand at Diego, who roared in pain as she 
slashed open the knee of his jeans, leaving a deep cut. “Oh, I’m so sorry, Diego, my hand’s 
shaking! Diffindo!” 

 The severed ropes fell away. Diego got to his feet, shaking his arms to regain 
feeling in them. Roberto picked up his wand and climbed over all the debris to where the 
large blond Death Eater was sprawled across the bench. 

 “I should’ve recognized him, he was there the night Dominguez died,” he said. 
He turned over the darker Death Eater with his foot; the man’s eyes moved rapidly 
between Roberto, Diego and Carolina. 

 “That’s Dolohov,” said Diego. “I recognize him from the old wanted posters. I think 
the big one’s Thorfinn Rowle.” 

 “Never mind what they’re called!” said Carolina a little hysterically. “How did 
they find us? What are we going to do?” 

 Somehow her panic seemed to clear Roberto’s head. 

 “Lock the door,” he told her, “and Diego, turn out the lights.” 


 He looked down at the paralyzed Dolohov, thinking fast as the lock clicked and 
Diego used the Deluminator to plunge the café into darkness. Roberto could hear the men 
who had jeered at Carolina earlier, yelling at another girl in the distance. 

 “What are we going to do with them?” Diego whispered to Roberto through the dark; 
then, even more quietly, “Kill them? They’d kill us. They had a good go just now.” 

 Carolina shuddered and took a step backward. Roberto shook his head. 

 “We just need to wipe their memories,” said Roberto. “It’s better like that, it’ll 
throw them off the scent. If we killed them it’d be obvious we were here.” 

 “You’re the boss,” said Diego, sounding profoundly relieved. “But I’ve never down 
a Memory Charm.” 

 “Nor have I,” said Carolina, “but I know the theory.” 

 She took a deep, calming breath, then pointed her wand at Dolohov’s forehead 
and said, “Obliviate.” 

 At once, Dolohov’s eyes became unfocused and dreamy. 

 “Brilliant!” said Roberto, clapping her on the back. “Take care of the other one and 
the waitress while Diego and I clear up.” 
“Clear up?” said Diego, looking around at the partly destroyed café. “Why?” 

 “Don’t you think they might wonder what’s happened if they wake up and find 
themselves in a place that looks like it’s just been bombed?” 

 “Oh right, yeah . . .” 

 Diego struggled for a moment before managing to extract his wand from his pocket. 

 “It’s no wonder I can’t get it out, Carolina, you packed my old jeans, they’re 
tight.” 

 “Oh, I’m so sorry,” hissed Carolina, and as she dragged the waitress out of sight 
of the windows, Roberto heard her mutter a suggestion as to where Diego could stick his 
wand instead. 

 Once the café was restored to its previous condition, they heaved the Death Eaters 
back into their booth and propped them up facing each other. “But how did they find us?” 
Carolina asked, looking from one inert man to the other. “How did they know where we 
were?” 

 She turned to Roberto. 

 “You – you don’t think you’ve still got your Trace on you, do you, Roberto?” 

 “He can’t have,” said Diego. “The Trace breaks at seventeen, that’s Wizarding law, 
you can’t put it on an adult.” 

 “As far as you know,” said Carolina. “What if the Death Eaters have found a 
way to put it on a seventeen-year-old?” 

 “But Roberto hasn’t been near a Death Eater in the last twenty-four hours. Who’s 
supposed to have put a Trace back on him?” 

 Carolina did not reply. Roberto felt contaminated, tainted: Was that really how the 
Death Eaters had found them? 

 “If I can’t use magic, and you can’t use magic near me, without us giving away 
our position – “ he began. 

 “We’re not splitting up!” said Carolina firmly. 

 “We need a safe place to hide,” said Diego. “Give us time to think things through.” 

 “Grimmauld Place,” said Roberto. 

 The other two gaped. 


 “Don’t be silly, Roberto, Peralta can get in there!” 

 “Diego’s dad said they’ve put up jinxes against him – and even if they haven’t 
worked,” he pressed on as Carolina began to argue “so what? I swear, I’d like nothing 
better than to meet Peralta!” 

 “But –“ 

 “Carolina, where else is there? It’s the best chance we’ve got. Peralta’s only one 
Death Eater. If I’ve still got the Trace on me, we’ll have whole crowds of them on us 
wherever else we go.” 

 She could not argue, though she looked as if she would have liked to. While she 
unlocked the café door, Diego clicked the Deluminator to release the café’s light. Then, on 
Roberto’s count of three, they reversed the spells upon their three victims, and before the 
waitress or either of the Death Eaters could do more than stir sleepily, Roberto, Diego and 
Carolina had turned on the spot and vanished into the compressing darkness once more. 

 Seconds later Roberto’s lungs expanded gratefully and he opened his eyes: They 
were now standing in the middle of a familiar small and shabby square. Tall, dilapidated 
houses looked down on them from every side. Number twelve was visible to them, for 
they had been told of its existence by Dominguez, its Secret-Keeper, and they rushed 
toward it, checking every few yards that they were not being followed or observed. They 
raced up the stone steps, and Roberto tapped the front door once with his wand. They heard 
a series of metallic clicks and the clatter of a chain, then the door swung open with a 
creak and they hurried over the threshold. 

 As Roberto closed the door behind them, the old-fashioned gas lamps sprang into 
life, casting flickering light along the length of the hallway. It looked just as Roberto 
remembered it: eerie, cobwebbed, the outlines of the house-elf heads on the wall 
throwing odd shadows up the staircase. Long dark curtains concealed the portrait of 
Gustavo’s mother. The only thing that was out of place was the troll’s leg umbrella stand, 
which was lying on its side as if Perez had just knocked it over again. 

 “I think somebody’s been in here,” Carolina whispered, pointing toward it. 

 “That could’ve happened as the Order left,” Diego murmured back. 

 “So where are these jinxes they put up against Peralta?” Roberto asked. 

 “Maybe they’re only activated if he shows up?” suggested Diego. 

 Yet they remained close together on the doormat, backs against the door, scared 
to move farther into the house. 

 “Well, we can’t stay here forever,” said Roberto, and he took a step forward. 

 “Carlos Peralta?” 

 Mad-Eye Acosta’s voice whispered out of the darkness, making all three of them 
jump back in fright. “We’re not Peralta!” croaked Roberto, before something whooshed over 
him like cold air and his tongue curled backward on itself, making it impossible to speak. 
Before he had time to feel inside his mouth, however, his tongue had unraveled again. 

 The other two seemed to have experienced the same unpleasant sensation. Diego 
was making retching noises; Carolina stammered, “That m-must have b-been the T-
Tongue-Tying Curse Mad-Eye set up for Peralta!” 

 Gingerly Roberto took another step forward. Something shifted in the shadows at 
the end of the hall, and before any of them could say another word, a figure had risen up 
out of the carpet, tall, dust-colored, and terrible; Carolina screamed and so did Mrs. 
Martinez, her curtains flying open; the gray figure was gliding toward them, faster and faster, 


its waist-length hair and beard streaming behind it, its face sunken, fleshless, with empty 
eye sockets: Horribly familiar, dreadfully altered, it raised a wasted arm, pointing at 
Roberto. 

 “No!” Roberto shouted, and though he had raised his wand no spell occurred to him. 
“No! It wasn’t us! We didn’t kill you –“ 

 On the word kill, the figure exploded in a great cloud of dust: Coughing, his eyes 
watering, Roberto looked around to see Carolina crouched on the floor by the door with 
her arms over her head, and Diego, who was shaking from head to foot, patting her 
clumsily on the shoulder and saying, “It’s all r-right. . . . It’s g-gone. . . .” 

 Dust swirled around Roberto like mist, catching the blue gaslight, as Mrs. Martinez 
continued to scream. 

 “Mudbloods, filth, stains of dishonor, taint of shame on the house of my fathers –“ 

 “SHUT UP!” Roberto bellowed, directing his wand at her, and with a bang and a 
burst of red sparks, the curtains swung shut again, silencing her. 

 “That . . . that was . . . “ Carolina whimpered, as Diego helped her to her feet. 

 “Yeah,” said Roberto, “but it wasn’t really him, was it? Just something to scare 
Peralta.” 
Had it worked, Roberto wondered, or had Peralta already blasted the horror-figure 
aside as casually as he had killed the real Dominguez? Nerves still tingling, he led the 
other two up the hall, half-expecting some new terror to reveal itself, but nothing moved 
except for a mouse skittering along the skirting board. 

 “Before we go any farther, I think we’d better check,” whispered Carolina, and 
she raised her wand and said, “Homenum revelio.” 

 Nothing happened. 

 “Well, you’ve just had a big shock,” said Diego kindly. “What was that supposed to 
do?” 

 “It did what I meant it to do!” said Carolina rather crossly. “That was a spell to 
reveal human presence, and there’s nobody here except us!” 
“And old Dusty,” said Diego, glancing at the patch of carpet from which the corpse-
figure had risen. 

 “Let’s go up,” said Carolina with a frightened look at the same spot, and she led 
the way up the creaking stairs to the drawing room on the first floor. 

 Carolina waved her wand to ignite the old gas lamps, then, shivering slightly in 
the drafty room, she perched on the sofa, her arms wrapped tightly around her. Diego 
crossed to the window and moved the heavy velvet curtains aside an inch. 

 “Can’t see anyone out there,” he reported. “And you’d think, if Roberto still had a 
Trace on him, they’d have followed us here. I know they can’t get in the house, but – 
what’s up, Roberto?” 

 Roberto had given a cry of pain: His scar had burned against as something flashed 
across his mind like a bright light on water. He saw a large shadow and felt a fury that 
was not his own pound through his body, violent and brief as an electric shock. 

 “What did you see?” Diego asked, advancing on Roberto. “Did you see him at my 
place?” 

 “No, I just felt anger – he’s really angry –“ 

 “But that could be at the Burrow,” said Diego loudly. “What else? Didn’t you see 
anything? Was he cursing someone?” 


 “No, I just felt anger – I couldn’t tell –“ 

 Roberto felt badgered, confused, and Carolina did not help as she said in a 
frightened voice, “Your scar, again? But what’s going on? I thought that connection had 
closed!” 

 “It did, for a while,” muttered Roberto; his scar was still painful, which made it hard 
to concentrate. “I – I think it’s started opening again whenever he loses control, that’s 
how it used to –“ 

 “But then you’ve got to close your mind!” said Carolina shrilly. “Roberto, 
Dominguez didn’t want you to use that connection, he wanted you to shut it down, that’s 
why you were supposed to use Occlumency! Otherwise Salvador can plant false images 
in your mind, remember –“ 

 “Yeah, I do remember, thanks,” said Roberto through gritted teeth; he did not need 
Carolina to tell him that Salvador had once used this selfsame connection between 
them to lead him into a trap, nor that it had resulted in Gustavo’s death. He wished that he 
had not told them what he had seen and felt; it made Salvador more threatening, as 
though he were pressing against the window of the room, and still the pain in his scar was 
building and he fought it: It was like resisting the urge to be sick. 

 He turned his back on Diego and Carolina, pretending to examine the old tapestry 
of the Martinez family tree on the wall. Then Carolina shrieked: Roberto drew his wand again 
and spun around to see a silver Patronus soar through the drawing room window and land 
upon the floor in front of them, where it solidified into the weasel that spoke with the 
voice of Diego’s father. 

 “Family safe, do not reply, we are being watched.” 

 The Patronus dissolved into nothingness. Diego let out a noise between a whimper 
and a groan and dropped onto the sofa: Carolina joined him, gripping his arm. 

 “They’re all right, they’re all right!” she whispered, and Diego half laughed and 
hugged her. 

 “Roberto,” he said over Carolina’s shoulder, “I –“ 

 “It’s not a problem,” said Roberto, sickened by the pain in his head. “It’s your 
family, ‘course you were worried. I’d feel the same way.” He thought of Martina. “I do feel 
the same way.” 

 The pain in his scar was reaching a peak, burning as it had back in the garden of 
the Burrow. Faintly he heard Carolina say “I don’t want to be on my own. Could we use 
the sleeping bags I’ve brought and camp in here tonight?” 

 He heard Diego agree. He could not fight the pain much longer. He had to succumb. 

 “Bathroom,” he muttered, and he left the room as fast as he could without running. 

 He barely made it: Bolting the door behind him with trembling hands, he grasped 
his pounding head and fell to the floor, then in an explosion of agony, he felt the rage that 
did not belong to him possess his soul, saw a long room lit only by firelight, and the giant 
blond Death Eater on the floor, screaming and writhing, and a slighter figure standing 
over him, wand outstretched, while Roberto spoke in a high, cold, merciless voice. 

 “More, Rowle, or shall we end it and feed you to Nagini? Lord Salvador is not 
sure that he will forgive this time. . . . You called me back for this, to tell me that Roberto 
Gonzales has escaped again? Javier, give Rowle another taste of our displeasure. . . . Do it, 
or feel my wrath yourself!” 


 A log fell in the fire: Flames reared, their light darting across a terrified, pointed 
white face – with a sense of emerging from deep water, Roberto drew heaving breaths and 
opened his eyes. 

 He was spread-eagled on the cold black marble floor, his nose inches from one of 
the silver serpent tails that supported the large bathtub. He sat up. Sosa’s gaunt, 
petrified face seemed burned on the inside of his eyes. Roberto felt sickened by what he had 
seen, by the use to which Javier was now being put by Salvador. 

 There was a sharp rap on the door, and Roberto jumped as Carolina’s voice rang 
out. 

 “Roberto, do you want your toothbrush? I’ve got it here.” 

 “Yeah, great, thanks,” he said, fighting to keep his voice casual as he stood up to 
let her in. 

 

Chapter Ten 

Kreacher’s Tale 

Roberto woke early next morning, wrapped in a sleeping bag on the drawing room 
floor. A chink of sky was visible between the heavy curtains. It was the cool, clear blue 
of watered ink, somewhere between night and dawn, and everything was quiet except for 
Diego and Carolina’s slow, deep breathing. Roberto glanced over at the dark shapes they 
made on the floor beside him. Diego had had a fit of gallantry and insisted that Carolina 
sleep on the cushions from the sofa, so that her silhouette was raised above his. Her arm 
curved to the floor, her fingers inches from Diego’s. Roberto wondered whether they had 
fallen asleep holding hands. The idea made him feel strangely lonely. 

 He looked up at the shadowy ceiling, the cobwebbed chandelier. Less than 
twenty-four house ago, he had been standing in the sunlight at the entrance to the 
marquee, waiting to show in wedding guests. It seemed a lifetime away. What was going 
to happen now? He lay on the floor and he thought of the Horcruxes, of the daunting 
complex mission Dominguez had left him… Dominguez… 

 The grief that had possessed him since Dominguez’s death felt different now. 
The accusations he had heard from Muriel at the wedding seemed to have nested in his 
brain like diseased things, infecting his memories of the wizard he had idolized. Could 
Dominguez have let such things happen? Had he been like Leonardo, content to watch 
neglect and abuse as long as it did not affect him? Could he have turned his back on a 
sister who was being imprisoned and hidden? 

 Roberto thought of Godric’s Hollow, of graves Dominguez had never mentioned 
there; he thought of mysterious objects left without explanation in Dominguez’s will, 
and resentment swelled in the darkness. Why hadn’t Dominguez told him? Why hadn’t 
he explained? Had Dominguez actually cared about Roberto at all? Or had Roberto been 
nothing more than a tool to be polished and honed, but not trusted, never confided in? 

 Roberto could not stand lying there with nothing but bitter thoughts for company. 
Desperate for something to do, for distraction, he slipped out of his sleeping bad, picked 
up his wand, and crept out of the room. On the landing he whispered, “Lumos,” and 
started to climb the stairs by wandlight. 


 On the second landing was the bedroom in which he and Diego had slept last time 
they had been here; he glanced into it. The wardrobe doors stood open and the bedclothes 
had been ripped back. Roberto remembered the overturned troll leg downstairs. Somebody 
had searched the house since the Order had left. Peralta? Or perhaps Mundungus, who had 
pilfered plenty from this house both before and after Gustavo died? Roberto’s gaze wandered 
to the portrait that sometimes contained Phineas Nigellus Martinez, Gustavo’s great-great 
grandfather, but it was empty, showing nothing but a stretch of muddy backdrop. Phineas 
Nigellus was evidently spending the night in the headmaster’s study at Hogwarts. 

 Roberto continued up the stairs until he reached the topmost landing where there 
were only two doors. The one facing him bore a nameplate reading Gustavo. Roberto had 
never entered his godfather’s bedroom before. He pushed open the door, holding his 
wand high to cast light as widely as possible. The room was spacious and must once have 
been handsome. There was a large bed with a carved wooden headboard, a tall window 
obscured by long velvet curtains and a chandelier thickly coated in dust with candle 
scrubs still resting in its sockets, solid wax banging in frostlike drips. A fine film of dust 
covered the pictures on the walls and the bed’s headboard; a spiders web stretched 
between the chandelier and the top of the large wooden wardrobe, and as Roberto moved 
deeper into the room, he head a scurrying of disturbed mice. 

 The teenage Gustavo had plastered the walls with so many posters and pictures that 
little of the wall’s silvery-gray silk was visible. Roberto could only assume that Gustavo’s 
parents had been unable to remove the Permanent Sticking Charm that kept them on the 
wall because he was sure they would not have appreciated their eldest son’s taste in 
decoration. Gustavo seemed to have long gone out of his way to annoy his parents. There 
were several large Gryffindor banners, faded scarlet and gold just to underline his 
difference from all the rest of the Slytherin family. There were many pictures of Muggle 
motorcycles, and also (Roberto had to admire Gustavo’s nerve) several posters of bikini-clad 
Muggle girls. Roberto could tell that they were Muggles because they remained quite 
stationary within their pictures, faded smiles and glazed eyes frozen on the paper. This 
was in contrast the only Wizarding photograph on the walls which was a picture of four 
Hogwarts students standing arm in arm, laughing at the camera. 

 With a leap of pleasure, Roberto recognized his father, his untidy black hair stuck 
up at the back like Roberto’s, and he too wore glasses. Beside him was Gustavo, carelessly 
handsome, his slightly arrogant face so much younger and happier than Roberto had ever 
seen it alive. To Gustavo’s right stood Salazar, more than a head shorter, plump and 
watery-eyed, flushed with pleasure at his inclusion in this coolest of gangs, with the 
much-admired rebels that Ricardo and Gustavo had been. On Ricardo’s left was Cardozo, even 
then a little shabby-looking, but he had the same air of delighted surprise at finding 
himself liked and included or was it simply because Roberto knew how it had been, that he 
saw these things in the picture? He tried to take it from the wall; it was his now, after all, 
Gustavo had left him everything, but it would not budge. Gustavo had taken no chances in 
preventing his parents from redecorating his room. 

 Roberto looked around at the floor. The sky outside was growing brightest. A shaft 
of light revealed bits of paper, books, and small objects scattered over the carpet. 
Evidently Gustavo’s bedroom had been reached too, although its contents seemed to have 
been judged mostly, if not entirely, worthless. A few of the books had been shaken 
roughly enough to part company with the covers and sundry pages littered the floor. 


 Roberto bent down, picked up a few of the pieces of paper, and examined them. He 
recognized one as a part of an old edition of A History of Magic, by Bathilda Bagshot, 
and another as belonging to a motorcycle maintenance manual. The third was 
handwritten and crumpled. He smoothed it out. 

 

 Dear Padfoot, 

 Thank you, thank you, for Roberto’s birthday present! It was his favorite by 
far. One year old and already zooming along on a toy broomstick, he looked so pleased 
with himself. I’m enclosing a picture so you can see. You know it only rises about two feet 
off the ground but he nearly killed the cat and he smashed a horrible vase Beatriz sent 
me for Christmas (no complaints there). Of course Ricardo thought it was so funny, says 
he’s going to be a great Quidditch player but we’ve had to pack away all the ornaments 
and make sure we don’t take our eyes off him when he gets going. 

 We had a very quiet birthday tea, just us and old Bathilda who has always been 
sweet to us and who dotes on Garry. We were so sorry you couldn’t come, but the 
Order’s got to come first, and Roberto’s not old enough to know it’s his birthday anyway! 
Ricardo is getting a bit frustrated shut up here, he tries not to show it but I can tell – also 
Dominguez’s still got his Invisibility Cloak, so no chance of little excursions. If you 
could visit, it would cheer him up so much. Wormy was here last weekend. I thought he 
seemed down, but that was probably the next about the McKinnons; I cried all evening 
when I heard. 

 Bathilda drops in most days, she’s a fascinating old thing with the most amazing 
stories about Dominguez. I’m not sure he’d be pleased if he knew! I don’t know how 
much to believe, actually because it seems incredible that Dominguez 

 

 Roberto’s extremities seemed to have gone numb. He stood quite still, holding the 
miraculous paper in his nerveless fingers while inside him a kind of quiet eruptions sent 
joy and grief thundering its equal measure through his veins. Lurching to the bed, he sat 
down. 

 He read the letter again, but could not take in any more meaning than he had done 
the first time, and was reduced to staring at the handwriting itself. She had made her “g”s 
the same way he did. He searched through the letter for every one of them, and each felt 
like a friendly little wave glimpsed from behind a veil. The letter was an incredible 
treasure, proof that Sofia Gonzales had lived, really lived, that her warm hand had once 
moved across this parchment, tracing ink into these letters, these words, words about him, 
Roberto, her son. 

 Impatiently brushing away the wetness in his eyes, he reread the letter, this time 
concentrating on the meaning. It was like listening to a half-remembered voice. 

 They had a cat… perhaps it had perished, like his parents at Godric’s Hollow… or 
else fled when there was nobody left to feed it… Gustavo had bought him his first 
broomstick… His parents had known Bathilda Bagshot; had Dominguez introduced 
them? Dominguez’s still got his Invisibility Cloak… there was something funny there… 

 Roberto paused, pondering his mother’s words. Why had Dominguez taken 
Ricardo’s Invisibility Cloak? Roberto distinctly remembered his headmaster telling him years 
before, “I don’t need a cloak to become invisible” Perhaps some less gifted Order 


member had needed its assistance, and Dominguez had acted as a carrier? Roberto passed 
on… 

 Wormy was here… Salazar, the traitor, had seemed “down” had he? Was he 
aware that he was seeing Ricardo and Sofia alive for the last time? 

 And finally Bathilda again, who told incredible stories about Dominguez. It 
seems incredible that Dominguez --- 

 That Dominguez what? But there were any number of things that would seem 
incredible about Dominguez; that he had once received bottom marks in a 
Transfiguration test, for instance or had taken up goat charming like Aberforth… 

 Roberto got to his feet and scanned the floor: Perhaps the rest of the letter was here 
somewhere. He seized papers, treating them in his eagerness, with as little consideration 
as the original searcher, he pulled open drawers, shook out books, stood on a chair to run 
his hand over the top of the wardrobe, and crawled under the bed and armchair. 

 At last, lying facedown on the floor, he spotted what looked like a torn piece of 
paper under the chest of drawers. When he pulled it out, it proved to be most of the 
photograph that Sofia had described in her letter. A black-haired baby was zooming in and 
out of the picture on a tiny broom, roaring with laughter, and a pair of legs that must have 
belonged to Ricardo was chasing after him. Roberto tucked the photograph into his pocket 
with Sofia’s letter and continued to look for the second sheet. 

 After another quarter of an hour, however he was forced to conclude that the rest 
of his mother’s letter was gone. Had it simply been lost in the sixteen years that had 
elapsed since it had been written, or had it been taken by whoever had searched the 
room? Roberto read the first sheet again, this time looking for clues as to what might have 
made the second sheet valuable. His toy broomstick could hardly be considered 
interesting to the Death Eaters… The only potentially useful thing he could see her was 
possible information on Dominguez. It seems incredible that Dominguez – what? 

 “Roberto? Roberto? Roberto!” 

“I’m here!” he called, “What’s happened?” 

There was a clatter of footsteps outside the door, and Carolina burst inside. 

“We woke up and didn’t know where you were!” she said breathlessly. She turned 
and shouted over her shoulder, “Diego! I’ve found him” 

Diego’s annoyed voice echoed distantly from several floors below. 

“Good! Tell him from me he’s a git!” 

“Roberto don’t just disappear, please, we were terrified! Why did you come up here 
anyway?” She gazed around the ransacked room. “What have you been doing?” 

“Look what I’ve just found” 

He held out his mother’s letter. Carolina took it out and read it while Roberto 
watched her. When she reached the end of the page she looked up at him. 

“Oh Roberto…” 
“And there’s this too” 

He handed her the torn photograph, and Carolina smiled at the baby zooming in 
and out of sight on the toy broom. 

“I’ve been looking for the rest of the letter,” Roberto said, “but it’s not here.” 

Carolina glanced around. 

“Did you make all this mess, or was some of it done when you got here?” 

“Someone had searched before me,” said Roberto. 


“I thought so. Every room I looked into on the way up had been disturbed. What 
were they after, do you think?” 

“Information on the Order, if it was Peralta.” 

“But you’d think he’d already have all he needed. I mean was in the Order, wasn’t 
he?” 

“Well then,” said Roberto, keen to discuss his theory, “what about information on 
Dominguez? The second page of the letter, for instance. You know this Bathilda my 
mum mentions, you know who she is?” 

“Who?” 

“Bathilda Bagshot, the author of –“ 

“A History of Magic,” said Carolina, looking interested. “So your parents knew 
her? She was an incredible magic historian.” 

“And she’s still alive,” said Roberto, “and she lives in Godric’s Hollow. Diego’s 
Auntie Muriel was talking about her at the wedding. She knew Dominguez’s family too. 
Be pretty interesting to talk to, wouldn’t she?” There was a little too much understanding 
in the smile Carolina gave him for Roberto’s liking. He took back the letter and the 
photograph and tucked them inside the pouch around his neck, so as not to have to look at 
her and give himself away. “I understand why you’d love to talk to her about your mum 
and dad, and Dominguez too,” said Carolina. “But that wouldn’t really help us in our 
search for the Horcruxes, would it?” Roberto did not answer, and she rushed on, “Roberto, I 
know you really want to go to Godric’s Hollow, but I’m scared. I’m scared at how easily 
those Death Eaters found us yesterday. It just makes me feel more than ever that we 
ought to avoid the place where your parents are buried, I’m sure they’d be expecting you 
to visit it.” 

“It’s not just that,” Roberto said, still avoiding looking at her, “Muriel said stuff 
about Dominguez at the wedding. I want to know the truth…” 

 He told Carolina everything that Muriel had told him. When he had finished, 
Carolina said, “Of course, I can see why that’s upset you, Roberto –“ 

 “I’m not upset,” he lied, “I’d just like to know whether or not it’s true or –“ 

 “Roberto do you really think you’ll get the truth from a malicious old woman like 
Muriel, or from Rita Skeeter? How can you believe them? You knew Dominguez!” 

 “I thought I did,” he muttered. 

 “But you know how much truth there was in everything Rita wrote about you! 
Doge is right, how can you let these people tarnish your memories of Dominguez?” 

 He looked away, trying not to betray the resentment he felt. There it was again: 
Paulaose what to believe. He wanted the truth. Why was everybody so determined that he 
should not get it? 

 “Shall we go down to the kitchen?” Carolina suggested after a little pause. “Find 
something for breakfast?” 

 He agreed, but grudgingly, and followed her out onto the landing and past the 
second door that led off it. There were deep scratch marks in the paintwork below a small 
sign that he had not noticed in the dark. He passed at the top of the stairs to read it. It was 
a pompous little sign, neatly lettered by hand the sort of thing that Miguel Lopez might 
have stuck on his bedroom door. 

 

Do Not Enter 


Without the Express Permission of 

Regulus Arcturus Martinez 

 

Excitement trickled through Roberto, but he was not immediately sure why. He read the 
sign again. Carolina was already a flight of stairs below him. 

 “Carolina,” he said, and he was surprised that his voice was so calm. “Come 
back up here.” 

 “What’s the matter?” 

 “R.A.B. I think I’ve found him.” 

 There was a gasp, and then Carolina ran back up the stairs. 

 “In your mum’s letter? But I didn’t see –“ 

 Roberto shook his head, pointing at Regulus’s sign. She read it, then clutched 
Roberto’s arm so tightly that he winced. 

 “Gustavo’s brother?” she whispered. 

 “He was a Death Eater,” said Roberto. “Gustavo told me about him, he joined up when 
he was really young and then got cold feet and tried to leave – so they killed him.” 

 “That fits!” gasped Carolina. “If he was a Death Eater he had access to 
Salvador, and if he became disenchanted, then he would have wanted to bring 
Salvador down!” 

 She released Roberto, leaned over the banister, and screamed, “Diego! DIEGO! Get up 
here, quick!” 

 Diego appeared, panting, a minute later, his wand ready in his hand. 

 “What’s up? If it’s massive spiders again I want breakfast before I –“ 

 He frowned at the sign on Regulus’s door, in which Carolina was silently 
pointing. 

 “What? That was Gustavo’s brother, wasn’t it? Regulus Arcturus … Regulus … 
R.A.B.! The locket – you don’t reckon -- ?” 

 “Let’s find out,” said Roberto. He pushed the door: It was locked. Carolina pointed 
her wand at the handle and said, “Alohamora.” There was a click, and the door swung 
open. 

 They moved over the threshold together, gazing around. Regulus’s bedroom was 
slightly smaller than Gustavo’s, though it had the same sense of former grandeur. Whereas 
Gustavo had sought to advertise his diffidence from the rest of the family, Regulus had 
striven to emphasize the opposite. The Slytherin colors of emerald and silver were 
everywhere, draping the bed, the walls, and the windows. The Martinez family crest was 
painstakingly painted over the bed, along with its motto, TOUJOURS PUR. Beneath this 
was a collection of yellow newspaper cuttings, all stuck together to make a ragged 
collage. Carolina crossed the room to examine them. 

 “They’re all about Salvador,” she said. “Regulus seems to have been a fan for a 
few years before he joined the Death Eaters …” 

 A little puff of dust rose from the bedcovers as she sat down to read the clippings. 
Roberto, meanwhile, had noticed another photograph: a Hogwarts Quidditch team was 
smiling and waving out of the frame. He moved closer and saw the snakes emblazoned 
on their chests: Slytherins. Regulus was instantly recognizable as the boy sitting in the 
middle of the front row: He had the same dark hair and slightly haughty look of his 
brother, though he was smaller, slighter, and rather less handsome than Gustavo had been. 


 “He played Seeker,” said Roberto. 

“What?” said Carolina vaguely; she was still immersed in Salvador’s press 
clippings. 

 “He’s sitting in the middle of the front row, that’s where the Seeker … Never 
mind,” said Roberto, realizing that nobody was listening. Diego was on his hands and knees, 
searching under the wardrobe. Roberto looked around the room for likely hiding places and 
approached the desk. Yet again, somebody had searched before them. The drawers’ 
contents had been turned over recently, the dust disturbed, but there was nothing of value 
there: old quills, out-of-date textbooks that bore evidence of being roughly handled, a 
recently smashed ink bottle, its sticky residue covering the contents of the drawer. 

 “There’s an easier way,” said Carolina, as Roberto wiped his inky fingers on his 
jeans. She raised her wand and said, “Accio Locket!” 

 Nothing happened. Diego, who had been searching the folds of the faded curtains, 
looked disappointed. 

 “Is that it, then? It’s not here?” 

 “Oh, it could still be here, but under counter-enchantments,” said Carolina. 
“Charms to prevent it from being summoned magically, you know.” 

 “Like Salvador put on the stone basin in the cave,” said Roberto, remembering 
how he had been unable to Summon the fake locket. 

 “How are we supposed to find it then?” asked Diego. 

 “We search manually,” said Carolina. 

 “That’s a good idea,” said Diego, rolling his eyes, and he resumed his examination 
of the curtains. 

 They combed every inch of the room for more than an hour, but were forced, 
finally, to conclude that the locket was not there. 

 The sun had risen now; its light dazzled them even through the grimy landing 
windows. 

 “It could be somewhere else in the house, though,” said Carolina in a rallying 
tone as they walked back downstairs. As Roberto and Diego had become more discouraged, 
she seemed to have become more determined. “Whether he’d manage to destroy it or not, 
he’d want to keep it hidden from Salvador, wouldn’t he? Remember all those awful 
things we had to get rid of when we were here last time? That clock that shot bolts at 
everyone and those old robes that tried to strangle Diego; Regulus might have put them 
there to protect the locket’s hiding place, even though we didn’t realize it at … at … “ 

 Roberto and Diego looked at her. She was standing with one foot in midair, with the 
dumbstruck look of one who had just been Obliviated: her eyes had even drifted out of 
focus. 

 “… at the time,” she finished in a whisper. 

 “Something wrong?” asked Diego. 

 “There was a locket.” 

 “What?” said Roberto and Diego together. 

 “In the cabinet in the drawing room. Nobody could open it. And we … we … “ 

 Roberto felt as though a brick had slid down through his chest into his stomach. He 
remembered. He had even handled the thing as they passed it around, each trying in turn 
to pry it open. It had been tossed into a sack of rubbish, along with the snuffbox of 
Wartcap powder and the music box that had made everyone sleepy …” 


 “Kreacher nicked loads of things back from us,” said Roberto. It was the only 
chance, the only slender hope left to them, and he was going to cling to it until forced to 
let go. “He had a whole stash of stuff in his cupboard in the kitchen. C’mon.” 

 He ran down the stairs taking two steps at a time, the other two thundering along 
in his wake. They made so much noise that they woke the portrait of Gustavo’s mother as 
they passed through the hall. 

 “Filth! Mudbloods! Scum!” she screamed after them as they dashed down into the 
basement kitchen and slammed the door behind them. Roberto ran the length of the room, 
skidded to a halt at the door of Kreacher’s cupboard, and wrenched it open. There was the 
nest of dirty old blankets in which the house-elf had once slept, but they were not longer 
glittering with the trinkets Kreacher had salvaged. The only thing there was an old copy 
of Nature’s Nobility: A Wizarding Genealogy. Refusing to believe his eyes, Roberto 
snatched up the blankets and shook them. A dead mouse fell out and rolled dismally 
across the floor. Diego groaned as he threw himself into a kitchen chair; Carolina closed 
her eyes. 

 “It’s not over yet,” said Roberto, and he raised his voice and called, “Kreacher!” 

 There was a loud crack and the house elf that Roberto had so reluctantly inherited 
from Gustavo appeared out of nowhere in front of the cold and empty fireplace: tiny, half 
human-sized, his pale skin hanging off him in folds, white hair sprouting copiously from 
his batlike ears. He was still wearing the filthy rag in which they had first met him, and 
the contemptuous look he bent upon Roberto showed that his attitude to his change of 
ownership had altered no more than his outfit. 

 “Master,” croaked Kreacher in his bullfrog’s voice, and he bowed low; muttering 
to his knees, “back in my Mistress’s old house with the blood-traitor Lopez and the 
Mudblood –“ 

 “I forbid you to call anyone ‘blood traitor’ or ‘Mudblood,’” growled Roberto. He 
would have found Kreacher, with his snoutlike nose and bloodshot eyes, a distinctively 
unlovable object even if the elf had not betrayed Gustavo to Salvador. 

 “I’ve got a question for you,” said Roberto, his heart beating rather fast as he looked 
down at the elf, “and I order you to answer it truthfully. Understand?” 

 “Yes, Master,” said Kreacher, bowing low again. Roberto saw his lips moving 
soundlessly, undoubtedly framing the insults he was now forbidden to utter. 

 “Two years ago,” said Roberto, his heart now hammering against his ribs, “there 
was a big gold locket in the drawing room upstairs. We threw it out. Did you steal it 
back?” 

 There was a moment’s silence, during which Kreacher straightened up to look 
Roberto full in the face. Then he said, “Yes.” 

 “Where is it now?” asked Roberto jubilantly as Diego and Carolina looked gleeful. 

 Kreacher closed his eyes as though he could not bear to see their reactions to his 
next word. 

 “Gone.” 

 “Gone?” echoed Roberto, elation floating out of him, “What do you mean, it’s 
gone?” 

 The elf shivered. He swayed. 

 “Kreacher,” said Roberto fiercely, “I order you –“ 


 “Mundungus Fletcher,” croaked the elf, his eyes still tight shut. “Mundungus 
Fletcher stole it all; Miss Bella’s and Miss Cissy’s pictures, my Mistress’s gloves, the 
Order of Merlin, First Class, the goblets with the family crest, and – and – “ 

 Kreacher was gulping for air: His hollow chest was rising and falling rapidly, then 
his eyes flew open and he uttered a bloodcurdling scream. 

 “—and the locket, Master Regulus’s locket. Kreacher did wrong, Kreacher failed 
in his orders!” 

 Roberto reacted instinctively: As Kreacher lunged for the poker standing in the grate, 
he launched himself upon the elf, flattening him. Carolina’s scream mingled with 
Kreacher’s but Roberto bellowed louder than both of them: “Kreacher, I order you to stay 
still!” 

 He felt the elf freeze and released him. Kreacher lay flat on the cold stone floor, 
tears gushing from his sagging eyes. 

 “Roberto, let him up!” Carolina whispered. 

 “So he can beat himself up with the poker?” snorted Roberto, kneeling beside the elf. 
“I don’t think so. Right. Kreacher, I want the truth: How do you know Mundungus 
Fletcher stole the locket?” 

 “Kreacher saw him!” gasped the elf as tears poured over his snout and into his 
mouth full of graying teeth. “Kreacher saw him coming out of Kreacher’s cupboard with 
his hands full of Kreacher’s treasures. Kreacher told the sneak thief to stop, but 
Mundungus Fletcher laughed and r-ran … “ 

 “You called the locket ‘Master Regulus’s,’” said Roberto. “Why? Where did it 
come from? What did Regulus have to do with it? Kreacher, sit up and tell me everything 
you know about that locket, and everything Regulus had to do with it!” 

 The elf sat up, curled into a ball, placed his wet face between his knees, and began 
to rock backward and forward. When he spoke, his voice was muffled but quite distinct 
in the silent, echoing kitchen. 

 “Master Gustavo ran away, good riddance, for he was a bad boy and broke my 
Mistress’s heart with his lawless ways. But Master Regulus had proper order; he knew 
what was due to the name of Martinez and the dignity of his pure blood. For years he talked 
of the Dark Lord, who was going to bring the wizards out of hiding to rule the Muggles 
and the Muggle-borns … and when he was sixteen years old, Master Regulus joined the 
Dark Lord. So proud, so proud, so happy to serve … 

 And one day, a year after he joined, Master Regulus came down to the kitchen to 
see Kreacher. Master Regulus always liked Kreacher. And Master Regulus said … he 
said …” 

 The old elf rocked faster than ever. 

 “… he said that the Dark Lord required an elf.” 

 “Salvador needed an elf?” Roberto repeated, looking around at Diego and Carolina, 
who looked just as puzzled as he did. 

 “Oh yes,” moaned Kreacher. “And Master Regulus had volunteered Kreacher. It 
was an honor, said Master Regulus, an honor for him and for Kreacher, who must be sure 
to do whatever the Dark Lord ordered him to do … and then to c-come home.” 

 Kreacher rocked still faster, his breath coming in sobs. 


 “So Kreacher went to the Dark Lord. The Dark Lord did not tell Kreacher what 
they were to do, but took Kreacher with him to a cave beside the sea. And beyond the 
cave was a cavern, and in the cavern was a great black lake … “ 

 The hairs on the back of Roberto’s neck stood up. Kreacher’s croaking voice 
seemed to come to him from across the dark water. He saw what had happened as clearly

 “… There was a boat …” 

 Of course there had been a boat; Roberto knew the boat, ghostly green and tiny, 
bewitched so as to carry one wizard and one victim toward the island in the center. This, 
then, was how Salvador had tested the defenses surrounding the Horcrux, by borrowing 
a disposable creature, a house-elf… 

 “There was a b-basin full of potion on the island. The D-Dark Lord made 
Kreacher drink it …” 

 The elf quaked from head to foot. 

 “Kreacher drank, and as he drank he saw terrible thing … Kreacher’s insides 
burned … Kreacher cried for Master Regulus to save him, he cried for his Mistress Martinez, 
but the Dark Lord only laughed … He made Kreacher drink all the potion … He dropped 
a locket into the empty basin … He filled it with more potion.” 

 “And then the Dark Lord sailed away, leaving Kreacher on the island … “ 

 Roberto could see it happening. He watched Salvador’s white, snakelike face 
vanishing into darkness, those red eyes fixed pitilessly on the thrashing elf whose death 
would occur within minutes, whenever he succumbed to the desperate thirst that the 
burning poison caused its victim … But here, Roberto’s imagination could go no further, 
for he could not see how Kreacher had escaped. 

 “Kreacher needed water, he crawled to the island’s edge and he drank from the 
black lake … and hands, dead hands, came out of the water and dragged Kreacher under 
the surface … “ 

 “How did you get away?” Roberto asked, and he was not surprised to hear himself 
whispering. 

 Kreacher raised his ugly head and looked Roberto with his great, bloodshot eyes. 

 “Master Regulus told Kreacher to come back,” he said. 

 “I know – but how did you escape the Inferi?” 

 Kreacher did not seem to understand. 

 “Master Regulus told Kreacher to come back,” he repeated. 

 “I know, but – “ 

 “Well, it’s obvious, isn’t it, Roberto?” said Diego. “He Disapparated!” 

 “But … you couldn’t Apparate in and out of that cave,” said Roberto, “otherwise 
Dominguez – “ 

 “Elf magic isn’t like wizard’s magic, is it?” said Diego, “I mean, they can Apparate 
and Disapparate in and out of Hogwarts when we can’t.” 

 There was a silence as Roberto digested this. How could Salvador have made such 
a mistake? But even as he thought this, Carolina spoke, and her voice was icy. 

 “Of course, Salvador would have considered the ways of house-elves far 
beneath his notice … It would never have occurred to him that they might have magic 
that he didn’t.” 


 “The house-elf’s highest law is his Master’s bidding,” intoned Kreacher. 
“Kreacher was told to come home, so Kreacher came home … “ 

 “Well, then, you did what you were told, didn’t you?” said Carolina kindly. 
“You didn’t disobey orders at all!” 

 Kreacher shook his head, rocking as fast as ever. 

 “So what happened when you got back?” Roberto asked. “What did Regulus say

 “Master Regulus was very worried, very worried,” croaked Kreacher. “Master 
Regulus told Kreacher to stay hidden and not to leave the house. And then … it was a 
little while later … Master Regulus came to find Kreacher in his cupboard one night, and 
Master Regulus was strange, not as he usually was, disturbed in his mind, Kreacher could 
tell … and he asked Kreacher to take him to the cave, the cave where Kreacher had gone 
with the Dark Lord … “ 

 And so they had set off. Roberto could visualize them quite clearly, the frightened 
old elf and the thin, dark Seeker who had so resembled Gustavo … Kreacher knew how to 
open the concealed entrance to the underground cavern, knew how to raise the tiny boat: 
this time it was his beloved Regulus who sailed with him to the island with its basin of 
poison … 

 “And he made you drink the poison?” said Roberto, disgusted. 

 But Kreacher shook his head and wept. Carolina’s hands leapt to her mouth: She 
seemed to have understood something. 

 “M-Master Regulus took from his pocket a locket like the one the Dark Lord 
had,” said Kreacher, tears pouring down either side of his snoutlike nose. “And he told 
Kreacher to take it and, when the basin was empty, to switch the lockets …” 

 Kreacher’s sobs came in great rasps now; Roberto had to concentrate hard to 
understand him. 

 “And he order – Kreacher to leave – without him. And he told Kreacher – to go 
home – and never to tell my Mistress – what he had done – but to destroy – the first 
locket. And he drank – all the potion – and Kreacher swapped the lockets – and watched

 “Oh, Kreacher!” wailed Carolina, who was crying. She dropped to her knees

quite obviously repulsed. 

 “The Mudblood touched Kreacher, he will not allow it, what would his Mistress 
say?” 

 “I told you not to call her ‘Mudblood’!” snarled Roberto, but the elf was already 
punishing himself. He fell to the ground and banged his forehead on the floor. 

 “Stop him – stop him!” Carolina cried. “Oh, don’t you see now how sick it is, 
the way they’ve got to obey?” 

 “Kreacher – stop, stop!” shouted Roberto. 

 The elf lay on the floor, panting and shivering, green mucus glistening around his 
snot, a bruise already blooming on his pallid forehead where he had struck himself, his 
eyes swollen and bloodshot and swimming in tears. Roberto had never seen anything so 
pitiful. 

 “So you brought the locket home,” he said relentlessly, for he was determined to 
know the full story. “And you tried to destroy it?” 


 “Nothing Kreacher did made any mark upon it,” moaned the elf. “Kreacher tried 
everything, everything he knew, but nothing, nothing would work … So many powerful 
spells upon the casing, Kreacher was sure the way to destroy it was to get inside it, but it 
would not open … Kreacher punished himself, he tried again, he punished himself, he 
tried again. Kreacher failed to obey orders, Kreacher could not destroy the locket! And 
his mistress was mad with grief, because Master Regulus had disappeared and Kreacher 
could not tell her what had happened, no, because Master Regulus had f-f-forbidden him 
to tell any of the f-f-family what happened in the c-cave …” 

 Kreacher began to sob so hard that there were no more coherent words. Tears 
flowed down Carolina’s cheeks as she watched Kreacher, but she did not dare touch 
him again. Even Diego, who was no fan of Kreacher’s, looked troubled. Roberto sat back on 
his heels and shook his head, trying to clear it. 

 “I don’t understand you, Kreacher,” he said finally. “Salvador tried to kill you, 
Regulus died to bring Salvador down, but you were still happy to betray Gustavo to 
Salvador? You were happy to go to Julia and Miranda, and pass information to 
Salvador through them … “ 

 “Roberto, Kreacher doesn’t think like that,” said Carolina, wiping her eyes on the 
back of her hand. “He’s a slave; house-elves are used to bad, even brutal treatment; what 
Salvador did to Kreacher wasn’t that far out of the common way. What do wizard wars 
mean to an elf like Kreacher? He’s loyal to people who are kind to him, and Mrs. Martinez 
must have been, and Regulus certainly was, so he served them willingly and parroted 
their beliefs. I know what you’re going to say,” she went on as Roberto began to protest, 
“that Regulus changed his mind … but he doesn’t seem to have explained that to 
Kreacher, does he?” And I think I know why. Kreacher and Regulus’s family were all 
safest if they kept to the old pure-blood line. Regulus was trying to protect them all.” 

 “Gustavo – “ 

 “Gustavo was horrible to Kreacher, Roberto, and it’s no good looking like that, you 
know it’s true. Kreacher had been alone for such a long time when Gustavo came to live 
here, and he was probably starving for a bit of affection. I’m sure ‘Miss Cissy’ and ‘Miss 
Bella’ were perfectly lovely to Kreacher when he turned up, so he did them a favor and 
told them everything they wanted to know. I’ve said all along that wizards would pay for 
how they treat house-elves. Well, Salvador did … and so did Gustavo.” 

 Roberto had no retort. As he watched Kreacher sobbing on the floor, he 
remembered what Dominguez had said to him, mere hours after Gustavo’s death: I do not 
think Gustavo ever saw Kreacher as a being with feelings as acute as a human’s … 

 “Kreacher,” said Roberto after a while, “when you feel up to it, er … please sit up.” 

 It was several minutes before Kreacher hiccupped himself into silence. Then he 
pushed himself into a sitting position again, rubbing his knuckles into his eyes like a 
small child. 

 “Kreacher, I am going to ask you to do something,” said Roberto. He glanced at 
Carolina for assistance. He wanted to give the order kindly, but at the same time, he 
could not pretend that it was not an order. However, the change in his tone seemed to 
have gained her approval: She smiled encouragingly. 

 “Kreacher, I want you, please, to go and find Mundungus Fletcher. We need to 
find out where the locket – where Master Regulus’s locket it. It’s really important. We 


want to finish the work Master Regulus started, we want to – er – ensure that he didn’t 
die in vain.” 

 Kreacher dropped his fists and looked up at Roberto. 

 “Find Mundungus Fletcher?” he croaked. 

 And bring him here, to Grimmauld Place,” said Roberto. “Do you think you could 
do that for us?” 

 As Kreacher nodded and got to his feet, Roberto had a sudden inspiration. He pulled 
out Villalba’s purse and took out the fake Horcrux, the substitute locket in which Regulus 
had placed the note to Salvador. 

 “Kreacher, I’d, er, like you to have this,” he said, pressing the locket into the elf’s 
hand. “This belonged to Regulus and I’m sure he’d want you to have it as a token of 
gratitude for what you—“ 

 “Overkill, mate,” said Diego as the elf took one look at the locket, let out a howl of 
shock and misery, and threw himself back onto the ground. 

 It took them nearly half an hour to calm down Kreacher, who was so overcome to 
be presented with a Martinez family heirloom for his very own that he was too weak at the 
knees to stand properly. When finally he was able to totter a few steps they all 
accompanied him to his cupboard, watched him tuck up the locket safely in his dirty 
blankets, and assured him that they would make its protection their first priority while he 
was away. He then made two low bows to Roberto and Diego, and even gave a funny little 
spasm in Carolina’s direction that might have been an attempt at a respectful salute, 
before Disapparating with the usual loud crack. 

 

Chapter Eleven 

The Bribe 

 

If Kreacher could escape a lake full of Inferi, Roberto was confident that the capture 
of Mundungus would take a few hours at most, and he prowled the house all morning in a 
state of high anticipation. However, Kreacher did not return that morning or even that 
afternoon. By nightfall, Roberto felt discouraged and anxious, and a supper composed 
largely of moldy bread, upon which Carolina had tried a variety of unsuccessful 
Transfigurations, did nothing to help. 

Kreacher did not return the following day, nor the day after that. However, two 
cloaked men had appeared in the square outside number twelve, and they remained there 
into the night, gazing in the direction of the house that they could not see. 

“Death Eaters, for sure,” said Diego, as he, Roberto, and Carolina watched from the 
drawing room windows. “Reckon they know we’re in here?” 

“I don’t think so,” said Carolina, though she looked frightened, “or they’d have 
sent Peralta in after us, wouldn’t they?” 

“D’you reckon he’s been in here and has his tongue tied by Acosta’s curse?” 
asked Diego. 

“Yes,” said Carolina, “otherwise he’d have been able to tell that lot how to get in, 
wouldn’t he? But they’re probably watching to see whether we turn up. They know that 
Roberto owns the house, after all.” 


“How do they --?” began Roberto. 

“Wizarding wills are examined by the Ministry, remember? They’ll know Gustavo 
left you the place.” 

The presence of the Death Eaters outside increased the ominous mood inside 
number twelve. They had not heard a word form anyone beyond Grimmauld Place since 
Mr. Lopez’s Patronus, and the strain was starting to tell. Restless and irritable, Diego had 
developed an annoying habit of playing with the Deluminator in his pocket; This 
particularly infuriated Carolina, who was whiling away the wait for Kreacher by 
studying The Tales of Beedle the Bard and did not appreciate the way the lights kept 
flashing on and off. 

“Will you stop it!” she cried on the third evening of Kreacher’s absence, as all the 
light was sucked from the drawing room yet again. 

“Sorry, sorry!” said Diego, clicking the Deluminator and restoring the lights. “I 
don’t know I’m doing it!” 

“Well, can’t you find something useful to occupy yourself?” 

“What, like reading kids’ stories?” 

“Dominguez left me this book, Diego –” 

“—and he left me the Deluminator, maybe I’m supposed to use it!” 

Unable to stand the bickering, Roberto slipped out of the room unnoticed by either 
of them. He headed downstairs toward the kitchen, which he kept visiting because he was 
sure that was where Kreacher was most likely to reappear. Halfway down the flight of 
stairs into the hall, however, he heard a tap on the front door, then metallic clicks and the 
grinding of the chain. 

Every nerve in his body seemed to tauten: He pulled out his wand, moved into the 
shadows beside the decapitated elf heads, and waited. The door opened: He saw a 
glimpse of the lamplit square outside, and a cloaked figure edged into the hall and closed 
the door behind it. The intruder took a step forward, and Acosta’s voice asked, “Carlos 
Peralta?” Then the dust figure rose from the end of the hall and rushed him, raising its 
dead hand. 

“It was not I who killed you, Alfonso,” said a quiet voice. 

The jinx broke: The dust-figure exploded again, and it was impossible to make 
out the newcomer through the dense gray cloud it left behind. 

Roberto pointed the wand into the middle of it. 

“Don’t move!” 

He had forgotten the portrait of Mrs. Martinez: At the sound of his yell, the curtains 
hiding her flew open and she began to scream, “Mudbloods and filth dishonoring my 
house –” 

Diego and Carolina came crashing down the stairs behind Roberto, wands pointing, 
like his, at the unknown man now standing with his arms raised in the hall below. 

“Hold your fire, it’s me, Pedro!” 

“Oh, thank goodness,” said Carolina weakly, pointing her wand at Mrs. Martinez 
instead; with a bang, the curtains swished shut again and silence fell. Diego too lowered his 
wand, but Roberto did not. 

“Show yourself!” he called back. 

Cardozo moved forward into the lamplight, hands still held high in a gesture of 
surrender. 


“I am Pedro John Cardozo, werewolf, sometimes known as Moony, one of the four 
creators of the Marauder’s Map, married to Viviana, usually known as Perez, and I 
taught you how to produce a Patronus, Roberto, which takes the form of a stag.” 

“Oh, all right,” said Roberto, lowering his wand, “but I had to check, didn’t I?” 

“Speaking as your ex-Defense Against the Dark Arts teacher, I quite agree that 
you had to check. Diego, Carolina, you shouldn’t be so quick to lower your defenses.” 

They ran down the stairs towards him. Wrapped in a thick black traveling cloak, 
he looked exhausted, but pleased to see them. 

“No sign of Carlos, then?” he asked. 

“No,” said Roberto. “What’s going on? Is everyone okay?’ 

“Yes,” said Cardozo, “but we’re all being watched. There are a couple of Death 
Eaters in the square outside –” 

“We know –” 

“I had to Apparate very precisely onto the top step outside the front door to be 
sure that they would not see me. They can’t know you’re in here or I’m sure they’d have 
more people out there; they’re staking out everywhere that’s got any connection with you, 
Roberto. Let’s go downstairs, there’s a lot to tell you, and I want to know what happened 
after you left the Burrow.” 

They descended into the kitchen, where Carolina pointed her wand at the grate. 
A fire sprang up instantly: It gave the illusion of coziness to the stark stone walls and 
glistened off the long wooden table. Cardozo pulled a few butterbeers from beneath his 
traveling cloak and they sat down. 

“I’d have been here three days ago but I needed to shake off the Death Eater 
tailing me,” said Cardozo. “So, you came straight here after the wedding?” 

“No,” said Roberto, “only after we ran into a couple of Death Eaters in a café on 
Tottenham Court Road.” 

Cardozo slopped most of his butterbeer down his front. 

“What?” 

They explained what had happened; when they had finished, Cardozo looked aghast. 

“But how did they find you so quickly? It’s impossible to track anyone who 
Apparates, unless you grab hold of them as they disappear.” 

“And it doesn’t seem likely they were just strolling down Tottenham Court Road 
at the time, does it?” said Roberto. 

“We wondered,” said Carolina tentatively, “whether Roberto could still have the 
Trace on him?” 

“Impossible,” said Cardozo. Diego looked smug, and Roberto felt hugely relieved. 
“Apart from anything else, they’d know for sure Roberto was here if he still had the Trace 
on him, wouldn’t they? But I can’t see how they could have tracked you to Tottenham 
Court Road, that’s worrying, really worrying.” 

He looked disturbed, but as far as Roberto was concerned, that question could wait. 

“Tell us what happened after we left, we haven’t heard a thing since Diego’s dad 
told us the family was safe.” 

“Well, Hector saved us,” said Cardozo. “Thanks to his warning most of the 
wedding guests were able to Disapparate before they arrived.” 

“Were they Death Eaters or Ministry people?” interjected Carolina. 


“A mixture; but to all intents and purposes they’re the same thing now,” said 
Cardozo. “There were about a dozen of them, but they didn’t know you were there, Roberto. 
Raul heard a rumor that they tried to torture your whereabouts out of Scrimgeour before 
they killed him; if it’s true, he didn’t give you away.” 

Roberto looked at Diego and Carolina; their expressions reflected the mingled shock 
and gratitude he felt. He had never liked Scrimgeour much, but if what Cardozo said was 
true, the man’s final act had been to try to protect Roberto. 

“The Death Eaters searched the Burrow from top to bottom,” Cardozo went on. 
“They found the ghoul, but didn’t want to get too close – and then they interrogated those 
of us who remained for hours. They were trying to get information on you, Roberto, but of 
course nobody apart from the Order knew that you had been there. 

“At the same time that they were smashing up the wedding, more Death Eaters 
were forcing their way into every Order-connected house in the country. No deaths,” he 
added quickly, forestalling the question, “but they were rough. They burned down 
Dedalus Diggle’s house, but as you know he wasn’t there, and they used the Cruciarus 
Curse on Perez’s family. Again, trying to find out where you went after you visited them. 
They’re all right – shaken, obviously, but otherwise okay.” 

“The Death Eaters got through all those protective charms?” 

Roberto asked, remembering how effective these had been on the night he had 
crashed in Perez’s parents’ garden. 

“What you’ve got to realize, Roberto, is that the Death Eaters have got the full 
might of the Ministry on their side now,” said Cardozo. “They’ve got the power to perform 
brutal spells without fear of identification or arrest. They managed to penetrate every 
defensive spell we’d cast against them, and once inside, they were completely open about 
why they’d come.” 

“And are they bothering to give an excuse for torturing Roberto’s whereabouts out 
of people?” asked Carolina, an edge to her voice. 

“Well,” Cardozo said. He hesitated, then pulled out a folded copy of the Daily 
Prophet. 

“Here,” he said, pushing it across the table to Roberto, “you’ll know sooner or later 
anyway. That’s their pretext for going after you.” 

Roberto smoothed out the paper. A huge photograph of his own face filled the front 
page. He read the headline over it: 

 

 WANTED FOR QUESTIONING ABOUT 

 THE DEATH OF ALFONSO DOMINGUEZ 

 

Diego and Carolina gave roars of outrage, but Roberto said nothing. He pushed the 
newspaper away; he did not want to read anymore: He knew what it would say. Nobody 
but those who had been on top of the tower when Dominguez died knew who had really 
killed him and, as Rita Skeeter had already told the Wizarding world, Roberto had been 
seen running from the place moments after Dominguez had fallen. 

“I’m sorry, Roberto,” Cardozo said. 

“So Death Eaters have taken over the Daily Prophet too?” asked Carolina 
furiously. 

Cardozo nodded. 


“But surely people realize what’s going on?” 

“The coup has been smooth and virtually silent,” said Cardozo. 

“The official version of Scrimgeour’s murder is that he resigned; he has been 
replaced by Pius Thicknesse, who is under the Imperius Curse.” 

“Why didn’t Salvador declare himself Minister of Magic?” asked Diego. 

Cardozo laughed. 

“He doesn’t need to, Diego. Effectively, he is the Minister, but why should he sit 
behind a desk at the Ministry? His puppet, Thicknesse, is taking care of everyday 
business, leaving Salvador free to extend his power beyond the Ministry. 

“Naturally many people have deduced what has happened: There has been such a 
dramatic change in Ministry policy in the last few days, and many are whispering that 
Salvador must be behind it. However, that is the point: They whisper. They daren’t 
confide in each other, not knowing whom to trust; they are scared to speak out, in case 
their suspicions are true and their families are targeted. Yes, Salvador is playing a very 
clever game. Declaring himself might have provoked open rebellion: Remaining masked 
has created confusion, uncertainty, and fear.” 

“And this dramatic change in Ministry policy,” said Roberto, “involves warning the 
Wizarding world against me instead of Salvador?” 

“That’s certainly a part of it,” said Cardozo, “and it is a masterstroke. Now that 
Dominguez is dead, you – the Boy Who Lived – were sure to be the symbol and rallying 
point for any resistance to Salvador. But by suggesting that you had a hand in the old 
hat’s death, Salvador has not only set a price upon your head, but sown doubt and fear 
amongst many who would have defended you. 

“Meanwhile, the Ministry has started moving against Muggle-borns.” 

Cardozo pointed at the Daily Prophet. 

“Look at page two.” 

Carolina turned the pages with much the same expression of distaste she had 
when handling Secrets of the Darkest Art. 

“Muggle-born Register!” she read aloud. “‘The Ministry of Magic is undertaking
