"But you have been misleading me, young woman!" said Xenophilius, now sitting

Hallows Quest! Many of us Questers believe that the Peverells have everything – 
everything! – to do with the Hallows!" 

"Who are the Peverells?" asked Diego. 

"That was the name on the grave with the mark on it, in Godric's Hollow," said

"Exactly!" said Xenophilius, his forefinger raised pedantically. "The sign of the 
Death Hallows on Ignotus's grave is conclusive proof!" 

"Of what?" asked Diego. 

"Why, that the three brothers in the story were actually the three Peverell brothers, 
Antioch, Cadmus and Ignotus! That they were the original owners of the Hallows!" 

With another glance at the window he got to his feet, picked up the tray, and 
headed for the spiral staircase. 

"You will stay for dinner?" he called, as he vanished downstairs again. 
"Everybody always requests our recipe for Freshwater Plimply soup." 


"Probably to show the Poisoning Department at St. Mungo's," said Diego under his

"One of those superstitions, isn't it? 'May-born witches will marry Muggles.' 'Jinx 
by twilight, undone by midnight.' 'Wand of cider, never prosper.' You must have heard

"Roberto and I were raised by Muggles," Carolina reminded him. "We were taught

The three of them spoke at the same time: Carolina said, "the Cloak," Diego said,

-Yes, but could you keep your trap shut?" said Carolina, looking skeptical. "You know

Carolina looked exasperated: The expression was so endearingly familiar that Roberto and

bigger and better than other people's" 


"But how do you know," said Roberto, "that those wants -- the Deathstick, and the Wand of

Roberto laughed: The strange idea that had occurred to him was after all, ridiculous. His

The smell from the kitchen was getting stronger. It was something like burning

As they argued in whispers, Roberto moved around the room, only half listening. Reaching

Roberto felt a great rush of affection for Gabriela. He looked around the room. There was a

around. Something was wrong. The pale blue carpet was also thick with dust. There were

Chapter Twenty-Two 

The Deathly Hallows 

 

 Roberto fell, panting, onto grass and scrambled up at once. They seemed to have 
landed in the corner of a field at dusk; Carolina was already running in a circle around 
them, waving her wand. 

 “Protego Totalum…Salvio Hexia…” 

 “That treacherous old bleeder.” Diego panted, emerging from beneath the 
Invisibility Cloak and throwing it to Roberto. “Carolina you’re a genius, a total genius. I 
can’t believe we got out of that.” 

 “Cave Inimicum…Didn’t I say it was an Frumpent horn, didn’t I tell him? And 
now his house has been blown apart!” 

 “Serves him right,” said Diego, examining his torn jeans and the cuts to his legs, 
“What’d you reckon they’ll do to him?” 

 “Oh I hope they don’t kill him!” groaned Carolina, “That’s why I wanted the 
Death Eaters to get a glimpse of Roberto before we left, so they knew Xenophilius hadn’t 
been lying!” 


 “Why hide me though?” asked Diego. 

 “You’re supposed to be in bed with spattergrolt, Diego! They’ve kidnapped Gabriela 
because her father supported Roberto! What would happen to your family if they knew 
you’re with him?” 

 “But what about your mum and dad?” 

 “They’re in Australia,” said Carolina, “They should be all right. They don’t 
know anything.” 

“You’re a genius,” Diego repeated, looking awed. 

Yeah, you are, Carolina,” agreed Roberto fervently. “I don’t know what we’d do 
without you.” 

She beamed, but became solemn at once. 

“What about Gabriela?” 

“Well, if they’re telling the truth and she’s still Alive ---“ began Diego. 

“Don’t say that, don’t say it!” squealed Carolina. “She must be alive, she must!” 

“Then she’ll be in Azkaban, I expect,” said Diego. “Whether she survives the place, 
though…Loads don’t…” 

“She will,” said Roberto. He could not bear to contemplate the alternative. “She’s 
tough, Gabriela, much tougher than you’d think. She’s probably teaching all the inmates 
about Wrackspurts and Nargles.” 

“I hope you’re right,” said Carolina. She passed a hand over her eyes. “I’d feel 
so sorry for Xenophilius if ---“ 

“---if he hadn’t just tried to sell us to the Death Eaters, yeah,” said Diego. 

They put up the tent and retreated inside it, where Diego made them tea. After their 
narrow escape, the chilly, musty old place felt like home: safe, familiar, and friendly. 

“Oh, why did we go there?” groaned Carolina after a few minutes’ silence. 
“Roberto, you were right, it was Godric’s Hollow all over again, a complete waste of time! 
The Deathly Hallows…such rubbish…although actually,” a sudden thought seemed to 
have struck her, “he might have made it all up, mightn’t he? He probably doesn’t believe 
in the Deathly Hallows at all, he just wanted to keep us talking until the Death Eaters 
arrived!” 

“I don’t think so,” said Diego. “It’s a damn sight harder making stuff up when 
you’re under stress than you’d think. I found that out when the Snatchers caught me. It 
was much easier pretending to be Stan, because I knew a bit about him, than inventing a 
whole new person. Old Ortiz was under loads of pressure, trying to make sure we 
stayed put. I reckon he told us the truth, or what he thinks is the truth, just to keep us 
talking.” 

“Well, I don’t suppose it matters,” sighed Carolina. “Even if he was being 
honest, I never heard such a lot of nonsense in all my life.” 

“Hang on, though,” said Diego. “The Chamber of Secrets was supposed to be a 
myth, wasn’t it?” 

“But the Deathly Hallows can’t exist, Diego!” 

“You keep saying that, but one of them can,” said Diego. “Roberto’s Invisibility 
Cloak ---“ 

“The Tale of the Three Brothers’ is a story,” said Carolina firmly. “A story about 
how humans are frightened of death. If surviving was as simple as hiding under the 
Invisibility Cloak, we’d have everything we need already!” 


“I don’t know. We could do with an unbeatable wand,” said Roberto, turning the 
blackthorn wand he so disliked over in his fingers. 

“There’s no such thing, Roberto!” 

“You said there have been loads of wands --- the Deathstick and whatever they 
were called ---“ 

“All right, even if you want to kid yourself the Elder Wand’s real, what about the 
Resurrection Stone?” Her fingers sketched quotation marks around the name, and her 
tone dripped sarcasm. “No magic can raise the dead, and that’s that!” 

“When my wand connected with You-Know-Who’s, it made my mum and dad 
appear…and Nicolas…” 

“But they weren’t really back from the dead, were they?” said Carolina. “Those

“But she, the girl in the tale, didn’t really come back, did she? The story says that 
once people are dead, they belong with the dead. But the second brother still got to see

He saw concern and something less easily definable in Carolina’s expression. 
Then, as she glanced at Diego, Roberto realized that it was fear: He had scared her with his

“So that Peverell bloke who’s buried in Godric’s Hollow,” he said hastily, trying

‘Peverell’ Is Nature’s Nobility: A Wizarding Genealogy. I borrowed it from Kreacher,” 
she explained as Diego raised his eyebrows. “It lists the pure-blood families that are now 
extinct in the male line. Apparently the Peverells were one of the earliest families to 
vanish.” 

“Extinct in the male line?” repeated Diego. 

“It means the name died out,” said Carolina, “centuries ago, in the case of the 
Peverells. They could still have descendents, though, they’d just be called something 
different.” 

And then it came to Roberto in one shining piece, the memory that had stirred at the 
sound of the name “Peverell”: a filthy old man brandishing an ugly ring in the face of a 
Ministry official, and he cried aloud, “Marvolo Gaunt!” 

“Sorry said Diego and Carolina together. 

“Marvolo Gaunt! You-Know-Who’s grandfather! In the Pensieve! With 
Dominguez! Marvolo Gaunt said he was descended from the Peverells!” 

Diego and Carolina looked bewildered. 

“The ring, the ring that became the Horcrux, Marvolo Gaunt said it had the

nearly shoved it up his nose!” 

“The Peverell coat of arms?” said Carolina sharply. “Could you see what it 
looked like?” 

“Not really,” said Roberto, trying to remember. “There was nothing fancy on there, 
as far as I could see; maybe a few scratches. I only ever saw it really close up after it had 
been cracked open.” 


Roberto saw Carolina’s comprehension in the sudden widening of her eyes. Diego 
was looking from one to the other, astonished. 

“Blimey…You reckon it was this sign again? The sign of the Hallows? 

“Why not said Roberto excitedly, “Marvolo Gaunt was an ignorant old git who lived

the centuries, he might not have known what it really was. There were no books in that

think the scratches on the stone were a coat of arms, because as far as he was concerned, 
having pure blood made you practically royal.” 

“Yes…and that’s all very interesting,” said Carolina cautiously, “but Roberto, if

“Well, why not? Why not? said Roberto, abandoning caution. “It was a stone,

Diego’s mouth fell open. 

“Blimey --- but would it still work if Dominguez broke --- ?”

Carolina leapt to her feet, looking exasperated and angry. Roberto you’re trying to

“A minute ago you told us you never saw the mark on the stone properly!” 

“Where’d you reckon the ring is now?” Diego asked Roberto. “What did Dominguez

“But Roberto’s imagination was racing ahead, far beyond Diego and Carolina’s… 

Three objects, or Hallows, which, if united, will make the possessor master of 
Death…Master…Conqueror…Vanquisher…The last enemy that shall be destroyed is 
death… 

And he saw himself, possessor of the Hallows, facing Salvador, whose 
Horcruxes were no match…Neither can live while the other survives…Was this the 
answer? Hallows versus Horcruxes? Was there a way after all, to ensure that he was the 
one who triumphed? If he were the master of the Deathly Hallows, would he be safe? 

“Roberto?” 

But he scarcely heard Carolina: He had pulled out his Invisibility Cloak and was 
running it through his fingers, the cloth supple as water, light as air. He had never seen 
anything to equal it in his nearly seven years in the Wizarding world. The Cloak was 
exactly what Xenophilius had described: A cloak that really and truly renders the wearer 
completely invisible, and endures eternally, giving constant and impenetrable 
concealment, no matter what spells are cast at it… 

And then, with a gasp, he remembered— 

“Dominguez had my Cloak the night my parents died!” 

His voice shook and he could feel the color in his face, but he did not care. 

“My mum told Gustavo that Dominguez borrowed the Cloak! This is why! He 
wanted to examine it, because he thought it was the third Hallow! Ignotus Peverell is 
buried in Godric’s Hollow…” Roberto was walking blindly around the tent, feeling as 


though great new vistas of truth were opening all around him. “He’s my ancestor. I’m 
descended from the third brother! It all makes sense!” 

“He felt armed in certainty, in his belief in the Hallows, as if the mere idea of 
possessing them was giving him protection, and he felt joyous as he turned back to the 
other two. 

“Roberto,” said Carolina again, but he was busy undoing the pouch around his 
neck, his fingers shaking hard. 

“Read it,” he told her, pushing his mother’s letter into her hand. “Read it! 
Dominguez had the Cloak, Carolina! Why else would he want it? He didn’t need a 
Cloak, he could perform a Disillusionment Charm so powerful that he made himself 
completely invisible without one!” 

Something fell to the floor and rolled, glittering, under a chair: He had dislodged 
the Snitch when he pulled out the letter. He stooped to pick it up, and then the newly 
tapped spring of fabulous discoveries threw him another gift, and shock and wonder 
erupted inside him so that he shouted out. 

“IT’S IN HERE! He left me the ring – it’s in the Snitch!” 

“You --- you reckon?” 

He could not understand why Diego looked taken aback. It was so obvious, so clear 
to Roberto. Everything fit, everything…His Cloak was the third Hallow, and when he 
discovered how to open the Snitch he would have the second, and then all he needed to 
do was find the first Hallow, the Elder Wand, and then --- 

But it was as though a curtain fell on a lit stage: All his excitement, all his hope 
and happiness were extinguished at a stroke, and he stood alone in the darkness, and the 
glorious spell was broken. 

“That’s what he’s after.” 

The change in his voice made Diego and Carolina look even more scared. 

“You-Know-Who’s after the Elder Wand.” 

He turned his back on their strained, incredulous faces. He knew it was the truth. 
It all made sense, Salvador was not seeking a new wand; he was seeking an old wand, a 
very old wand indeed. Roberto walked to the entrance of the tent, forgetting about Diego and 
Carolina as he looked out into the night, thinking… 

Salvador had been raised in a Muggle orphanage. Nobody could have told him 
The Tales of Beedle the Bard when he was a child, any more than Roberto had heard them. 
Hardly any wizards believed in the Deathly Hallows. Was it likely that Salvador knew 
about them? 

Roberto gazed into the darkness…If Salvador had known about the Deathly 
Hallows, surely he would have sought them, done anything to possess them: three objects 
that made the possessor master of Death? If he had known about the Deathly Hallows, he 
might not have needed Horcruxes in the first place. Didn’t the simple fact that he had 
taken a Hallow, and turned it into a Horcrux, demonstrate that he did not know this last 
great Wizarding secret? 

Which meant that Salvador sought the Elder Wand without realizing its full 
power, without understanding that it was one of three…for the wand was the Hallow that 
could not be hidden, whose existence was best known…The bloody trail of the Elder 
Wand is splattered across the pages of Wizarding history… 


Roberto watched the cloudy sky, curves of smoke-gray and silver sliding over the 
face of the white moon. He felt lightheaded with amazement at his discoveries. 

He turned back into the tent. It was a shock to see Diego and Carolina standing 
exactly where he had left them, Carolina still holding Sofia’s letter, Diego at her side 
looking slightly anxious. Didn’t they realize how far they had traveled in the last few 
minutes? 

“This is it?” Roberto said, trying to bring them inside the glow of his own 
astonished certainty, “This explains everything. The Deathly Hallows are real and I’ve 
got one --- maybe two ---“ 

He held up the Snitch. 

“--- and You-Know-Who’s chasing the third, but he doesn’t realize…he just 
thinks it’s a powerful wand ---“ 

“Roberto,” said Carolina, moving across to him and handing him back Sofia’s letter, 
“I’m sorry, but I think you’ve got this wrong, all wrong.” 

“But don’t you see? It all fits ---“ 

“Not, it doesn’t,” she said. “It doesn’t. Roberto, you’re just getting carried away. 
Please,” she said as she started to speak, “please just answer me this: If the Deathly 
Hallows really existed, and Dominguez knew about them, knew that the person who 
possessed all of them would be master of Death --- Roberto, why wouldn’t he have told 
you? Why?” 

He had his answer ready. 

“But you said it, Carolina! You’ve got to find out about them for yourself! It’s a 
Quest!” 

“But I only said that to try and persuade you to come to the Ortizs’!” cried 
Carolina in exasperation. “I didn’t really believe it!” 

Roberto took no notice. 

“Dominguez usually let me find out stuff for myself. He let me try my strength, 
take risks. This feels like the kind of thing he’d do.” 

“Roberto, this isn’t a game, this isn’t practice! This is the real thing, and 
Dominguez left you very clear instructions: Find and destroy the Horcruxes! That 
symbol doesn’t mean anything, forget the Deathly Hallows, we can’t afford to get 
sidetracked ---“ 

Roberto was barely listening to her. He was turning the Snitch over and over in his 
hands, half expecting it to break open, to reveal the Resurrection Stone, to prove to 
Carolina that he was right, that the Deathly Hallows were real. 

She appealed to Diego. 

“You don’t believe in this, do you?” 

Roberto looked up, Diego hesitated. 

“I dunno…I mean…bits of it sort of fit together,” said Diego awkwardly, “But 
when you look at the whole thing…” He took a deep breath. “I think we’re supposed to 
get rid of Horcruxes, Roberto. That’s what Dominguez told us to do. Maybe…maybe we 
should forget about this Hallows business.” 

“Thank you, Diego,” said Carolina. “I’ll take first watch.” 

And she strode past Roberto and sat down in the tent entrance bringing the action to 
a fierce full stop. 


But Roberto hardly slept that night. The idea of the Deathly Hallows had taken 
possession of him, and he could not rest while agitating thoughts whirled through his 
mind: the wand, the stone, and the Cloak, if he could just possess them all… 

I open at the close…But what was the close? Why couldn’t he have the stone 
now? If only he had the stone, he could ask Dominguez these questions in person…and 
Roberto murmured words to the Snitch in the darkness, trying everything, even 
Parseltongue, but the golden ball would not open… 

And the wand, the Elder Wand, where was that hidden? Where was Salvador 
searching now? Roberto wished his scar would burn and show him Salvador’s thoughts, 
because for the first time ever, he and Salvador were united in wanting the very same 
thing…Carolina would not like that idea, of course…But then, she did not 
believe….Xenophilius had been right, in a way…Limited, Narrow, Close-minded. The 
truth was that she was scared of the idea of the Deathly Hallows, especially of the 
Resurrection Stone…and Roberto pressed his mouth again to the Snitch, kissing it, nearly 
swallowing it, but the cold medal did not yield… 

It was nearly dawn when he remembered Gabriela, alone in a cell in Azkaban, 
surrounded by dementors, and he suddenly felt ashamed of himself. He had forgotten all 
about her in his feverish contemplation of the Hallows. If only they could rescue her, but 
dementors in those numbers would be virtually unassailable. Now he came to think about 
it, he had not tried casting a Patronus with the blackthorn wand…He must try that in the 
morning… 

If only there was a way of getting a better wand… 

And desire for the Elder Wand, the Deathstick, unbeatable, invincible, swallowed 
him once more… 

They packed up the tent next morning and moved on through a dreary shower of 
rain. The downpour pursued them to the coast, where they pitched the tent that night, and 
persisted through the whole week, through sodden landscapes that Roberto found bleak and 
depressing. He could think only of the Deathly Hallows. It was as though a flame had 
been lit inside him that nothing, not Carolina’s flat disbelief nor Diego’s persistent doubts, 
could extinguish. And yet the fiercer the longing for the Hallows burned inside him, the 
less joyful it made him. He blamed Diego and Carolina: Their determined indifference 
was as bad as the relentless rain for dampening his spirits, but neither could erode his 
certainty, which remained absolute. Roberto’s belief in and longing for the Hallows 
consumed him so much that he felt isolated from the other two and their obsession with 
the Horcruxes. 

“Obsession?” said Carolina in a low fierce voice, when Roberto was careless 
enough to use the word one evening, after Carolina had told him off for his lack of 
interest in locating more Horcruxes. “We’re not the one with an obsession, Roberto! We’re 
the ones trying to do what Dominguez wanted us to do!” 

But he was impervious to the veiled criticism. Dominguez had left the sign of the 
Hallows for Carolina to decipher, and he had also, Roberto remained convinced of it, left 
the Resurrection Stone hidden in the golden Snitch. Neither can live while the other 
survives…master of Death…Why didn’t Diego and Carolina understand? 

“’The last enemy shall be destroyed is death,’” Roberto quoted calmly. 

“I thought it was You-Know-Who we were supposed to be fighting?” Carolina 
retorted, and Roberto gave up on her. 


Even the mystery of the silver doe, which the other two insisted on discussing, 
seemed less important to Roberto now, a vaguely interesting sideshow. The only other thing 
that mattered to him was that his scar had begun to prickle again, although he did all he 
could to hide this fact from the other two. He sought solitude whenever it happened, but 
was disappointed by what he saw. The visions he and Salvador were sharing had 
changed in quality; they had become blurred, shifting as though they were moving in and 
out of focus. Roberto was just able to make out the indistinct features of an object that 
looked like a skull, and something like a mountain that was more shadow than substance. 
Used to images sharp as reality, Roberto was disconcerted by the change. He was worried 
that the connection between himself and Salvador had been damaged, a connection that 
he both feared and, whatever he had told Carolina, prized. Somehow Roberto connected 
these unsatisfying, vague images with the destruction of his wand, as if it was the 
blackthorn wand’s fault that he could no longer see into Salvador’s mind as well as 
before. 

As the weeks crept on, Roberto could not help but notice, even through his new self-
absorption, that Diego seemed to be taking charge. Perhaps because he was determined to 
make up for having walked out on them, perhaps because Roberto’s descent into 
listlessness galvanized his dormant leadership qualities, Diego was the one now 
encouraging and exhorting the other two into action. 

“Three Horcruxes left,” he kept saying. “We need a plan of action, come on! 
Where haven’t we looked? Let’s go through it again. The orphanage…” 

Diagon Alley, Hogwarts, the Castillo House, Borgin and Burkes, Albania, every 
place that they knew Oscar Castillo had ever lived or worked, visited or murdered, Diego and 
Carolina raked over them again, Roberto joining in only to stop Carolina pestering him. 
He would have been happy to sit alone in silence, trying to read Salvador’s thoughts, to 
find out more about the Elder Wand, but Diego insisted on journeying to ever more 
unlikely places simply, Roberto was aware, to keep them moving. 

“You never know,” was Diego’s constant refrain. “Upper Flagley is a Wizarding 
village, he might’ve wanted to live there. Let’s go and have a poke around.” 

These frequent forays into Wizarding territory brought them within occasional 
sight of Snatchers. 

“Some of them are supposed to be as bad as Death Eaters,” said Diego. “The lot that 
got me were a bit pathetic, but Bill recons some of them are really dangerous. They said 
on Gonzaleswatch ---“ 

“On what?” said Roberto. 

“Gonzaleswatch, didn’t I tell you that’s what it was called? The program I keep 
trying to get on the radio, the only one that tells the truth about what’s going on! Nearly 
all of the programs are following You-Know-Who’s line, all except Gonzaleswatch, I really 
want you to hear it, but it’s tricky tuning in…” 

Diego spent evening after evening using his wand to beat out various rhythms on 
top of the wireless while the dials whirled. Occasionally they would catch snatches of 
advice on how to treat dragonpox, and once a few bars of “A Cauldron Full of Hot, 
Strong Love.” While he taped, Diego continued to try to hit on the correct password, 
muttering strings of random words under his breath. 

“They’re normally something to do with the Order,” he told them. “Bill had a real 
knack for guessing them. I’m bound to get one in the end…” 


“But not until March did luck favor Diego at last. Roberto was sitting in the tent 
entrance, on guard duty, staring idly at a clump of grape hyacinths that had forced their 
way through the chilly ground, when Diego shouted excitedly from inside the tent. 

“I’ve got it, I’ve got it! Password was ‘Alfonso’! Get in here, Roberto.” 

Roused for the first time in days from his contemplation of the Deathly Hallows, 
Roberto hurried back inside the tent to find Diego and Carolina kneeling on the floor beside 
the little radio. Carolina, who had been polishing the sword of Gryffindor just for 
something to do, was sitting open-mouthed, staring at the tiny speaker, from which a 
most familiar voice was issuing. 

“…apologize for our temporary absence from the airwaves, which was due to a 
number of house calls in our area by those charming Death Eaters.” 

“But that’s Lee Jordan!” said Carolina. 

“I know!” beamed Diego. “Cool, eh?” 

“…now found ourselves another secure location,” Lee was saying, and I’m 
pleased to tell you that two of our regular contributors have joined me here this evening. 
Evening, boys!” 

“Hi.” 

“Evening, River.” 

“’River’” that’s Lee,” Diego explained. “They’ve all got code names, but you can 
usually tell ---“ 

“Shh!” said Carolina. 

“But before we hear from Royal and Romulus,” Lee went on, “let’s take a 
moment to report those deaths that the Wizarding Wireless Network News and Daily 
Prophet don’t think important enough to mention. It is with great regret that we inform 
our listeners of the murders of Ted Perez and Dirk Cresswell.” 

Roberto felt a sick, swooping in his belly. He, Diego, and Carolina gazed at one 
another in horror. 

“A goblin by the name of Gornuk was also killed. It is believed that Muggle-born 
Dean Thomas and a second goblin, both believed to have been traveling with Perez, 
Cresswell, and Gornuk, may have escaped. If Dean is listening, or if anyone has any 
knowledge of his whereabouts, his parents and sisters are desperate for news. 

“Meanwhile, in Gaddley, a Muggle family of five has been found dead in their 
home. Muggle authorities are attributing their deaths to a gas leak, but members of the 
Order of the Phoenix inform me that it was the Killing Curse --- more evidence, as if it 
were needed, of the fact that Muggle slaughter is becoming little more than a recreational 
sport under the new regime. 

“Finally, we regret to inform our listeners that the remains of Bathilda Bagshot 
have been discovered in Godric’s Hollow. The evidence is that she died several months 
ago. The Order of the Phoenix informs us that her body showed unmistakable signs of 
injuries inflicted by Dark Magic. 

“Listeners, I’d like to invite you now to join us in a minute’s silence in memory of 
Ted Perez, Dirk Cresswell, Bathilda Bagshot, Gornuk, and the unnamed, but no less 
regretted, Muggles murdered by the Death Eaters.” 

Silence fell, and Roberto, Diego, and Carolina did not speak. Half of Roberto yearned 
to hear more, half of him was afraid of what might come next. It was the first time he had 
felt fully connected to the outside world for a long time. 


“Thank you,” said Lee’s voice. “And now we can return to regular contributor 
Royal, for an update on how the new Wizarding order is affecting the Muggle world.” 

“Thanks, River,” said an unmistakable voice, deep, measured, reassuring. 

“Hector!” burst out Diego. 

“We know!” said Carolina, hushing him. 

“Muggles remain ignorant of the source of their suffering as they continue to 
sustain heavy casualties,” said Hector. “However, we continue to hear truly 
inspirational stories of wizards and witches risking their own safety to protect Muggle 
friends and neighbors, often without the Muggles’ knowledge. I’d like to appeal to all our 
listeners to emulate their example, perhaps by casting a protective charm over any 
Muggle dwellings in your street. Many lives could be saved if such simple measures are 
taken.” 

“And what would you say, Royal, to those listeners who reply that in these 
dangerous times, it should be ‘Wizards first’? asked Lee. 

“I’d say that it’s one short step from ‘Wizards first’ to ‘Purebloods first,’ and then 
to ‘Death Eaters,’” replied Hector. “We’re all human, aren’t we? Every human life is 
worth the same, and worth saving.” 

“Excellently put, Royal, and you’ve got my vote for Minister of Magic if we ever 
get out of this mess,” said Lee. “And now, over to Romulus for our popular feature ‘Pals 
of Gonzales.’” 

“Thanks, River,” said another very familiar voice. Diego started to speak, but 
Carolina forestalled him in a whisper. 

“We know it’s Cardozo!” 

“Romulus, do you maintain, as you have every time you’ve appeared on our 
program, that Roberto Gonzales is still alive?” 

“I do,” said Cardozo firmly. “There is no doubt at all in my mind that his death 
would be proclaimed as widely as possible by the Death Eaters if it had happened, 
because it would strike a deadly blow at the morale of those resisting the new regime. 
‘The Boy Who Lived’ remains a symbol of everything for which we are fighting: the 
triumph of good, the power of innocence, the need to keep resisting.” 

A mixture of gratitude and shame welled up in Roberto. Had Cardozo forgiven him, 
then, for the terrible things he had said when they had last met? 

“And what would you say to Roberto if you knew he was listening, Romulus?” 

“I’d tell him we’re all with him in spirit,” said Cardozo, then hesitated slightly, 
“And I’d tell him to follow his instincts, which are good and nearly always right.” 

Roberto looked at Carolina, whose eyes were full of tears. 

“Nearly always right,” she repeated. 

“Oh, didn’t I tell you?” said Diego in surprise. “Bill told me Cardozo’s living with 
Perez again! And apparently she’s getting pretty big too…” 

“…and our usual update on those friends of Roberto Gonzales’s who are suffering for 
their allegiance?” Lee was saying. 

 “Well, as regular listeners will know, several of the more outspoken supporters of 
Roberto Gonzales have now been imprisoned, including Xenophilius Ortiz, erstwhile 
editor of The Quibbler,” said Cardozo. 

 “At least he’s still alive!” muttered Diego. 


 “We have also heard within the last few hours that Matias Villalba” – all three of 
them gasped, and so nearly missed the rest of the sentence -- “well-known gamekeeper at 
Hogwarts School, has narrowly escaped arrest within the grounds of Hogwarts, where he 
is rumored to have hosted a ‘Support Roberto Gonzales’ party in his house. However, Villalba 
was not taken into custody, and is, we believe, on the run.” 

 “I suppose it helps, when escaping from Death Eaters, if you’ve got a sixteen-
foot-high half brother?” asked Lee. 

 “It would tend to give you an edge,” agreed Cardozo gravely. “May I just add that 
while we here at Gonzaleswatch applaud Villalba’s spirit, we would urge even the most 
devoted of Roberto’s supporters against following Villalba’s lead. ‘Support Roberto Gonzales’ 
parties are unwise in the present climate.” 

 “Indeed they are, Romulus,” said Lee, “so we suggest that you continue to show 
your devotion to the man with the lightning scar by listening to Gonzaleswatch! And now 
let’s move to news concerning the wizard who is proving just as elusive as Roberto Gonzales. 
We like to refer to him as the Chief Death Eater, and here to give his views on some of 
the more insane rumors circulating about him, I’d like to introduce a new correspondent. 
Rodent?” 

 “’Rodent’?” said yet another familiar voice, and Roberto, Diego, and Carolina cried 
out together: 

 “Pablo!” 

 “No – is it Luis?” 

 “It’s Pablo, I think,” said Diego, leaning in closer, as whichever twin it was said, 

 “I’m not being ‘Rodent,’ no way, I told you I wanted to be ‘Rapier’!” 

 “Oh, all right then, ‘Rapier,’ could you please give us your take on the various 
stories we’ve been hearing about the Chief Death Eater?” 

 “Yes, River, I can,” said Pablo. “As our listeners will know, unless they’ve taken 
refuge at the bottom of a garden pond or somewhere similar, You-Know-Who’s strategy 
of remaining in the shadows is creating a nice little climate of panic. Mind you, if all the 
alleged sightings of him are genuine, we must have a good nineteen You-Know-Whos 
running around the place.” 

 “Which suits him, of course,” said Hector. “The air of mystery is creating more 
terror than actually showing himself.” 

 “Agreed,” said Pablo. “So, people, let’s try and calm down a bit. Things are bad 
enough without inventing stuff as well. For instance, this new idea that You-Know-Who 
can kill people with a single glance from his eyes. That’s a basilisk, listeners. One simple 
test: Check whether the thing that’s glaring at you has got legs. If it has, it’s safe to look 
into its eyes, although if it really is You-Know-Who, that’s still likely to be the last thing 
you ever do.” 

 For the first time in weeks and weeks, Roberto was laughing: He could feel the 
weight of tension leaving him. 

 “And the rumors that he keeps being sighted abroad?” asked Lee. 

 “Well, who wouldn’t want a nice little holiday after all the hard work he’s been 
putting in?” asked Pablo. “Point is, people, don’t get lulled into a false sense of security, 
thinking he’s out of the country. Maybe he is, maybe he isn’t, but the fact remains he can 
move faster than Carlos Peralta confronted with shampoo when he wants to, so don’t 


count on him being a long way away if you’re planning to take any risks. I never thought 
I’d hear myself say it, but safety first!” 

 “Thank you very much for those wise words, Rapier,” said Lee. ”Listeners, that 
brings us to the end of another Gonzaleswatch. We don’t know when it will be possible to 
broadcast again, but you can be sure we shall be back. Keep twiddling those dials: The 
next password will be ‘Mad-Eye.’ Keep each other safe: Keep faith. Good night.” 

 The radio’s dial twirled and the lights behind the tuning panel went out. Roberto, 
Diego, and Carolina were still beaming. Hearing familiar, friendly voices was an 
extraordinary tonic; Roberto had become so used to their isolation he had nearly forgotten 
that other people were resisting Salvador. It was like waking from a long sleep. 

 “Good, eh?” said Diego happily. 

 “Brilliant,” said Roberto. 

 “It’s so brave of them,” sighed Carolina admiringly. “If they were found …” 

 “Well, they keep on the move, don’t they?” said Diego. “Like us.” 

 “But did you hear what Pablo said?” asked Roberto excitedly; now the broadcast was 
over, his thoughts turned around toward his all consuming obsession. “He’s abroad! He’s 
still looking for the Wand, I knew it!” 

 “Roberto—“ 

 “Come on, Carolina, why are you so determined not to admit it? Vol –“ 

 “ROBERTO, NO!” 

 “—demort’s after the Elder Wand!” 

 “The name’s Taboo!” Diego bellowed, leaping to his feet as a loud crack sounded 
outside the tent. “I told you, Roberto, I told you, we can’t say it anymore – we’ve got to put 
the protection back around us – quickly – it’s how they find –“ 

 But Diego stopped talking, and Roberto knew why. The Sneakoscope on the table had 
lit up and begun to spin; they could hear voices coming nearer and nearer: rough, excited 
voices. Diego pulled the Deluminator out of his pocket and clicked it: Their lamps went out. 

 “Come out of there with your hands up!” came a rasping voice through the 
darkness. “We know you’re in there! You’ve got half a dozen wands pointing at you and 
we don’t care who we curse!” 

 

 

Chapter Twenty-Three 

Sosa Manor 

 

Roberto looked around at the other two, now mere outlines in the darkness. He saw 
Carolina point her wand, set toward the outside, but into his face; there was a bang, a 
burst of white light, and he buckled in agony, unable to see. He could feel his face 
swelling rapidly under his hands as heavy footfalls surrounded him. 

 "Get up, vermin." 

 Unknown hands dragged Roberto roughly off the ground, before he could stop them, 
someone had rummaged through his pockets and removed the blackthorn wand. Roberto 
clutched at his excruciatingly painful face, which felt unrecognizable beneath his fingers, 
tight, swollen, and puffy as though he had suffered some violent allergic reaction. His 


eyes had been reduced to slits through which he could barely see; his glasses fell off as he 
was bundled out of the tent: all he could make out were the blurred shapes of four or five 
people wrestling Diego and Carolina outside too. 

 "Get -- off - her!" Diego shouted. There was the unmistakable sound of knuckles 
hitting flesh: Diego grunted in pain and Carolina screamed, "No! Leave him alone, leave 
him alone!" 

 "Your boyfriend's going to have worse than that done to him if he's on my list," 
said the horribly familiar, rasping voice. "Delicious girl... what a treat . . . I do enjoy the 
softness of the skin. . . ." 

 Roberto's stomach turned over. He knew who this was, Fenrit Greyback, the 
werewolf who was permitted to wear Death Eater robes in return for his hired savagery. 

 "Search the tent!" said another voice. 

 Roberto was thrown face down onto the ground. A thud told him that Diego had been 
cast down beside him. They could hear footsteps and crashes; the men were pushing over 
chairs inside the tent as they searched. 

 "Now, let's see who we've got," said Greyback's gloating voice from overhead, 
and Roberto was rolled over onto his back. A beam of wand light fell onto his face and 
Greyback laughed. 

 "I'll be needing butterbeer to wash this one down. What happened to you, ugly?" 

 Roberto did not answer immediately. 

 "I said," repeated Greyback, and Roberto received a blow to the diaphragm that 
made him double over in pain. "what happened to you?" 

 "Stung." Roberto muttered. "Been Stung." 

 "Yeah, looks like it." said a second voice. 

 "What’s your name?" snarled Greyback. 

 "Leonardo." said Roberto. 

 "And your first name?" 

 "I -- Francisco. Francisco Leonardo." 

 "Check the list, Scabior." said Greyback, and Roberto head him move sideways to 
look down at Diego, instead. "And what about you, ginger?" 

 "Stan Shunpike." said Diego. 

 "Like 'ell you are." said the man called Scabior. "We know Stan Shunpike, 'e's put 
a bit of work our way." 

 There was another thud. 

 "I'b Bardy," said Diego, and Roberto could tell that his mouth was full of blood. 
"Bardy Lopez." 

 "A Lopez?" rasped Greyback. "So you're related to blood traitors even if you're 
not a Mudblood. And lastly, your pretty little friend . . ." The relish in his voice made 
Roberto's flesh crawl. 

 "Easy, Greyback." said Scabior over the jeering of the others. 

 "Oh, I'm not going to bite just yet. We'll see if she’s a bit quicker at remembering 
her name than Barny. Who are you, girly? 

 "Penelope Clearwater." said Carolina. She sounded terrified, but convincing. 

 "What's your blood status?" 

 "Half-Blood." said Carolina. 


 "Easy enough to check," said Scabior. "But the 'ole lot of 'em look like they could 
still be 'ogwarts age -" 

 "We'b lebt," said Diego. 

 "Left, 'ave you, ginger?" said Scabior. "And you decided to go camping? And you 
thought, just for a laugh, you'd use the Dark Lords name?" 

 "Nod a laugh," said Diego. "Aggiden." 

 "Accident?" There was more jeering laughter. 

 "You know who used to like using the Dark Lord's name, Lopez?" growled 
Greyback, "The Order of the Phoenix. Mean anything to you?" 

 "Doh." 

 "Well, they don't show the Dark Lord proper respect, so the name's been Tabooed. 
A few Order members have been tracked that way. We'll see. Bind them up with the 
other two prisoners!" 

 Someone yanked Roberto up by the hair, dragged him a short way, pushed him 
down into a sitting position, then started binding him back-to-back with other people. 
Roberto was still half blind, barely able to see anything through his puffed-up eyes. When 
at last the man tying then had walked away, Roberto whispered to the other prisoners. 

 "Anyone still got a wand?" 

 "No." Said Diego and Carolina from either side of him. 

 "This is all my fault. I said the name. I'm sorry -" 

 "Roberto?" 

 It was a new, but familiar voice. and it came from directly behind Roberto, from the 
person tied to Carolina's left. 

 "Dean?" 

 "It is you! If they find out who they've got -! They're Snatchers, they're only 
looking for truants to sell for gold -" 

 "Not a bad little haul for one night." Greyback was saying, as a pair of hobnailed 
boots marched close by Roberto and they heard more crashes from inside the tent. "A 
Mudblood, a runaway goblin, and these truants. You checked their names on the list yet, 
Scabior?" he roared. 

 "Yeah. There's no Francisco Leonardo un 'ere, Greyback." 

 "Interesting," said Greyback. "That's interesting." 

 He crouched down beside Roberto, who saw, through the infinitesimal gap left 
between his swollen eyelids, a face covered in matted gray hair and whiskers, with 
pointed brown teeth and sores in the corners of his mouth. Greyback smelled as he had 
done at the top of the tower where Dominguez had died: of dirt, sweat, and blood. 

 "So you aren't wanted, then, Francisco? Or are you on that list under a different 
name? What house were you in at Hogwarts?" 

 "Slytherin," said Roberto automatically. 

 "Funny 'ow they all thinks we wants to 'ear that." leered Scabior out of the 
shadows. "But none of 'em can tell us where the common room is." 

 "It's in the dungeons." said Roberto clearly. "You enter through the wall. It's full of 
skulls and stuff and its under the lake, so the light's all green," 

 There was a short pause. 


 "Well, well, looks like we really 'ave caught a little Slytherin." said Scabior. 
"Good for you, Francisco, 'cause there ain't a lot of Mudblood Slytherins. Who's your 
father?" 

 "He works at the Ministry," Roberto lied. He knew that his whole story would 
collapse with the smallest investigation, but on the other hand, he only had until his face 
regained its usual appearance before the game was up in any case. "Department of 
Magical Accidents and Catastrophes." 

 "You know what, Greyback," said Scabior. "I think there is a Leonardo in there." 

 Roberto could barely breathe: Could luck, sheer luck, get them safely out of this? 

 "Well, well." said Greyback, and Roberto could hear the tiniest note of trepidation 
in that callous voice, and knew that Greyback was wondering whether he had just indeed 
just attacked and bound the son of a Ministry Official. Roberto's heart was pounding against 
the ropes around his ribs; he would not have been surprised to know that Greyback could 
see it. "If you're telling the truth, ugly, you've got nothing to fear from a trip to the 
Ministry. I expect your father'll reward us just for picking you up." 

 "But," said Roberto, his mouth bone dry, "if you just let us -" 

 "Hey!" came a shout from inside the tent. "Look at this. Greyback!" 

 A dark figure came bustling toward them, and Roberto saw a glint of silver to the 
light of their wands. They had found Gryffindor's sword. 

 "Ve-e-ery nice," said Greyback appreciatively, taking it from his companion. "Oh, 
very nice indeed. Looks goblin-made, that. Where did you get something like this?" 

 "It's my father's," Roberto lied, hoping against hope that it was too dark for 
Greyback to see the name etched just below the hilt. "We borrowed it to cut firewood -" 

 "'ang on a minute, Greyback! Look at this, in the Prophet!" 

 As Scabior said it, Roberto's scar, which was stretched tight across his distended 
forehead, burned savagely. More clearly than he could make out anything around him, he 
saw a towering building, a grim fortress, jet-black and forbidding: Salvador's thoughts 
had suddenly become Razor-Sharp again; he was gliding toward the gigantic building 
with a sense of calmly euphoric purpose . . . 

 So close . . . So close . . . 

With a huge effort of will Roberto closed his mind to Salvador's thoughts, pulling himself 
back to where he sat, tied to Diego, Carolina, Dean, and Griphook in the darkness, 
listening to Greyback and Scabior. 

"'Carolina Fernandez," Scabior was saying, "the Mudblood who is known to be traveling 
with 'arry Gonzales." 

 Roberto's scar burned in the silence, but he made a supreme effort to keep himself 
present, nor to slip into Salvador's mind. He heard the creak of Greyback's boots as he 
crouched down, in front of Carolina. 

 "you know what, little girly? This picture looks a hell of a lot like you." 

 "It isn't! It isn't me!" 

 Carolina's terrified squeak was as good as a confession. 

 "... known to be traveling with Roberto Gonzales," repeated Greyback quietly. 

 A stillness had settled over the scene. Roberto's scar was Exquisitely painful, but he 
struggled with all his strength against the pull of Salvador's thoughts. It had never been 
so important to remain in his own right mind. 


 "Well, this changed things, doesn't it?" whispered Greyback. Nobody spoke: 
Roberto sensed the gang of Snatchers watching, frozen, and felt Carolina's arm trembling 
against his. Greyback got up and took a couple of steps to where Roberto sat, crouching 
down again to stare closely at his misshapen features. 

 "What's that on your forehead, Francisco?" he asked softly, his breath foul in 
Roberto's nostrils as he pressed a filthy finger to the taught scar. 

 "Don't touch it! Roberto yelled; he could not stop himself, he thought he might be 
sick from the pain of it. 

 "I thought you wore glasses, Gonzales?" breathed Greyback. 

 "I found glasses!" yelped one of the Snatchers skulking in the background. "There 
was glasses in the tent, Greyback, wait -" 

 And seconds later Roberto's glasses had been rammed back onto his face. The 
Snatchers were closing in now, peering at him. 

 "It Is!" rasped Greyback. "We've caught Gonzales!" 

 They all took several steps backward, stunned by what they had done. Roberto, still 
fighting to remain present in his own splitting head, could think of nothing to say. 
Fragmented visions were breaking across the surface of his mind - 

 --He was hiding around the high walls of the black fortress-- 

 No, he was Roberto, tied up and wandless, in grave danger-- 

 --looking up, up to the topmost window, the highest tower-- 

 He was Roberto, and they were discussing his fate in low voices-- 

 --Time to fly . . . 

 ". . . To the Ministry?" 

 "To hell with the Ministry." growled Greyback. "They'll take the credit, and we 
won't get a look in. I say we take him straight to You-Know-Who." 

 "Will you summon 'im? 'ere?" said Scabior, sounding awed, terrified. 

 "No," snarled Greyback, "I haven't got -- they say he's using the Sosa's place as 
a base. We'll take the boy there." 

 Roberto thought he knew why Greyback was not calling Salvador. The werewolf 
might be allowed to wear Death Eater robes when they wanted to use him, but only 
Salvador's inner circle were branded with the Dark Mark: Greyback had not been 
granted this highest honor. 

Roberto’s scar seared again – 

– and he rose into the night, flying straight up to the windows at the very top of 
the tower – 

“. . . completely sure it’s him? ‘Cause if it ain’t, Greyback, we’re dead.” 

“Who’s in charge here?” roared Greyback, covering his moment of inadequacy. “I 
say that’s Gonzales, and him plus his wand, that’s two hundred thousand Galleons right 
there! But if you’re too gutless to come along, any of you, it’s all for me, and with any 
luck, I’ll get the girl thrown in!” 

 – The window was the merest slit in the black rock, not big enough for a man to 
enter. . . . A skeletal figure was just visible through it, curled beneath a blanket. . . . Dead, 
or sleeping . . . ? 

“All right!” said Scabior. “All right, we’re in! And what about the rest of ‘em, 
Greyback, what’ll we do with ‘em?” 


“Might as well take the lot. We’ve got two Mudbloods, that’s another ten 
Galleons. Give me the sword as well. If they’re rubies, that’s another small fortune right 
there.” 

The prisoners were dragged to their feet. Roberto could hear Carolina’s breathing, 
fast and terrified. 

“Grab hold and make it tight. I’ll do Gonzales!” said Greyback, seizing a fistful of 
Roberto’s hair; Roberto could feel his long yellow nails scratching his scalp. “On three! One – 
two – three –“ 

They Disapparated, pulling the prisoners with them. Roberto struggled, trying to 
throw off Greyback’s hand, but it was hopeless: Diego and Carolina were squeezed tightly 
against him on either side; he could not separate from the group, and as the breath was 
squeezed out of him his scar seared more painfully still – 

 – as he forced himself through the slit of a window like a snake and landed, 
lightly as vapor inside the cell-like room – 

 The prisoners lurched into one another as they landed in a country lane. Roberto’s 
eyes, still puffy, took a moment to acclimatize, then he saw a pair of wrought-iron gates 
at the foot of what looked like a long drive. He experienced the tiniest trickle of relief. 
The worst had not happened yet: Salvador was not here. He was, Roberto knew, for he 
was fighting to resist the vision, in some strange, fortresslike place, at the top of a tower. 
How long it would take Salvador to get to this place, once he knew that Roberto was here, 
was another matter. . . . 

 One of the Snatchers strode to the gates and shook them. 

 “How do we get in? They’re locked, Greyback, I can’t – blimey!” 

 He whipped his hands away in fright. The iron was contorting, twisting itself out 
of the abstract furls and coils into a frightening face, which spoke in a clanging, echoing 
voice. “State your purpose!” 

 “We’ve got Gonzales!” Greyback roared triumphantly. “We’ve captured Roberto 
Gonzales!” 

 The gates swung open. 

 “Come on!” said Greyback to his men, and the prisoners were shunted through the 
gates and up the drive, between high hedges that muffled their footsteps. Roberto saw a 
ghostly white shape above him, and realized it was an albino peacock. He stumbled and 
was dragged onto his feet by Greyback; now he was staggering along sideways, tied 
back-to-back to the four other prisoner. Closing his puffy eyes, he allowed the pain in his 
scar to overcome him for a moment, wanting to know what Salvador was doing, 
whether he knew yet that Roberto was caught. . . . 

 The emaciated figure stirred beneath its thin blanket and rolled over toward him, 
eyes opening in a skull of a face. . . . The frail man sat up, great sunken eyes fixed upon 
him, upon Salvador, and then he smiled. Most of his teeth were gone. . . . 

 “So, you have come. I thought you would . . . one day. But your journey was 
pointless. I never had it.” 

 “You lie!” 

 As Salvador’s anger throbbed inside him, Roberto’s scar threatened to burst with 
pain, and he wrenched his mind back to his own body, fighting to remain present as the 
prisoners were pushed over gravel. 


 Light spilled out over all of them. 

 “What is this?” said a woman’s cold voice. 

 “We’re here to see He-Who-Must-Not-Be-Named!” rasped Greyback. 

 “Who are you?” 

 “You know me!” There was resentment in the werewolf’s voice. “Fenrit 
Greyback! We’ve caught Roberto Gonzales!” 

 Greyback seized Roberto and dragged him around to face the light, forcing the other 
prisoners to shuffle around too. 

 “I know ‘es swollen, ma’am, but it’s ‘im!” piped up Scabior. “If you look a bit 
closer, you’ll see ‘is scar. And this ‘ere, see the girl? The Mudblood who’s been traveling 
around with ‘im, ma’am. There’s no doubt it’s ‘im, and we’ve got ‘is wand as well! ‘Ere, 
ma’am –“ 

 Through his puffy eyelids Roberto saw Julia Sosa scrutinizing his swollen 
face. Scabior thrust the blackthorn wand at her. She raised her eyebrows. 

 “Bring them in,” she said. 

 Roberto and the others were shoved and kicked up broad stone steps into a hallway 
lined with portraits. 

 “Follow me,” said Julia, leading the way across the hall. “My son, Javier, is 
home for his Easter holidays. If that is Roberto Gonzales, he will know.” 

 The drawing room dazzled after the darkness outside; even with his eyes almost 
closed Roberto could make out the wide proportions of the room. A crystal chandelier hung 
from the ceiling, more portraits against the dark purple walls. Two figures rose from 
chairs in front of an ornate marble fireplace as the prisoners were forced into the room by 
the Snatchers. 

 “What is this?” 

 The dreadfully familiar, drawling voice of Mariano Sosa fell on Roberto’s ears. He 
was panicking now. He could see no way out, and it was easier, as his fear mounted, to 
block out Salvador’s thoughts, though his scar was still burning. 

 “They say they’ve got Gonzales,” said Julia’s cold voice. “Javier, come here.” 
Roberto did not dare look directly at Javier, but saw him obliquely; a figure slightly 
taller than he was, rising from an armchair, his face a pale and pointed blur beneath 
white-blond hair. 

 Greyback forced the prisoners to turn again so as to place Roberto directly beneath 
the chandelier. 

 “Well, boy?” rasped the werewolf. 

 Roberto was facing a mirror over the fireplace, a great gilded thing in an intricately 
scrolled frame. Through the slits of his eyes he saw his own reflection for the first time 
since leaving Grimmauld Place. 

 His face was huge, shiny, and pink, every feature distorted by Carolina’s jinx. 
His black hair reached his shoulders and there was a dark shadow around his jaw. Had he 
not known that it was he who stood there, he would have wondered who was wearing his 
glasses. He resolved not to speak, for his voice was sure to give him away; yet he still 
avoided eye contact with Javier as the latter approached. 

 “Well, Javier?” said Mariano Sosa. He sounded avid. “Is it? Is it Roberto Gonzales?” 
“I can’t – I can’t be sure,” said Javier. He was keeping his distance from 
Greyback, and seemed as scared of looking at Roberto as Roberto was of looking at him. 


 “But look at him carefully, look! Come closer!” 

 Roberto had never heard Mariano Sosa so excited. 

 “Javier, if we are the ones who hand Gonzales over to the Dark Lord, everything will 
be forgiv –“ 

 “Now, we won’t be forgetting who actually caught him, I hope Mr. Sosa?” said 
Greyback menacingly. 

 “Of course not, of course not!” said Mariano impatiently. He approached Roberto 
himself, came so close that Roberto could see the usually languid, pale face in sharp detail 
even through his swollen eyes. With his face a puffy mask, Roberto felt as though he was 
peering out from between the bars of a cage. 

 “What did you do to him?” Mariano asked Greyback. “How did he get into this 
state?” 

 “That wasn’t us.” 
“Looks more like a Stinging Jinx to me,” said Mariano. 

 His gray eyes raked Roberto’s forehead. 

 “There’s something there,” he whispered. “it could be the scar, stretched 
tight. . . .” Javier, come here, look properly! What do you think?” 

 Roberto saw Javier’s face up close now, right beside his father’s. They were 
extraordinarily alike, except that while his father looked beside himself with excitement, 
Javier’s expression was full of reluctance, even fear. 

 “I don’t know,” he said, and he walked away toward the fireplace where his 
mother stood watching. 

 “We had better be certain, Mariano,” Julia called to her husband in her cold,

say this is his” – she was looking closely at the blackthorn wand – “but it does not 
resemble Ollivander’s description. . . . If we are mistaken, if we call the Dark Lord here 
for nothing . . . Remember what he did to Rowle and Dolohov?” 

 “What about the Mudblood, then?” growled Greyback. Roberto was nearly thrown

fell on Carolina instead. 

 “Wait,” said Julia sharply. “Yes – yes, she was in Madam Malkin’s with 
Gonzales! I saw her picture in the Prophet! Look, Javier, isn’t it the Fernandez girl?” 

 “I . . . maybe . . . yeah.” 

 “But then, that’s the Lopez boy!” shouted Mariano, striding around the bound

Lopez’s son, what’s his name – ?” 

 “Yeah,” said Javier again, his back to the prisoners. “It could be.” 

 The drawing room door opened behind Roberto. A woman spoke, and the sound of

 “What is this? What’s happened, Cissy?” 

 Miranda Gimenez walked slowly around the prisoners, and stopped on Roberto’s 
right, staring at Carolina through her heavily lidded eyes, 

 “But surely,” she said quietly, “this is the Mudblood girl? This is Grander?” 

 “Yes, yes, it’s Fernandez!” cried Mariano, “And beside her, we think, Gonzales! Gonzales 
and his friends, caught at last!” 
“Gonzales?” shrieked Miranda, and she backed away, the better to take in Roberto. 


“Are you sure? Well then, the Dark Lord must be informed at once!” 
She dragged back her left sleeve: Roberto saw the Dark Mark burned into the flesh

 “I was about to call him!” said Mariano, and his hand actually closed upon 
Miranda’s wrist, preventing her from touching the Mark. “I shall summon him, Bella. 
Gonzales has been brought to my house, and it is therefore upon my authority –“ 

 “Your authority!” she sneered, attempting to wrench her hand from his grasp. 
“You lost your authority when you lost your wand, Mariano! How dare you! Take your

 “This is nothing to do with you, you did not capture the boy –“

 She stopped struggling, her dark eyes fixed upon something Roberto could not see.

 Mariano froze, his index finger hovering over his own Mark. Miranda strode out of

 “What is that?” he heard her say. 

 “Sword,” grunted an out-of-sight Snatcher. 

 “Give it to me.” 

 “It’s not yours, missus, it’s mine, I reckon I found it.” 

 There was a bang and a flash of red light; Roberto knew that the Snatcher had been 
Stunned. There was a roar of anger from his fellows: Scabior drew his wand. 

 “What d’you think you’re playing at, woman?” 

 “Stupefy!” she screamed, ”Stupefy!” 

 They were no match for her, even thought there were four of them against one of 
her: She was a witch, as Roberto knew, with prodigious skill and no conscience. They fell 
where they stood, all except Greyback, who had been forced into a kneeling position, his

 “Where did you get this sword?” she whispered to Greyback as she pulled his 
wand out of his unresisting grip. 

 “How dare you?” he snarled, his mouth the only thing that could move as he was 
forced to gaze up at her. He bared his pointed teeth. “Release me, woman!” 
“Where did you find this sword?” she repeated, brandishing it in his face, “Peralta 
sent it to my vault in Gringotts!” 

 “It was in their tent,” rasped Greyback. “Release me, I say!” 

 She waved her wand, and the werewolf sprang to his feet, but appeared too wary 
to approach her. He prowled behind an armchair, his filthy curved nails clutching its back. 

 “Javier, move this scum outside,” said Miranda, indicating the unconscious men. 
“If you haven’t got the guts to finish them, then leave them in the courtyard for me.” 


 “Don’t you dare speak to Javier like –“ said Julia furiously, but Miranda

 “Be quiet! The situation is graver than you can possibly imagine, Cissy! We have

 She stood, panting slightly, looking down at the sword, examining its hilt. Then

 “If it is indeed Gonzales, he must not be harmed,” she muttered, more to herself than

 She turned back to her sister again. 

“The prisoners must be placed in the cellar, while I think what to do!” 
“This is my house, Bella, you don’t give orders in my –“

Julia hesitated for a moment, then addressed the werewolf. 

“Take these prisoners down to the cellar, Greyback.”

Greyback gave a grunt of pleasure. 

“No!” shouted Diego. “You can have me, keep me!” 
Miranda hit him across the face: the blow echoed around the room. 

“If she dies under questioning, I’ll take you next,” she said. “Blood traitor is next

She threw Greyback’s wand back to him, then took a short silver knife from under

“Reckon she’ll let me have a bit of the girl when she’s finished with her?”

Roberto could feel Diego shaking. They were forced down a steep flight of stairs, still 
tied back-to-back and in danger of slipping and breaking their necks at any moment. At

“CAROLINA!” Diego bellowed, and he started to writhe and struggle against the 
ropes tying them together, so that Roberto staggered. “CAROLINA!” 

“Be quiet!” Roberto said. “Shut up. Diego, we need to work out a way –“ 

“CAROLINA! CAROLINA!” 

“We need a plan, stop yelling – we need to get these ropes off –“

Diego stopped shouting. There was a sound of movement close by them, then Roberto 
saw a shadow moving closer. 


“Roberto? Diego?” 

“Gabriela?” 

“Yes, it’s me! Oh no, I didn’t want you to be caught!”

Carolina screamed again from overhead, and they could hear Miranda

She was back within seconds. 

“You’ll need to stay still,” she said. 

Roberto could feel her digging at the rope’s tough fibers to work the knots free. 
From upstairs they heard Miranda’s voice. 

“I’m going to ask you again! Where did you get this sword? Where?” 

“We found it – we found it – PLEASE!” Carolina screamed again; Diego

A few seconds later, there was a click, and the luminescent spheres the 
Deluminator had sucked from the lamps in the tent flew into the cellar: Unable to rejoin

light. Roberto saw Gabriela, all eyes in her white face, and the motionless figure of Ollivander

“Oh, that’s much easier, thanks, Diego,” said Gabriela, and she began hacking at their

From above came Miranda’s voice. 

“You’re lying, filthy Mudblood, and I know it! You have been inside my vault at 
Gringotts! Tell the truth, tell the truth!” 

Another terrible scream– 

“CAROLINA!” 

“What else did you take? What else have you got? Tel me the truth or, I swear, I 
shall run you through with this knife!” 

“There!” 

Roberto felt the ropes fall away and turned, rubbing his wrists, to see Diego running

bruised and bloody, said “Thanks” to Gabriela and stood there, shivering, but Griphook sank

Diego was now trying to Disapparate without a wand. 

“There’s no way out, Diego,” said Gabriela, watching his fruitless efforts. “The cellar 
is completely escape-proof. I tried, at first. Mr. Ollivander has been here for a long time, 
he’s tried everything.” 


Carolina was screaming again: The sound went through Roberto like physical pain. 
Barely conscious of the fierce prickling of his scar, he too started to run around the cellar, 
feeling the walls for he hardly knew what, knowing in his heart that it was useless. 

“What else did you take, what else? ANSWER ME! CRUCIO!” 

Carolina’s screams echoed off the walls upstairs, Diego was half sobbing as he 
pounded the walls with his fists, and Roberto in utter desperation seized Villalba’s pouch 
from around his neck and groped inside it: He pulled out Dominguez’s Snitch and shook 
it, hoping for he did not know what – nothing happened – he waved the broken halves of 
the phoenix wand, but they were lifeless – the mirror fragment fell sparkling to the floor, 
and he saw a gleam of brightest blue – 

Dominguez’s eye was gazing at him out of the mirror. 

“Help us!” he yelled at it in mad desperation. “We’re in the cellar of Sosa 
Manor, help us!” 

The eye blinked and was gone. 

Roberto was not even sure that it had really been there. He tilted the shard of mirror 
this way and that, and saw nothing reflected there but the walls and ceiling of their prison, 
and upstairs Carolina was screaming worse than ever, and next to him Diego was

“How did you get into my vault?” they heard Miranda scream. “Did that dirty

“We only met him tonight!” Carolina sobbed. “We’ve never been inside your

“A copy?” screeched Miranda. “Oh, a likely story!” 

“But we can find out easily!” came Mariano’s voice. “Javier, fetch the goblin, he 
can tell us whether the sword is real or not!” 

Roberto dashed across the cellar to where Griphook was huddled on the floor. 

“Griphook,” he whispered into the goblin’s pointed ear, “you must tell them that 
sword’s a fake, they mustn’t know it’s the real one, Griphook, please –“ 

He could hear someone scuttling own the cellar steps; next moment, Javier’s

“Stand back. Line up against the back wall. Don’t try anything, or I’ll kill you!” 

They did as they were bidden; as the lock turned, Diego clicked the Deluminator 
and the lights whisked back into his pocket, restoring the cellar’s darkness. The door flew 
open; Sosa marched inside, wand held out in front of him, pale and determined. He

The door slammed shut and at the same moment a loud crack echoed inside the cellar. 

Diego clicked the Deluminator. Three balls of light flew back into the air from his 
pocket, revealing Dobby the house-elf, who had just Apparated into their midst. 

“DOB – !” 

Roberto hit Diego on the arm to stop him shouting, and Diego looked terrified at his 
mistake. Footsteps crossed the ceiling overhead: Javier marching Griphook to Miranda. 

Dobby’s enormous, tennis-ball shaped eyes were wide; he was trembling from his

that he was petrified. 

“Roberto Gonzales,” he squeaked in the tiniest quiver of a voice, “Dobby has come to 
rescue you.” 


“But how did you – ?” 

An awful scream drowned Roberto’s words: Carolina was being tortured again. He 
cut to the essentials. 

“You can Disapparate out of this cellar?” he asked Dobby, who nodded, his ears 
flapping. 

“And you can take humans with you?” 

Dobby nodded again. 

“Right. Dobby, I want you to grab Gabriela, Dean, and Mr. Ollivander, and take them 
– take them to –“ 

“Bill and Camila’s,” said Diego. “Shell Cottage on the outskirts of Tinworth!” 

The elf nodded for a third time. 

“And then come back,” said Roberto. “Can you do that, Dobby?” 

“Of course, Roberto Gonzales,” whispered the little elf. He hurried over to Mr.

“Roberto, we want to help you!” Gabriela whispered. 

“We can’t leave you here,” said Dean. 

“Go, both of you! We’ll see you at Bill and Camila’s.” 

As Roberto spoke, his scar burned worse than ever, and for a few seconds he looked

laughing scornfully. 

“Kill me, then. Salvador, I welcome death! But my death will not bring you what

He felt Salvador’s fury, but as Carolina screamed again he shut it out, 
returning to the cellar and the horror of his own present. 

“Go!” Roberto beseeched to Gabriela and Dean. “Go! We’ll follow, just go!” 

They caught hold of the elf’s outstretched fingers. There was another loud crack, 
and Dobby, Gabriela, Dean, and Ollivander vanished. 

“What was that?” shouted Mariano Sosa from over their heads. “Did you hear 
that? What was that noise in the cellar?” 

Roberto and Diego stared at each other. 

“Javier – no, call Wormtail! Make him go and check!” 

Footsteps crossed the room overhead, then there was silence. Roberto knew that the 
people in the drawing room were listening for more noises from the cellar. 

“We’re going to have to try and tackle him,” he whispered to Diego. They had no 
choice: The moment anyone entered the room and saw the absence of three prisoners, 
they were lost. “Leave the lights on,” Roberto added, and as they heard someone 
descending the steps outside the door, they backed against the wall on either side of it. 

“Stand back,” came Wormtail’s voice. “Stand away from the door. I’m coming 
in.” 
The door flew open. For a split second Wormtail gazed into the apparently empty cellar, 
ablaze with light from the three miniature suns floating in midair. Then Roberto and Diego 
launched themselves upon him. Diego seized Wormtail’s wand arm and forced it upwards. 
Roberto slapped a hand to his mouth, muffling his voice. Silently they struggled: 
Wormtail’s wand emitted sparks; his silver hand closed around Roberto’s throat. 

“What is it, Wormtail?” called Mariano Sosa from above. 


“Nothing!” Diego called back, in a passable imitation of Wormtail’s wheezy voice. 
“All fine!” 

Roberto could barely breathe. 

“You’re going to kill me?” Roberto choked, attempting to prise off the metal fingers. 
“After I saved your life? You owe me, Wormtail!” 

The silver fingers slackened. Roberto had not expected it: He wrenched himself free, 
astonished, keeping his hand over Wormtail’s mouth. He saw the ratlike man’s small 
watery eyes widen with fear and surprise: He seemed just as shocked as Roberto at what his 
hand had done, at the tiny, merciful impulse it had betrayed, and he continued to struggle 
more powerfully, as though to undo that moment of weakness. 

“And we’ll have that,” whispered Diego, tugging Wormtail’s wand from his other 
hand. 

Wandless, helpless, Salazar’s pupils dilated in terror. His eyes had slid from 
Roberto’s face to something else. His own silver fingers were moving inexorably toward 
his own throat. 

“No –“ 

Without pausing to think, Roberto tried to drag back the hand, but there was no 
stopping it. The silver tool that Salvador had given his most cowardly servant had 
turned upon its disarmed and useless owner; Salazar was reaping his reward for his 
hesitation, his moment of pity; he was being strangled before their eyes. 

“No!” 

Diego had released Wormtail too, and together he and Roberto tried to pull the 
crushing metal fingers from around Wormtail’s throat, but it was no use. Salazar was 
turning blue. 

“Relashio!” said Diego, pointing the wand at the silver hand, but nothing happened; 
Salazar dropped to his knees, and at the same moment, Carolina gave a dreadful 
scream from overhead. Wormtail’s eyes rolled upward in his purple face; he gave a last 
twitch, and was still. 

Roberto and Diego looked at each other, then leaving Wormtail’s body on the floor 
behind them, ran up the stairs and back into the shadowy passageway leading to the 
drawing room. Cautiously they crept along it until they reached the drawing room door, 
which was ajar. Now they had a clear view of Miranda looking down at Griphook, who 
was holding Gryffindor’s sword in his long-fingered hands. Carolina was lying at 
Miranda’s feet. She was barely stirring. 

“Well?” Miranda said to Griphook. “Is it the true sword?” 

Roberto waited, holding his breath, fighting against the prickling of his scar. 

“No,” said Griphook. “It is a fake.” 

“Are you sure?” panted Miranda. “Quite sure?” 

“Yes,” said the goblin. 

Relief broke across her face, all tension drained from it. 

“Good,” she said, and with a casual flick of her wand she slashed another deep cut 
into the goblin’s face, and he dropped with a yell at her feet. She kicked him aside. “And 
now,” she said in a voice that burst with triumph, “we call the Dark Lord!” 

And she pushed back her sleeve and touched her forefinger to the Dark Mark. 

At once, Roberto’s scar felt as though it had split open again. His true surroundings 
vanished: He was Salvador, and the skeletal wizard before him was laughing 


toothlessly at him; he was enraged at the summons he felt – he had warned them, he had 
told them to summon him for nothing less than Gonzales. If they were mistaken . . . 

“Kill me, then!” demanded the old man. “You will not win, you cannot win! That 
wand will never, ever be yours –“ 

And Salvador’s fury broke: A burst of green light filled the prison room and the 
frail old body was lifted from its hard bed and then fell back, lifeless, and Salvador 
returned to the window, his wrath barely controllable. . . . They would suffer his 
retribution if they had no good reason for calling him back. . . . 

“And I think,” said Miranda’s voice, “we can dispose of the Mudblood. Greyback, 
take her if you want her.” 

“NOOOOOOOOOOOO!” 

Diego had burst into the drawing room; Miranda looked around, shocked; she 
turned her wand to face Diego instead – 

“Expelliarmus!” he roared, pointing Wormtail’s wand at Miranda, and hers flew 
into the air and was caught by Roberto, who had sprinted after Diego. Mariano, Julia, 
Javier and Greyback wheeled about; Roberto yelled, “Stupefy!” and Mariano Sosa 
collapsed onto the hearth. Jets of light flew from Javier’s, Julia’s, and Greyback’s 
wands; Roberto threw himself to the floor, rolling behind a sofa to avoid them. 

“STOP OR SHE DIES! 

Panting, Roberto peered around the edge of the sofa. Miranda was supporting 
Carolina, who seemed to be unconscious, and was holding her short silver knife to 
Carolina’s throat. 

“Drop your wands,” she whispered. “Drop them, or we’ll see exactly how filthy 
her blood is!” 

Diego stood rigid, clutching Wormtail’s wand. Roberto straightened up, still holding 
Miranda’s. 

“I said, drop them!” she screeched, pressing the blade into Carolina’s throat: 
Roberto saw beads of blood appear there. 

“All right!” he shouted, and he dropped Miranda’s wand onto the floor at his feet, 
Diego did the same with Wormtail’s. Both raised their hands to shoulder height. 

“Good!” she leered. “Javier, pick them up! The Dark Lord is coming, Roberto 
Gonzales! Your death approaches!” 

Roberto knew it; his scar was bursting with the pain of it, and he could feel 
Salvador flying through the sky from far away, over a dark and stormy sea, and soon he 
would be close enough to Apparate to them, and Roberto could see no way out. 

“Now,” said Miranda softly, as Javier hurried back to her with the wands. “Cissy, 
I think we ought to tie these little heroes up again, while Greyback takes care of Miss 
Mudblood. I am sure the Dark Lord will not begrudge you the girl, Greyback, after what 
you have done tonight.” 

At the last word there was a peculiar grinding noise from above. All of them 
looked upward in time to see the crystal chandelier tremble; then, with a creak and an 
ominous jingling, it began to fall. Miranda was directly beneath it; dropping Carolina, 
she threw herself aside with a scream. The chandelier crashed to the floor in an explosion 
of crystal and chains, falling on top of Carolina and the goblin, who still clutched the 
sword of Gryffindor. Glittering shards of crystal flew in all directions; Javier doubled 
over, his hands covering his bloody face. 


As Diego ran to pull Carolina out of the wreckage, Roberto took the chance: He 
leapt over an armchair and wrested the three wands from Javier’s grip, pointed all of 
them at Greyback, and yelled, “Stupefy!” The werewolf was lifted off his feet by the 
triple spell, flew up to the ceiling and then smashed to the ground. 

As Julia dragged Javier out of the way of further harm, Miranda sprang to her 
feet, her hair flying as she brandished the silver knife; but Julia had directed her wand 
at the doorway. 

“Dobby!” she screamed and even Miranda froze. “You! You dropped the 
chandelier – ?” 

The tiny elf trotted into the room, his shaking finger pointing at his old mistress. 

“You must not hurt Roberto Gonzales,” he squeaked. 

“Kill him, Cissy!” shrieked Miranda, but there was another loud crack, and 
Julia’s wand too flew into the air and landed on the other side of the room. 

“You dirty little monkey!” bawled Miranda. “How dare you take a witch’s wand, 
how dare you defy your masters?” 

“Dobby has no master!” squealed the elf. “Dobby is a free elf, and Dobby has 
come to save Roberto Gonzales and his friends!” 

Roberto’s scar was blinding him with pain. Dimly he knew that they had moments, 
seconds before Salvador was with them. 

“Diego, catch – and GO!” he yelled, throwing one of the wands to him; then he bent 
down to tug Griphook out from under the chandelier. Hoisting the groaning goblin, who 
still clung to the sword, over one shoulder, Roberto seized Dobby’s hand and spun on the 
spot to Disapparate. 

As he turned into darkness he caught one last view of the drawing room of the 
pale, frozen figures of Julia and Javier, of the streak of red that was Diego’s hair, and a 
blue of flying silver, as Miranda’s knife flew across the room at the place where he was 
vanishing – 

Bill and Camila’s . . . Shell Cottage . . . Bill and Camila’s . . . 

He had disappeared into the unknown; all he could do was repeat the name of the 
destination and hope that it would suffice to take him there. The pain in his forehead 
pierced him, and the weight of the goblin bore down upon him; he could feel the blade of 
Gryffindor’s sword bumping against his back: Dobby’s hand jerked in his; he wondered 
whether the elf was trying to take charge, to pull them in the right direction, and tried, by 
squeezing the fingers, to indicate that that was fine with them. . . . 

And then they hit solid earth and smelled salty air. Roberto fell to his knees, 
relinquished Dobby’s hand, and attempted to lower Griphook gently to the ground. 

“Are you all right?” he said as the goblin stirred, but Griphook merely whimpered. 

Roberto squinted around through the darkness. There seemed to be a cottage a short 
way away under the wide starry sky, and he thought he saw movement outside it. 

“Dobby, is this Shell Cottage?” he whispered, clutching the two wands he had 
brought from the Sosas’, ready to fight if he needed to. “Have we come to the right 
place? Dobby?” 

He looked around. The little elf stood feet from him. 

“DOBBY!” 

The elf swayed slightly, stars reflected in his wide, shining eyes. Together, he and 
Roberto looked down at the silver hilt of the knife protruding from the elf’s heaving chest. 


“Dobby – no – HELP!” Roberto bellowed toward the cottage, toward the people 
moving there. “HELP!” 

He did not know or care whether they were wizards or Muggles, friends or foes; 
all he cared about was that a dark stain was spreading across Dobby’s front, and that he 
had stretched out his own arms to Roberto with a look of supplication. Roberto caught him 
and laid him sideways on the cool grass. 

“Dobby, no, don’t die, don’t die –“ 

The elf’s eyes found him, and his lips trembled with the effort to form words. 

“Roberto . . . Gonzales . . .” 

And then with a little shudder the elf became quite still, and his eyes were nothing 
more than great glassy orbs, sprinkled with light from the stars they could not see.” 


 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Chapter Twenty-Four 

The Wandmaker 

 

It was like sinking into an old nightmare; for an instant Roberto knelt again beside 
Dominguez’s body at the foot of the tallest tower at Hogwarts, but in reality he was 
staring at a tiny body curled upon the grass, pierced by Miranda’s silver knife. Roberto’s 
voice was still saying, “Dobby…Dobby…” even though he knew that the elf had gone 
where he could not call him back. 

 After a minute or so he realized that they had, after all, come to the right place, for 
here were Bill and Camila, Dean and Gabriela, gathering around him as he knelt over the elf. 
“Carolina,” he said suddenly. “Where is she?” 

“Diego’s taken her inside,” said Bill. “She’ll be all right.” Roberto looked back down at 
Dobby. He stretched out a hand and pulled the sharp blade from the elf’s body, then 
dragged off his own jacket and covered Dobby in it like a blanket. 

 The sea was rushing against the rock somewhere nearby; Roberto listened to it 
while the others talked, discussing matters in which he could take no interest, making 
decisions, Dean carried the injured Griphook into the house, Camila hurrying with them; 
now Bill was really knowing what he was saying. As he did so, he gazed down at the 
tiny body, and his scar prickled and burned, and in one part of his mind, viewed as if 
from the wrong end of a long telescope, he saw Salvador punishing those they had left 
behind at the Sosa Manor. His rage was dreadful and yet Roberto’s grief for Dobby 
seemed to diminish it, so that it became a distant storm that reached Roberto from across a 
vast, silent ocean. 


 “I want to do it properly,” were the first words of which Roberto was fully 
conscious of speaking. “Not by magic. Have you got a spade?” And shortly afterward he 
had set to work, alone, digging the grave in the place that Bill had shown him at the end 
of the garden, between bushes. He dug with a kind of fury, relishing the manual work, 
glorying in the non-magic of it, for every drop of his sweat and every blister felt like a 
gift to the elf who had saved their lives. 

 His scar burned, but he was master of the pain, he felt it, yet was apart from it.
