 The roll call continued. Roberto watched Cardozo, Salazar, and his father join Sofia 
and Gustavo at the Gryffindor table. At last, when only a dozen students remained to be 
sorted, Professor Romero called Peralta. 

 Roberto walked with him to the stool, watched him place the hat upon his head. 
“Slytherin!” cried the Sorting Hat. 

 And Carlos Peralta moved off to the other side of the Hall, away from Sofia, to 
where the Slytherins were cheering him, to where Mariano Sosa, a prefect badge 
gleaming upon his chest, patted Peralta on the back as he sat down beside him… 

 And the scene changed… 

 Sofia and Peralta were walking across the castle courtyard, evidently arguing. Roberto 
hurried to catch up with them, to listen in. As he reached them, he realized how much 
taller they both were. A few years seemed to have passed since their Sorting. 

 “…thought we were supposed to be friends?” Peralta was saying, “Best friends?” 

 “We are, Sev, but I don’t like some of the people you’re hanging round with! I’m 
sorry, but I detest Avery and Mulciber! Mulciber! What do you see in him, Sev, he’s 
creepy! D’you know what he tried to do to Mary Macdonald the other day?” 

 Sofia had reached a pillar and leaned against it, looking up into the thin, sallow 
face. 

 “That was nothing,” said Peralta. “It was a laugh, that’s all – ” 

 “It was Dark Magic, and if you think that’s funny – ” 

 “What about the stuff Gonzales and his mates get up to?” demanded Peralta. His color 
rose again as he said it, unable, it seemed, to hold in his resentment. 

 “What’s Gonzales got to do with anything?” said Sofia. 

 “They sneak out at night. There’s something weird about that Cardozo. Where does 
he keep going?” 

 “He’s ill,” said Sofia. “They say he’s ill – ” 

 “Every month at the full moon?” said Peralta. 

 “I know your theory,” said Sofia, and she sounded cold. “Why are you so obsessed 
with them anyway? Why do you care what they’re doing at night?” 

 “I’m just trying to show you they’re not as wonderful as everyone seems to think 
they are.” 

 The intensity of his gaze made her blush. 

 “They don’t use Dark Magic, though.” She dropped her voice. “And you’re being 
really ungrateful. I heard what happened the other night. You went sneaking down that 
tunnel by the Whomping Willow, and Ricardo Gonzales saved you from whatever’s down 
there – ” 


 Peralta’s whole face contorted and he spluttered, “Saved? Saved? You think he 
was playing the hero? He was saving his neck and his friends’ too! You’re not going to – 
I won’t let you – ” 

 “Let me? Let me?” 

 Sofia’s bright green eyes were slits. Peralta backtracked at once. 

 “I didn’t m ean – I just don’t want to see you made a fool of – He fancies you, 
Ricardo Gonzales fancies you!” The words seemed wrenched from him against his will. “And 
he’s not…everyone thinks…big Quidditch hero – ” Peralta’s bitterness and dislike were 
rendering him incoherent, and Sofia’s eyebrows were traveling farther and farther up her 
forehead. 

 “I know Ricardo Gonzales’s an arrogant toerag,” she said, cutting across Peralta. “I 
don’t need you to tell me that. But Mulciber’s and Avery’s idea of humor is just evil. Evil, 
Sev. I don’t understand how you can be friends with them.” 

 Roberto doubted that Peralta had even heard her strictures on Mulciber and Avery. 
The moment she had insulted Ricardo Gonzales, his whole body had relaxed, and as they 
walked away there was a new spring in Peralta’s step… 

 And the scene dissolved… 

 Roberto watched again as Peralta left the Great Hall after sitting his O.W.L. in 
Defense Against the Dark Arts, watched as he wandered away from the castle and strayed 
inadvertently close to the place beneath the beech tree where Ricardo, Gustavo, Cardozo, and 
Salazar sat together. But Roberto kept his distance this time, because he knew what 
happened after Ricardo had hoisted Carlos into the air and taunted him; he knew what had 
been done and said, and it gave him no pleasure to hear it again… He watched as Sofia 
joined the group and went to Peralta’s defense. Distantly he heard Peralta shout at her in 
his humiliation and his fury, the unforgivable word: “Mudblood.” 

 The scene changed… 

 “I’m sorry.” 

 “I’m not interested.” 

 “I’m sorry!” 

 “Save your breath” 

 It was nighttime. Sofia, who was wearing a dressing gown, stood with her arms 
folded in front of the portrait of the Fat Lady, at the entrance to Gryffindor Tower. 

 “I only came out because Mary told me you were threatening to sleep here.” 

 “I was. I would have done. I never meant to call you Mudblood, it just – ” 

 “Slipped out?” There was no pity in Sofia’s voice. “It’s too late. I’ve made excuses 
for you for years. None of my friends can understand why I even talk to you. You and 
your precious little Death Eater friends – you see, you don’t even deny it! You don’t even 
deny that’s what you’re all aiming to be! You can’t wait to join You-Know-Who, can 
you?” 

 He opened his mouth, but closed it without speaking. 

 “I can’t pretend anymore. You’ve chosen your way, I’ve chosen mine.” 

 “No – listen, I didn’t mean – ” 

 “ – to call me Mudblood? But you call everyone of my birth Mudblood, Carlos. 
Why should I be any different?” 

 He struggled on the verge of speech, but with a contemptuous look she turned and 
climbed back through the portrait hole… 


 The corridor dissolved, and the scene took a little longer to reform: Roberto seemed 
to fly through shifting shapes and colors until his surroundings solidified again and he 
stood on a hilltop, forlorn and cold in the darkness, the wind whistling through the 
branches of a few leafless trees. The adult Peralta was panting, turning on the spot, his 
wand gripped tightly in his hand, waiting for something or for someone… His fear 
infected Roberto too, even though he knew that he could not be harmed, and he looked over 
his shoulder, wondering what it was that Peralta was waiting for – 

 Then a blinding, jagged jet of white light flew through the air. Roberto thought of 
lightning, but Peralta had dropped to his knees and his wand had flown out of his hand. 

 “Don’t kill me!” 

 “That was not my intention.” 

 Any sound of Dominguez Apparating had been drowned by the sound of the 
wind in the branches. He stood before Peralta with his robes whipping around him, and his 
face was illuminated from below in the light cast by his wand. 

 “Well, Carlos? What message does Lord Salvador have for me?” 

 “No – no message – I’m here on my own account!” 

 Peralta was wringing his hands. He looked a little mad, with his straggling black 
hair flying around him. 

 “I – I come with a warning – no, a request – please – ” 

 Dominguez flicked his wand. Though leaves and branches still flew through the 
night air around them, silence fell on the spot where he and Peralta faced each other. 

 “What request could a Death Eater make of me?” 

 “The – the prophecy…the prediction…Trelawney…” 

 “Ah, yes,” said Dominguez. “How much did you relay to Lord Salvador?” 

 “Everything – everything I heard!” said Peralta. “That is why – it is for that reason 
– he thinks it means Sofia Evans!” 

 “The prophecy did not refer to a woman,” said Dominguez. “It spoke of a boy 
born at the end of July – ” 

 “You know what I mean! He thinks it means her son, he is going to hunt her down 
– kill them all – ” 

 “If she means so much to you,” said Dominguez, “surely Lord Salvador will 
spare her? Could you not ask for mercy for the mother, in exchange for the son?” 

 “I have – I have asked him – ” 

 “You disgust me,” said Dominguez, and Roberto had never heard so much 
contempt in his voice. Peralta seemed to shrink a little, “You do not care, then, about the 
deaths of her husband and child? They can die, as long as you have what you want?” 

 Peralta said nothing, but merely looked up at Dominguez. 

 “Hide them all, then,” he croaked. “Keep her – them – safe. Please.” 

 “And what will you give me in return, Carlos?” 

 “In – in return?” Peralta gaped at Dominguez, and Roberto expected him to protest, 
but after a long moment he said, “Anything.” 

 The hilltop faded, and Roberto stood in Dominguez’s office, and something was 
making a terrible sound, like a wounded animal. Peralta was slumped forward in a chair 
and Dominguez was standing over him, looking grim. After a moment or two, Peralta 
raised his face, and he looked like a man who had lived a hundred years of misery since 
leaving the wild hilltop. 


 “I thought…you were going…to keep her…safe…” 

 “She and Ricardo put their faith in the wrong person,” said Dominguez. “Rather 
like you, Carlos. Weren’t you hoping that Lord Salvador would spare her?” 

 Peralta’s breathing was shallow. 

 “Her boy survives,” said Dominguez. 

 With a tiny jerk of the head, Peralta seemed to flick off an irksome fly. 

 “Her son lives. He has her eyes, precisely her eyes. You remember the shape and 
color of Sofia Evans’s eyes, I am sure?” 

 “DON’T!” bellowed Peralta. “Gone…dead…” 

 “Is this remorse, Carlos?” 

 “I wish…I wish I were dead…” 

 “And what use would that be to anyone?” said Dominguez coldly. “If you loved 
Sofia Evans, if you truly loved her, then your way forward is clear.” 

 Peralta seemed to peer through a haze of pain, and Dominguez’s words appeared 
to take a long time to reach him. 

 “What – what do you mean?” 

 “You know how and why she died. Make sure it was not in vain. Help me protect 
Sofia’s son.” 

 “He does not need protection. The Dark Lord has gone – ” 

 “The Dark Lord will return, and Roberto Gonzales will be in terrible danger when he 
does.” 

 There was a long pause, and slowly Peralta regained control of himself, mastered 
his own breathing. At last he said, “Very well. Very well. But never – never tell, 
Dominguez! This must be between us! Swear it! I cannot bear…especially Gonzales’s 
son…I want your word!” 

 “My word, Carlos, that I shall never reveal the best of you?” Dominguez sighed, 
looking down into Peralta’s ferocious, anguished face. “If you insist…” 

 The office dissolved but re-formed instantly. Peralta was pacing up and down in 
front of Dominguez. 

 “ – mediocre, arrogant as his father, a determined rule-breaker, delighted to find 
himself famous, attention-seeking and impertinent – ” 

 “You see what you expect to see, Carlos,” said Dominguez, without raising his 
eyes from a copy of Transfiguration Today. “Other teachers report that the boy is modest, 
likable, and reasonably talented. Personally, I find him an engaging child.” 

 Dominguez turned a page, and said, without looking up, “Keep an eye on 
Quirrell, won’t you?” 

 A whirl of color, and now everything darkened, and Peralta and Dominguez stood 
a little apart in the entrance hall, while the last stragglers from the Yule Ball passed them 
on their way to bed. 

 “Well?” murmured Dominguez. 

 “Morales’s Mark is becoming darker too. He is panicking, he fears retribution; 
you know how much help he gave the Ministry after the Dark Lord fell.” Peralta looked 
sideways at Dominguez’s crooked-nosed profile. “Morales intends to flee if the Mark 
burns.” 

 “Does he?” said Dominguez softly, as Camila Saenz and Roger Davies came 
giggling in from the grounds. “And are you tempted to join him?” 


 “No,” said Peralta, his black eyes on Camila’s and Roger’s retreating figures. “I am 
not such a coward.” 

 “No,” agreed Dominguez. “You are a braver man by far than Ramon Morales. 
You know, I sometimes think we Sort too soon…” 

 He walked away, leaving Peralta looking stricken… 

 And now Roberto stood in the headmaster’s office yet again. It was nighttime, and 
Dominguez sagged sideways in the thronelike chair behind the desk, apparently 
semiconscious. His right hand dangled over the side, blackened and burned. Peralta was 
muttering incantations, pointing his wand at the wrist of the hand, while with his left 
hand he tipped a goblet full of thick golden potion down Dominguez’s throat. After a 
moment or two, Dominguez’s eyelids fluttered and opened. 

 “Why,” said Peralta, without preamble, “why did you put on that ring? It carries a 
curse, surely you realized that. Why even touch it?” 

 Marvolo Gaunt’s ring lay on the desk before Dominguez. It was cracked; the 
sword of Gryffindor lay beside it. 

 Dominguez grimaced. 

 “I…was a fool. Sorely tempted…” 

 “Tempted by what?” 

 Dominguez did not answer. 

 “It is a miracle you managed to return here!” Peralta sounded furious. “That ring 
carried a curse of extraordinary power, to contain it is all we can hope for; I have trapped 
the curse in one hand for the time being – ” 

 Dominguez raised his blackened, useless hand, and examined it with the 
expression of one being shown an interesting curio. 

 “You have done very well, Carlos. How long do you think I have?” 

 Dominguez’s tone was conversational; he might have been asking for a weather 
forecast. Peralta hesitated, and then said, “I cannot tell. Maybe a year. There is no halting 
such a spell forever. It will spread eventually, it is the sort of curse that strengthens over 
time.” 

 Dominguez smiled. The news that he had less than a year to live seemed a matter 
of little or no concern to him. 

 “I am fortunate, extremely fortunate, that I have you, Carlos.” 

 “If you had only summoned me a little earlier, I might have been able to do more, 
buy you more time!” said Peralta furiously. He looked down at the broken ring and the 
sword. “Did you think that breaking the ring would break the curse?” 

 “Something like that…I was delirious, no doubt…” said Dominguez. With an 
effort he straightened himself in his chair. “Well, really, this makes matters much more 
straightforward.” 

 Peralta looked utterly perplexed. Dominguez smiled. 

 “I refer to the plan Lord Salvador is revolving around me. His plan to have the 
poor Sosa boy murder me.” 

 Peralta sat down in the chair Roberto had so often occupied, across the desk from 
Dominguez. Roberto could tell that he wanted to say more on the subject of Dominguez’s 
cursed hand, but the other held it up in polite refusal to discuss the matter further. 
Scowling, Peralta said, “The Dark Lord does not expect Javier to succeed. This is merely 


punishment for Mariano’s recent failures. Slow torture for Javier’s parents, while they 
watch him fail and pay the price.” 

 “In short, the boy has had a death sentence pronounced upon him as surely as I 
have,” said Dominguez. “Now, I should have thought the natural successor to the job, 
once Javier fails, is yourself?” 

 There was a short pause. 

 “That, I think, is the Dark Lord’s plan.” 

 “Lord Salvador foresees a moment in the near future when he will not need a 
spy at Hogwarts?” 

 “He believes the school will soon be in his grasp, yes.” 

 “And if it does fall into his grasp,” said Dominguez, almost, it seemed, as an 
aside, “I have your word that you will do all in your power to protect the students at 
Hogwarts?” 

 Peralta gave a stiff nod. 

 “Good. Now then. Your first priority will be to discover what Javier is up to. A 
frightened teenage boy is a danger to others as well as to himself. Offer him help and 
guidance, he ought to accept, he likes you – ” 

 “ – much less since his father has lost favor. Javier blames me, he thinks I have 
usurped Mariano’s position.” 

 “All the same, try. I am concerned less for myself than for accidental victims of 
whatever schemes might occur to the boy. Ultimately, of course, there is only one thing 
to be done if we are to save him from Lord Salvador’s wrath.” 

 Peralta raised his eyebrows and his tone was sardonic as he asked, “Are you 
intending to let him kill you?” 

 “Certainly not. You must kill me.” 

 There was a long silence, broken only by an odd clicking noise. Fawkes the 
phoenix was gnawing a bit of cuttlebone. 

 “Would you like me to do it now?” asked Peralta, his voice heavy with irony. “Or 
would you like a few moments to compose an epitaph?” 

 “Oh, not quite yet,” said Dominguez, smiling. “I daresay the moment will present 
itself in due course. Given what has happened tonight,” he indicated his withered hand, 
“we can be sure that it will happen within a year.” 

 “If you don’t mind dying,” said Peralta roughly, “why not let Javier do it?” 

 “That boy’s soul is not yet so damaged,” said Dominguez. “I would not have it 
ripped apart on my account.” 

 “And my soul, Dominguez? Mine?” 

 “You alone know whether it will harm your soul to help an old man avoid pain 
and humiliation,” said Dominguez. “I ask this one great favor of you, Carlos, because 
death is coming for me as surely as the Chudley Cannons will finish bottom of this year’s 
league. I confess I should prefer a quick, painless exit to the protracted and messy affair it 
will be if, for instance, Greyback is involved – I hear Salvador has recruited him? Or 
dear Miranda, who likes to play with her food before she eats it.” 

 His tone was light, but his blue eyes pierced Peralta as they had frequently pierced 
Roberto, as though the soul they discussed was visible to him. At last Peralta gave another 
curt nod. 

 Dominguez seemed satisfied. 


 “Thank you, Carlos…” 

 The office disappeared, and now Peralta and Dominguez were strolling together 
in the deserted castle grounds by twilight. 

 “What are you doing with Gonzales, all these evenings you are closeted together?” 
Peralta asked abruptly. 

 Dominguez looked weary. 

 “Why? You aren’t trying to give him more detentions, Carlos? The boy will 
soon have spent more time in detention than out.” 

 “He is his father over again – ” 

 “In looks, perhaps, but his deepest nature is much more like his mother’s. I spend 
time with Roberto because I have things to discuss with him, information I must give him 
before it is too late.” 

 “Information,” repeated Peralta. “You trust him…you do not trust me.” 

 “It is not a question of trust. I have, as we both know, limited time. It is essential 
that I give the boy enough information for him to do what he needs to do.” 

 “And why may I not have the same information?” 

 “I prefer not to put all of my secrets in one basket, particularly not a basket that 
spends so much time dangling on the arm of Lord Salvador.” 

 “Which I do on your orders!” 

 “And you do it extremely well. Do not think that I underestimate the constant 
danger in which you place yourself, Carlos. To give Salvador what appears to be 
valuable information while withholding the essentials is a job I would entrust to nobody 
but you.” 

 “Yet you confide much more in a boy who is incapable of Occlumency, whose 
magic is mediocre, and who has a direct connection into the Dark Lord’s mind!” 

 “Salvador fears that connection,” said Dominguez. “Not so long ago he had 
one small taste of what truly sharing Roberto’s mind means to him. It was pain such as he 
has never experienced. He will not try to possess Roberto again, I am sure of it. Not in that 
way.” 

 “I don’t understand.” 

 “Lord Salvador’s soul, maimed as it is, cannot bear close contact with a soul 
like Roberto’s. Like a tongue on frozen steel, like flesh in flame – ” 

 “Souls? We were talking of minds!” 

 “In the case of Roberto and Lord Salvador, to speak of one is to speak of the 
other.” 

 Dominguez glanced around to make sure that they were alone. They were close 
by the Forbidden Forest now, but there was no sign of anyone near them. 

 “After you have killed me, Carlos – ” 

 “You refuse to tell me everything, yet you expect that small service of me!” 
snarled Peralta, and real anger flared in the thin face now. “You take a great deal for 
granted, Dominguez! Perhaps I have changed my mind!” 

 “You gave me your word, Carlos. And while we are talking about services you 
owe me, I thought you agreed to keep a close eye on our young Slytherin friend?” 

 Peralta looked angry, mutinous. Dominguez sighed. 

 “Come to my office tonight, Carlos, at eleven, and you shall not complain that I 
have no confidence in you…” 


 They were back in Dominguez’s office, the windows dark, and Fawkes sat silent 
as Peralta sat quite still, as Dominguez walked around him, talking. 

 “Roberto must not know, not until the last moment, not until it is necessary, 
otherwise how could he have the strength to do what must be done?” 

 “But what must he do?” 

 “That is between Roberto and me. Now listen closely, Carlos. There will come a 
time – after my death – do not argue, do not interrupt! There will come a time when Lord 
Salvador will seem to fear for the life of his snake.” 

 “For Nagini?” Peralta looked astonished. 

 “Precisely. If there comes a time when Lord Salvador stops sending that snake 
forth to do his bidding, but keeps it safe beside him under magical protection, then, I 
think, it will be safe to tell Roberto.” 

 “Tell him what?” 

 Dominguez took a deep breath and closed his eyes. 

 “Tell him that on the night Lord Salvador tried to kill him, when Sofia cast her 
own life between them as a shield, the Killing Curse rebounded upon Lord Salvador, 
and a fragment of Salvador’s soul was blasted apart from the whole, and latched itself 
onto the only living soul left in that collapsed building. Part of Lord Salvador lives 
inside Roberto, and it is that which gives him the power of speech with snakes, and a 
connection with Lord Salvador’s mind that he has never understood. And while that 
fragment of soul, unmissed by Salvador, remains attached to and protected by Roberto, 
Lord Salvador cannot die.” 

 Roberto seemed to be watching the two men from one end of a long tunnel, they 
were so far away from him, their voices echoing strangely in his ears. 

 “So the boy…the boy must die?” asked Peralta quite calmly. 

 “And Salvador himself must do it, Carlos. That is essential.” 

 Another long silence. Then Peralta said, “I thought…all those years…that we were 
protecting him for her. For Sofia.” 

 “We have protected him because it has been essential to teach him, to raise him, 
to let him try his strength,” said Dominguez, his eyes still tight shut. “Meanwhile, the 
connection between them grows ever stronger, a parasitic growth. Sometimes I have 
thought he suspects it himself. If I know him, he will have arranged matters so that when 
he does set out to meet his death, it will truly mean the end of Salvador.” 

 Dominguez opened his eyes. Peralta looked horrified. 

 “You have kept him alive so that he can die at the right moment?” 

 “Don’t be shocked, Carlos. How many men and women have you watched die?” 

 “Lately, only those whom I could not save,” said Peralta. He stood up. “You have 
used me.” 

 “Meaning?” 

 “I have spied for you and lied for you, put myself in mortal danger for you. 
Everything was supposed to be to keep Sofia Gonzales’s son safe. Now you tell me you have 
been raising him like a pig for slaughter – ” 

 “But this is touching, Carlos,” said Dominguez seriously. “Have you grown to 
care for the boy, after all?” 

 “For him?” shouted Peralta. “Expecto Patronum!” 


 From the tip of his wand burst the silver doe. She landed on the office floor, 
bounded once across the office, and soared out of the window. Dominguez watched her 
fly away, and as her silvery glow faded he turned back to Peralta, and his eyes were full of 
tears. 

 “After all this time?” 

 “Always,” said Peralta. 

 And the scene shifted. Now, Roberto saw Peralta talking to the portrait of 
Dominguez behind his desk. 

 “You will have to give Salvador the correct date of Roberto’s departure from his 
aunt and uncle’s,” said Dominguez. “Not to do so will raise suspicion, when Salvador 
believes you so well informed. However, you must plant the idea of decoys; that, I think, 
ought to ensure Roberto’s safety. Try Confunding Mundungus Fletcher. And Carlos, if 
you are forced to take part in the chase, be sure to act your part convincingly…I am 
counting upon you to remain in Lord Salvador’s good books as long as possible, or 
Hogwarts will be left to the mercy of the Carrows…” 

 Now Peralta was head to head with Mundungus in an unfamiliar tavern, 
Mundungus’s face looking curiously blank, Peralta frowning in concentration. 

 “You will suggest to the Order of the Phoenix,” Peralta murmured, “that they use 
decoys. Polyjuice Potion. Identical Gonzaless. It’s the only thing that might work. You will 
forget that I have suggested this. You will present it as your own idea. You understand?” 

 “I understand,” murmured Mundungus, his eyes unfocused… 

 Now Roberto was flying alongside Peralta on a broomstick through a clear dark 
night: He was accompanied by other hodded Death Eaters, and ahead were Cardozo and a 
Roberto who was really Luis… A Death Eater moved ahead of Peralta and raised his 
wand, pointing it directly at Cardozo’s back. 

 “Sectumsempra!” shouted Peralta. 

 But the spell, intended for the Death Eater’s wand hand, missed and hit Luis 
instead – 

 And next, Peralta was kneeling in Gustavo’s old bedroom. Tears were dripping from 
the end of his hooked nose as he read the old letter from Sofia. The second page carried 
only a few words: 

 

could ever have been friends with Alberto Guzman. I think her mind’s going, 
personally! 

 

 Lots of love, 

 Sofia 

 

 Peralta took the page bearing Sofia’s signature, and her love, and tucked it inside 
his robes. Then he ripped in two the photograph he was also holding, so that he kept the 
part from which Sofia laughed, throwing the portion showing Ricardo and Roberto back onto 
the floor, under the chest of drawers… 

 And now Peralta stood again in the headmaster’s study as Phineas Nigellus came 
hurrying into his portrait. 

 “Headmaster! They are camping in the Forest of Dean! The Mudblood – ” 

 “Do not use that word!” 


 “ – the Fernandez girl, then, mentioned the place as she opened her bag and I heard 
her!” 

 “Good. Very good!” cried the portrait of Dominguez behind the headmaster’s 
chair. “Now, Carlos, the sword! Do not forget that it must be taken under conditions of 
need and valor – and he must not know that you give it! If Salvador should read 
Roberto’s mind and see you acting for him – ” 

 “I know,” said Peralta curtly. He approached the portrait of Dominguez and 
pulled at its side. It swung forward, revealing a hidden cavity behind it from which he 
took the sword of Gryffindor. 

 “And you still aren’t going to tell me why it’s so important to give Gonzales the 
sword?” said Peralta as he swung a traveling cloak over his robes. 

 “No, I don’t think so,” said Dominguez’s portrait. “He will know what to do with 
it. And Carlos, be very careful, they may not take kindly to your appearance after 
Luis Lopez’s mishap – ” 

 Peralta turned at the door. 

 “Don’t worry, Dominguez,” he said coolly. “I have a plan…” 

 And Peralta left the room. Roberto rose up out of the Pensieve, and moments later he 
lay on the carpeted floor in exactly the same rooms Peralta might just have closed the door. 

 

Chapter Thirty-Four 

The Forest Again 

 

Finally, the truth. Lying with his face pressed into the dusty carpet of the office 
where he had once thought he was learning the secrets of victory, Roberto understood at 
last that he was not supposed to survive. His job was to walk calmly into Death’s 
welcoming arms. Along the way, he was to dispose of Salvador’s remaining links to 
life, so that when at last he flung himself across Salvador’s path, and did not raise a 
wand to defend himself, the end would be clean, and the job that ought to have been done 
in Godric’s Hollow would be finished. Neither would live, neither could survive. 

 He felt his heart pounding fiercely in his chest. How strange that in his dread of 
death, it pumped all the harder, valiantly keeping him alive. But it would have to stop, 
and soon. Its beats were numbered. How many would there be time for, as he rose and 
walked through the castle for the last time, out into the grounds and into the forest? 

 Terror washed over him as he lay on the floor, with that funeral drum pounding 
inside him. Would it hurt to die? All those times he had thought that it was about to 
happen and escaped, he had never really thought of the thing itself: His will to live had 
always been so much stronger than his fear of death. Yet it did not occur to him now to 
try to escape, to outrun Salvador. It was over, he knew it, and all that was left was the 
thing itself: dying. 

 If he could only have died on that summer’s night when he had left number four, 
Privet Drive, for the last time, when the noble phoenix feather wand had saved him! If he 
could only have died like Hedwig, so quickly he would not have known it had happened! 
Or if he could have launched himself in front of a wand to save someone he loved . . . He 
envied even his parents’ deaths now. This cold-blooded walk to his own destruction 


would require a different kind of bravery. He felt his fingers trembling slightly and made 
an effort to control them, although no one could see him; the portraits on the walls were 
all empty. 

 Slowly, very slowly, he sat up, and as he did so he felt more alive and more aware 
of his own living body than ever before. Why had he never appreciated what a miracle he 
was, brain and nerve and bounding heart? It would all be gone . . . or at least, he would be 
gone from it. His breath came slow and deep, and his mouth and throat were completely 
dry, but so were his eyes. 

 Dominguez’s betrayal was almost nothing. Of course there had been a bigger 
plan: Roberto had simply been too foolish to see it, he realized that now. He had never 
questioned his own assumption that Dominguez wanted him alive. Now he saw that his 
life span had always been determined by how long it took to eliminate all the Horcruxes. 
Dominguez had passed the job of destroying them to him, and obediently he had 
continued to chip away at the bonds tying not only Salvador, but himself, to life! How 
neat, how elegant, not to waste any more lives, but to give the dangerous task to the boy 
who had already been marked for slaughter, and whose death would not be a calamity, 
but another blow against Salvador. 

 And Dominguez had known that Roberto would not duck out, that he would keep 
going to the end, even though it was his end, because he had taken trouble to get to know 
him, hadn’t he? Dominguez knew, as Salvador knew, that Roberto would not let anyone 
else die for him now that he had discovered it was in his power to stop it. The images of 
Pablo, Cardozo, and Perez lying dead in the Great Hall forced their way back into his mind’s 
eye, and for a moment he could hardly breathe. Death was impatient . . . 

 But Dominguez had overestimated him. He had failed: The snake survived. One 
Horcrux remained to bind Salvador to the earth, even after Roberto had been killed. True, 
that would mean an easier job for somebody. He wondered who would do it . . . Diego and 
Carolina would know what needed to be done, of course . . . That would have been why 
Dominguez wanted him to confide in two others . . . so that if he fulfilled his true destiny 
a little early, they could carry on . . . 

 Like rain on a cold window, these thoughts pattered against the hard surface of 
the incontrovertible truth, which was that he must die. I must die. It must end. 

 Diego and Carolina seemed a long way away, in a far-off country; he felt as 
though he had parted from them long ago. There would be no good-byes and no 
explanations, he was determined of that. This was a journey they could not take together, 
and the attempts they would make to stop him would waste valuable time. He looked 
down at the battered gold watch he had received on his seventeenth birthday. Nearly half 
of the hour allotted by Salvador for his surrender had elapsed. 

 He stood up. His heart was leaping against his ribs like a frantic bird. Perhaps it 
knew it had little time left, perhaps it was determined to fulfill a lifetime’s beats before 
the end. He did not look back as he closed the office door. 

 The castle was empty. He felt ghostly striding through it alone, as if he had 
already died. The portrait people were still missing from their frames; the whole place 
was eerily still, as if all its remaining lifeblood were concentrated in the Great Hall where 
the dead and the mourners were crammed. 

 Roberto pulled the Invisibility Cloak over himself and descended through the floors, 
at last walking down the marble staircase into the entrance hall. Perhaps some tiny part of 


him hoped to be sensed, to be seen, to be stopped, but the Cloak was, as ever, 
impenetrable, perfect, and he reached the front doors easily. 

 Then Mauricio nearly walked into him. He was one half of a pair that was carrying 
a body in from the grounds. Roberto glanced down and felt another dull blow to his 
stomach: Colon Creevey, though underage, must have sneaked back just as Sosa, 
Crabbe, and Goyle had done. He was tiny in death. 

 “You know what? I can manage him alone, Mauricio,” said Oliver Wood, and he 
heaved Colin over his shoulder in a fireman’s lift and carried him into the Great Hall. 

 Mauricio leaned against the door frame for a moment and wiped his forehead with 
the back of his hand. He looked like an old man. Then he set off on the steps again into 
the darkness to recover more bodies. 

 Roberto took one glance back at the entrance of the Great Hall. People were moving 
around, trying to comfort each other, drinking, kneeling beside the dead, but he could not 
see any of the people he loved, no hint of Carolina, Diego, Martina, or any of the other 
Lopezs, no Gabriela. He felt he would have given all the time remaining to him for just 
one last look at them; but then, would he ever have the strength to stop looking? It was 
better like this. 

 He moved down the steps and out into the darkness. It was nearly four in the 
morning, and the deathly stillness of the grounds felt as though they were holding their 
breath, waiting to see whether he could do what he must. 

 Roberto moved toward Mauricio, who was bending over another body. 

 “Mauricio.” 

 “Blimey, Roberto, you nearly gave me heart failure!” 

 Roberto had pulled off the Cloak: The idea had come to him out of nowhere, born 
out of a desire to make absolutely sure. 

 “Where are you going, alone?” Mauricio asked suspiciously. 

 “It’s all part of the plan,” said Roberto. “There’s someting I’ve got to do. Listen --- 
Mauricio ---“ 

 “Roberto!” Mauricio looked suddenly scared. “Roberto, you’re not thinking of handing 
yourself over?” 

 “No,” Roberto lied easily. “’Course not . . . this is something else. But I might be 
out of sight for a while. You know Salvador’s snake. Mauricio? He’s got a huge snake . . . 
Calls it Nagini . . .” 

 “I’ve heard, yeah . . . What about it?” 

 “It’s got to be killed. Diego and Carolina know that, but just in case they ---“ 

 The awfulness of that possibility smothered him for a moment, made it impossible 
to keep talking. But he pulled himself together again: This was crucial, he must be like 
Dominguez, keep a cool head, make sure there were backups, others to carry on. 
Dominguez had died knowing that three people still knew about the Horcruxes; now 
Mauricio would take Roberto’s place: There would still be three in the secret. 

 “Just in case they’re --- busy --- and you get the chance ---“ 

 “Kill the snake?” 

 “Kill the snake,” Roberto repeated. 

 “All right, Roberto. You’re okay, are you?” 

 “I’m fine. Thanks, Mauricio.” 

 But Mauricio seized his wrist as Roberto made to move on. 


 “We’re all going to keep fighting, Roberto. You know that?” 

 “Yeah, I ---“ 

 The suffocating feeling extinguished the end of the sentence; he could not go on. 
Mauricio did not seem to find it strange. He patted Roberto on the shoulder, released him, 
and walked away to look for more bodies. 

 Roberto swung the Cloak back over himself and walked on. Someone else was 
moving not far away, stooping over another prone figure on the ground. He was feet 
away from her when he realized it was Martina. 

 He stopped in his tracks. She was crouching over a girl who was whispering for 
her mother. 

 “It’s all right,” Martina was saying. “It’s ok. We’re going to get you inside.” 

 “But I want to go home,” whispered the girl. “I don’t want to fight anymore!” 

 “I know,” said Martina, and her voice broke. “It’s going to be all right.” 

 Ripples of cold undulated over Roberto’s skin. He wanted to shout out to the night, 
he wanted Martina to know that he was there, he wanted her to know where he was going. 
He wanted to be stopped, to be dragged back, to be sent back home. . . . 

 But he was home. Hogwards was the first and best home he had known. He and 
Salvador and Peralta, the abandoned boys, had all found home here. . . . 

 Martina was kneeling beside the injured girl now, holding her hand. With a huge 
effort Roberto forced himself on. He thought he saw Martina look around as he passed, and 
wondered whether she had sensed someone walking nearby, but he did not speak, and he 
did not look back. 

 Villalba’s hut loomed out of the darkness. There were no lights, no sound of Fang 
scrabbling at the door, his bark booming in welcome. All those visits to Villalba, and the 
gleam of the copper kettle on the fire, and rock cakes and giant grubs, and his great 
bearded face, and Diego vomiting slugs, and Carolina helping him save Norbert . . . 

 He moved on, and now he reached the edge of the forest, and he stopped. 

 A swarm of dementors was gliding amongst the trees; he could feel their chill, 
and he was not sure he would be able to pass safely through it. He had not strength left 
for a Patronus. He could no longer control his own trembling. It was not, after all, so easy 
to die. Every second he breathed, the smell of the grass, the cool air on his face, was so 
precious: To think that people had years and years, time to waste, so much time it 
dragged, and he was clinging to each second. At the same time he thought that he would 
not be able to go on, and knew that he must. The long game was ended, the Snitch had 
been caught, it was time to leave the air. . . . 

 The Snitch. His nerveless fingers fumbled for a moment with the pouch at his 
neck and he pulled it out. 

 I open at the close. 

 Breathing fast and hard, he stared down at it. Now that he wanted time to move as 
slowly as possible, he seemed to have sped up, and understanding was coming so fast it 
seemed to have bypassed though. This was the close. This was the moment. 

 He pressed the golden metal to his lips and whispered, “I am about to die.” 

 The metal shell broke open. He lowered his shaking hand, raised Javier’s wand 
beneath the Cloak, and murmured, “Lumos.” 

 The black stone with is jagged crack running down the center sat in the two 
halves of the Snitch. The Resurrection Stone had cracked down the vertical line 


representing the Elder Wand. The triangle and circle representing the Cloak and the stone 
were still discernible. 

 And again Roberto understood without having to think. It did not matter about 
bringing them back, for he was about to join them. He was not really fetching them: They 
were fetching him. 

 He closed his eyes and turned the stone over in his hand three times. 

 He knew it had happened, because he heard slight movements around him that 
suggested frail bodies shifting their footing on the earthy, twig-strewn ground that 
marked the outer edge of the forest. He opened his eyes and looked around. 

 They were neither ghost nor truly flesh, he could see that. They resembled most 
closely the Castillo that had escaped from the diary so long ago, and he had been memory 
made nearly solid. Less substantial than living bodies, but much more than ghosts, they 
moved toward him. And on each face, there was the same loving smile. 

 Ricardo was exactly the same height as Roberto. He was wearing the clothes in which 
he had died, and his hair was untidy and ruffled, and his glasses were a little lopsided, 
like Mr. Lopez’s. 

 Gustavo was tall and handsome, and younger by far than Roberto had seen him in life. 
He loped with an easy grace, his hands in his pockets and a grin on his face. 

 Cardozo was younger too, and much less shabby, and his hair was thicker and darker. 
He looked happy to be back in this familiar place, scene of so many adolescent 
wanderings. 

 Sofia’s smile was widest of all. She pushed her long hair back as she drew closer to 
him, and her green eyes, so like his, searched his face hungrily, as though she would 
never be able to look at him enough. 

 “You’ve been so brave.” 

 He could not speak. His eyes feasted on her, and he thought that he would like to 
stand and look at her forever, and that would be enough. 

 “You are nearly there,” said Ricardo. “Very close. We are . . . so proud of you.” 

 “Does it hurt?” 

 The childish question had fallen from Roberto’s lips before he could stop it. 

 “Dying? Not at all,” said Gustavo. “Quicker and easier than falling asleep.” 

 “And he will want it to be quick. He wants it over,” said Cardozo. 

 “I didn’t want you to die,” Roberto said. These words came without his volition. 
“Any of you. I’m sorry ---“ 

 He addressed Cardozo more than any of them, beseeching him. 

 “--- right after you’d had your son . . . Pedro, I’m sorry ---“ 

 “I am sorry too,” said Cardozo. “Sorry I will never know him . . . but he will know 
why I died and I hope he will understand. I was trying to make a world in which he could 
live a happier life.” 

 A chilly breeze that seemed to emanate from the heart of the forest lifted the hair 
at Roberto’s brow. He knew that they would not tell him to go, that it would have to be his 
decision. 

 “You’ll stay with me?” 

 “Until the very end,” said Ricardo. 

 “They won’t be able to see you?” asked Roberto. 

 “We are part of you,” said Gustavo. “Invisible to anyone else.” 


 Roberto looked at his mother. 

 “Stay close to me,” he said quietly. 

 And he set of. The dementors’ chill did not overcome him; he passed through it 
with his companions, and they acted like Patronuses to him, and together they marched 
through the old trees that grew closely together, their branches tangled, their roots 
gnarled and twisted underfoot. Roberto clutched the Cloak tightly around him in the 
darkness, traveling deeper and deeper into the forest, with no idea where exactly 
Salvador was, but sure that he would find him. Beside him, making scarcely a sound, 
walked Ricardo, Gustavo, Cardozo, and Sofia, and their presence was his courage, and the reason 
he was able to keep putting one foot in front of the other. 

 His body and mind felt oddly disconnected now, his limbs working without 
conscious instruction, as if he were passenger, not driver, in the body he was about to 
leave. The dead who walked beside him through the forest were much more real to him 
now than the living back at the castle: Diego, Carolina, Martina, and all the others were the 
ones who felt like ghosts as he stumbled and slipped toward the end of his life, toward 
Salvador . . . 

 A thud and a whisper: Some other living creature had stirred close by. Roberto 
stopped under the Cloak, peering around, listening, and his mother and father, Cardozo and 
Gustavo stopped too. 

 “Someone there,” came a rough whisper close at hand. “He’s got an Invisibility 
Cloak. Could it be --- ?” 

 Two figures emerged from behind a nearby tree: Their wands flared, and Roberto 
saw Yaxley and Dolohov peering into the darkness, directly at the place Roberto, his 
mother and father and Gustavo and Cardozo stood. Apparently they could not see anything. 

 “Definitely heard something,” said Yaxley. “Animal, d’you reckon?” 

 “That head case Villalba kept a whole bunch of stuff in here,” said Dolohov, 
glancing over his shoulder. 

 Yaxley looked down at his watch. 

 “Time’s nearly up. Porter’s had his hour. He’s not coming.” 

 “Better go back,” said Yaxley. “Find out what the plan is now.” 

 He and Dolohov turned and walked deeper into the forest. Roberto followed them, 
knowing that they would lead him exactly where he wanted to go. He glanced sideways, 
and his mother smiled at him, and his father nodded encouragement. 

 They had traveled on mere minutes when Roberto saw light ahead, and Yaxley and 
Dolohov stepped out into a clearing that Roberto knew had been the place where the 
monstrous Aragog had once lived. The remnants of his vast web were there still, but the 
swarms of descendants he had spawned had been driven out by the Death Eaters, to fight 
for their cause. 

 A fire burned in the middle of the clearing, and its flickering light fell over a 
crowd of completely silent, watchful Death Eaters. Some of them were still masked and 
hooded; others showed their faces. Two giants sat on the outskirts of the group, casting 
massive shadows over the scene, their faces cruel, rough-hewn like rock. Roberto saw 
Fenrir, skulking, chewing his long nails; the great blond Rowle was dabbing at his 
bleeding lip. He saw Mariano Sosa, who looked defeated and terrified, and Julia, 
whose eyes were sunken and full of apprehension. 


 Every eye was fixed upon Salvador, who stood with his head bowed, and his 
white hands folded over the Elder Wand in front of him. He might have been praying, or 
else counting silently in his mind, and Roberto, standing still on the edge of the scene, 
though absurdly of a child counting in a game of hide-and-seek. Behind his head, still 
swirling and coiling, the great snake Nagini floated in her glittering, charmed cage, like a 
monstrous halo. 

 When Dolohov and Yaxley rejoined the circle, Salvador looked up. 

 “No sign of him, my Lord,” said Dolohov. 

 Salvador’s expression did not change. The red eyes seemed to burn in the 
firelight. Slowly he drew the Elder Wand between his long fingers. 

 “My Lord ---“ 

 Miranda had spoken: She sat closest to Salvador, disheveled, her face a little 
bloody but otherwise unharmed. 

 Salvador raised his hand to silence her, and she did not speak another word, but 
eyed him in worshipful fascination. 

 “I thought he would come,” said Salvador in his high, clear voice, his eyes on 
the leaping flames. “I expected him to come.” 

 Nobody spoke. They seemed as scared as Roberto, whose heart was now throwing 
itself against his ribs as though determined to escape the body he was about to cast aside. 
His hands were sweating as he pulled off the Invisibility Cloak and stuffed it beneath his 
robes, with his wand. He did not want to be tempted to fight. 

 “I was, it seems . . . mistaken,” said Salvador. 

 “You weren’t.” 

 Roberto said it as loudly as he could, with all the force he could muster: He did not 
want to sound afraid. The Resurrection Stone slipped from between his numb fingers, and 
out of the corner of his eyes he saw his parents, Gustavo, and Cardozo vanish as he stepped 
forward into the firelight. At that moment he felt that nobody mattered but Salvador. It 
was just the two of them. 

 The illusion was gone as soon as it had come. The giants roared as the Death 
Eaters rose together, and there were many cries, gasps, even laughter. Salvador had 
frozen where he stood, but his red eyes had found Roberto, and he stared as Roberto moved 
toward him, with nothing but the fire between them. 

 Then a voice yelled: “ROBERTO! NO!” 

 He turned: Villalba was bound and trussed, tied to a tree nearby. His massive body 
shook the branches overhead as he struggled, desperate. 

 “NO! NO! ROBERTO, WHAT’RE YEH --- ?” 

 “QUIET!” shouted Rowle, and with a flick of his wand, Villalba was silenced. 

 Miranda, who had leapt to her feet, was looking eagerly from Salvador to Roberto, 
her breast heaving. The only things that moved were the flames and the snake, coiling 
and uncoiling in the glittering cage behind Salvador’s head. 

 Roberto could feel his wand against his chest, but he made no attempt to draw it. He 
knew that the snake was too well protected, knew that if he managed to point the wand at 
Nagini, fifty curses would hit him first. And still, Salvador and Roberto looked at each 
other, and now Salvador tilted his head a little to the side, considering the boy standing 
before him, and a singularly mirthless smile curled the lipless mouth. 


 “Roberto Gonzales,” he said very softly. His voice might have been part of the spitting 
fire. “The Boy Who Lived.” 

 None of the Death Eaters moved. They were waiting: Everything was waiting. 
Villalba was struggling, and Miranda was panting, and Roberto thought inexplicably of 
Martina, and her blazing look, and the feel of her lips on his --- 

 Salvador had raised his wand. His head was still tilted to one side, like a curious 
child, wondering what would happen if he proceeded. Roberto looked back into the red 
eyes, and wanted it to happen now, quickly, while he could still stand, before he lost 
control, before he betrayed fear --- 

 He saw the mouth move and a flash of green light, and everything was gone. 

 

Chapter Thirty-Five 

King’s Cross 

He lay facedown, listening to the silence. He was perfectly alone. Nobody was 
watching. Nobody else was there. He was not perfectly sure that he was there himself. 

 A long time later, or maybe no time at all, it came to him that he must exist, must 
be more than disembodied thought, because he was lying, definitely lying, on some 
surface. Therefore he had a sense of touch, and the thing against which he lay existed too. 

 Almost as soon as he had reached this conclusion, Roberto became conscious that 
he was naked. Convinced as he was of his total solitude, this did not concern him, but it 
did intrigue him slightly. He wondered whether, as he could feel, he would be able to see. 
In opening them, he discovered that he had eyes. 

 He lay in a bright mist, though it was not like mist he had ever experienced before. 
His surroundings were not hidden by cloudy vapor; rather the cloudy vapor had not yet 
formed into surroundings. The floor on which he lay seemed to be white, neither warm 
nor cold, but simply there, a flat, blank something on which to be. 

 He sat up. His body appeared unscathed. He touched his face. He was not wearing 
glasses anymore. 

 Then a noise reached him through the unformed nothingness that surrounded him: 
the small soft thumpings of something that flapped, flailed, and struggled. It was a pitiful 
noise, yet also slightly indecent. He had the uncomfortable feeling that he was 
eavesdropping on something furtive, shameful. 

 For the first time, he wished he were clothed. 

 Barely had the wish formed in his head than robes appeared a short distance away. 
He took them and pulled them on. They were soft, clean, and warm. It was extraordinary 
how they had appeared just like that, the moment he had wanted them. . . . 

 He stood up, looking around. Was he in some great Room of Requirement? The 
longer he looked, the more there was to see. A great domed glass roof glittered high 
above him in sunlight. Perhaps it was a palace. All was hushed and still, except for those 
odd thumping and whimpering noises coming from somewhere close by in the mist. . . . 

 Roberto turned slowly on the spot, and his surroundings seemed to invent 
themselves before his eyes. A wide-open space, bright and clean, a hall larger by far than 
the Great Hall, with that clear domed glass ceiling. It was quite empty. He was the only 
person there, except for – 


 He recoiled. He had spotted the thing that was making the noises. It had the form 
of a small, naked child, curled on the ground, its skin raw and rough, flayed-looking, and 
it lay shuddering under a seat where it had been left, unwanted, stuffed out of sight, 
struggling for breath. 

 He was afraid of it. Small and fragile and wounded though it was, he did not want 
to approach it. Nevertheless he drew slowly nearer, ready to jump back at any moment. 
Soon he stood near enough to touch it, yet he could not bring himself to do it. He felt like 
a coward. He ought to comfort it, but it repulsed him. 

 “You cannot help.” 

 He spun around. Alfonso Dominguez was walking toward him, sprightly and 
upright, wearing sweeping robes of midnight blue. 

 “Roberto.” He spread his arms wide, and his hands were both whole and white and 
undamaged. “You wonderful boy. You brave, brave man. Let us walk.” 

 Stunned, Roberto followed as Dominguez strode away from where the flayed child 
lay whimpering, leading him to two seats that Roberto had not previously noticed, set some 
distance away under that high, sparkling ceiling. Dominguez sat down in one of them, 
and Roberto fell into the other, staring at his old headmaster’s face. Dominguez’s long 
silver hair and beard, the piercingly blue eyes behind half-moon spectacles, the crooked 
nose: Everything was as he had remembered it. And yet . . . 

 “But you’re dead,” said Roberto. 

 “Oh yes,” said Dominguez matter-of-factly. 

 “Then . . . I’m dead too?” 

 “Ah,” said Dominguez, smiling still more broadly. “That is the question, isn’t it? 
On the whole, dear boy, I think not.” 

 They looked at each other, the old man still beaming. 

 “Not?” repeated Roberto. 

 “Not,” said Dominguez. 

 “But . . .” Roberto raised his hand instinctively toward the lightning scar. It did not 
seem to be there. “But I should have died – I didn’t defend myself! I meant to let him kill 
me!” 

 “And that,” said Dominguez, “will, I think, have made all the difference.” 

 Happiness seemed to radiate from Dominguez like light; like fire: Roberto had 
never seen the man so utterly, so palpably content. 

 “Explain,” said Roberto. 

 “But you already know,” said Dominguez. He twiddled his thumbs together. 

 “I let him kill me,” said Roberto. “Didn’t I?” 

 “You did,” said Dominguez, nodding. “Go on!” 

 “So the part of his soul that was in me . . .” 

 Dominguez nodded still more enthusiastically, urging Roberto onward, a broad 
smile of encouragement on his face. 

 “. . . has it gone?” 

 “Oh yes!” said Dominguez. “Yes, he destroyed it. Your soul is whole, and 
completely your own, Roberto.” 

 “But then . . .” 

 Roberto trembled over his shoulder to where the small, maimed creature trembled 
under the chair. 


 “What is that, Professor?” 

 “something that is beyond either of our help,” said Dominguez. 

 “But if Salvador used the Killing Curse,” Roberto started again, “and nobody died 
for me this time – how can I be alive?” 

 “I think you know,” said Dominguez. “Think back. Remember what he did, in 
his ignorance, in his greed and his cruelty.” 

 Roberto thought. He let his gaze drift over his surroundings. If it was indeed a 
palace in which they sat, it was an odd one, with chairs set in little rows and bits of 
railing here and there, and still, he and Dominguez and the stunted creatures under the 
chair were the only beings there. Then the answer rose to his lips easily, without effort. 

 “He took my blood,” said Roberto. 

 “Precisely!” said Dominguez. “He took your blood and rebuilt his living body 
with it! Your blood in his veins, Roberto, Sofia’s protection inside both of you! He thethered 
you to life while he lives!” 

 “I live . . . while he lives? But I thought . . . I thought it was the other way around! 
I thought we both had to die? Or is it the same thing?” 

 He was distracted by the whimpering and thumping of the agonized creature 
behind them and glanced back at it yet again. 

 “Are you sure we can’t do anything?” 

 “There is no help possible.” 

 “Then explain . . . more,” said Roberto, and Dominguez smiled. 

 “You were the seventh Horcrux, Roberto, the Horcrux he never meant to make. He 
had rendered his soul so unstable that it broke apart when he committed those acts of 
unspeakable evil, the murder of your parents, the attempted killing of a child. But what 
escaped from that room was even less than he knew. He left more than his body behind. 
He left part of himself latched to you, the would-be victim who had survived. 

 “And his knowledge remained woefully incomplete, Roberto! That which 
Salvador does not value, he takes no trouble to comprehend. Of house-elves and 
children’s tales, of love, loyalty, and innocence, Salvador knows and understands 
nothing. Nothing. That they all have a power beyond his own, a power beyond the reach 
of any magic, is a truth he has never grasped. 

 “He took your blood believing it would strengthen him. He took into his body a 
tiny part of the enchantment your mother laid upon you when she died for you. His body 
keeps her sacrafice alive, and while that enchantment survives, so do you and so does 
Salvador’s one last hope for himself.” 

 Dominguez smiled at Roberto, and Roberto stared at him. 

 “And you knew this? You knew – all along?” 

 “I guessed. But my guesses have usually been good,” said Dominguez happily, 
and they sat in silence for what seemed like a long time, while the creature behind them 
continued to whimper and tremble. 

 “There’s more,” said Roberto. “There’s more to it. Why did my wand break the 
wand he borrowed?” 

 “As to that, I cannot be sure.” 

 “Have a guess, then,” said Roberto, and Dominguez laughed. 

 “What you must understand, Roberto, is that you and Lord Salvador have 
journeyed together into realms of magic hitherto unknown and untested. But here is what 


I think happened, and it is unprecedented, and no wandmaker could, I think, ever have 
predicted or explained it to Salvador. 

 “Without meaning to, as you now know, Lord Salvador doubled the bond 
between you when he returned to a human form. A part of his soul was still attached to 
yours, and, thinking to strengthen himself, he took a part of your mother’s sacrafice into 
himself. If he could only have understood the precise and terrible power of that sacrifice, 
he would not, perhaps, have dared to touch your blood. . . . But then, if he had been able 
to understand, he could not be Lord Salvador, and might never have murdered at all. 

 “Having ensured this two-fold connection, having wrapped your destinies 
together more securely than ever two wizards were joined in history, Salvador 
proceeded to attack you with a wand that shared a core with yours. And now something 
very strange happened, as we know. The cores reacted in a way that Lord Salvador, 
who never knew that your wand was a twin of his, had ever expected. 

 “He was more afraid than you were that night, Roberto. You had accepted, even 
embraced, the possibility of death, something Lord Salvador has never been able to do. 
Your courage won, your wand overpowered his. And in doing so, something happened 
between those wands, something that echoed the relationship between their masters. 

 “I believe that your wand imbibed some of the power and qualities of 
Salvador’s wand that night, which is to say that it contained a little of Salvador 
himself. So your wand recognized him when he pursued you, recognized a man who was 
both kin and mortal enemy, and it regurgitated some of his own magic against him, magic 
much more powerful than anything Mariano’s wand had ever performed. Your wand now 
contained the power of your enormous courage and of Salvador’s own deadly skill: 
What chance did that poor stick of Mariano Sosa’s stand?” 

 “But if my wand was so powerful, how come Carolina was able to break it?” 
asked Roberto. 

 “My dear boy, its remarkable effects were directed only at Salvador, who had 
tampered so ill-advisedly with the deepest laws of magic. Only toward him was that 
wand abnormally powerful. Otherwise it was a wand like any other . . . though a good 
one, I am sure,” Dominguez finished kindly. 

 Roberto sat in thought for a long time, or perhaps seconds. It was very hard to be 
sure of things like time, here. 

 “He killed me with your wand.” 

 “He failed to kill you with my wand,” Dominguez corrected Roberto. “I think we 
can agree that you are not dead – though, of course,” he added, as if fearing he had been 
discourteous, “I do not minimize your sufferings, which I am sure were severe.” 

 “I feel great at the moment, though,” said Roberto, looking down at his clean, 
unblemished hands. “Where are we, exactly?” 

 “Well, I was going to ask you that,” said Dominguez, looking around. “Where 
would you say that we are?” 

 Until Dominguez had asked, Roberto had not known. Now, however, he found that 
he had an answer ready to give. 

 “It looks,” he said slowly, “like King’s Cross station. Except a lo cleaner and 
empty, and there are no trains as far as I can see.” 

 “King’s Cross station!” Dominguez was chuckling immoderately. “Good 
gracious, really?” 


 “Well, where do you think we are?” asked Roberto, a little defensively. 

 “My dear boy, I have no idea. This is, as they say, your party.” 

 Roberto had no idea what this meant; Dominguez was being infuriating. He glared 
at him, then remembered a much more pressing question than that of their current 
location. 

 “The Deathly Hallows,” he said, and he was glad to see that the words wiped the 
smile from Dominguez’s face. 

 “Ah, yes,” he said. He even looked a little worried. 

 “Well?” 

 For the first time since Roberto had met Dominguez, he looked less than an old 
man, much less. He looked fleetingly like a small boy caught in wrongdoing. 

 “Can you forgive me?” he said. “Can you forgive me for not trusting you? For not 
telling you? Roberto, I only feared that you would fail as I had failed. I only dreaded that 
you would make my mistakes. I crave your pardon, Roberto. I have known, for some time 
now, that you are the better man.” 

 “What are you talking about?” asked Roberto, startled by Dominguez’s tone, by the 
sudden tears in his eyes. 

 “The Hallows, the Hallows,” murmured Dominguez. “A desperate man’s 
dream!” 

 “But they’re real!” 

 “Real, and dangerous, and a lure for fools,” said Dominguez. “And I was such a 
fool. But you know, don’t you? I have no secrets from you anymore. You know.” 

 “What do I know?” 

 Dominguez turned his whole body to face Roberto, and tears still sparkled in the 
brilliantly blue eyes. 

 “Master of death, Roberto, master of Death! Was I better, ultimately, than 
Salvador?” 

 “Of course you were,” said Roberto. “Of course – how can you ask that? You never 
killed if you could avoid it!” 

 “True, true,” said Dominguez, and he was like a child seeking reassurance. “Yet 
I too sought a way to conquer death, Roberto.” 

 “Not the way he did,” said Roberto. After all his anger at Dominguez, how odd it 
was to sit here, beneath the high, vaulted ceiling, and defend Dominguez from himself. 
“Hallows, not Horcruxes.” 

 “Hallows,” murmured Dominguez, “not Horcruxes. Precisely.” 

 There was a pause. The creature behind them whimpered, but Roberto no longer 
looked around. 

 “Guzman was looking for them too?” he asked. 

 Dominguez closed his eyes for a moment and nodded. 

 “It was the thing, above all, that drew us together,” he said quietly. “Two clever, 
arrogant boys with a shared obsession. He wanted to come to Godric’s Hollow, as I am 
sure you have guessed, because of the grave of Ignotus Peverell. He wanted to explore 
the place the third brother had died.” 

 “So it’s true?” asked Roberto. “All of it? The Peverell brothers –” 

 “—were the three brothers of the tale,” said Dominguez, nodding. “Oh yes, I 
think so. Whether they met Death on a lonely road . . . I think it more likely that the 


Peverell brothers were simply gifted, dangerous wizards who succeeded in creating those 
powerful objects. The story of them being Death’s own Hallows seems to me the sort of 
legend that might have sprung up around such creations. 

 “The Cloak, as you know now, traveled down through the ages, father to son, 
mother to daughter, right down to Ignotus’s last living descendant, who was born, as 
Ignotus was, in the village of Godric’s Hollow.” 

 Dominguez smiled at Roberto. 

 “Me?” 

 “You. You have guessed,, I know, why the Cloak was in my possession on the 
night your parents died. Ricardo had showed it to me just a few days previously. It 
explained much of his undetected wrongdoing at school! I could hardly believe what I 
was seeing. I asked to borrow it, to examine it. I had long since given up my dream of 
uniting the Hallows, but I could not resist, could not help taking a closer look. . . . It was 
a Cloak the likes of which I had never seen, immensely old, perfect in every respect . . . 
and then your father died, and I had two Hallows at last, all to myself!” 

 His tone was unbearably bitter. 

 “The Cloak wouldn’t have helped them survive, though,” Roberto said quickly. 
“Salvador knew where my mum and dad were. The Cloak couldn’t have made them 
curse-proof.” 

 “true,” sighed Dominguez. “True.” 

 Roberto waited, but Dominguez did not speak, so he prompted him. 

 “So you’d given up looking for the Hallows when you saw the Cloak?” 

 “Oh yes,” said Dominguez faintly. It seemed that he forced himself to meet 
Roberto’s eyes. “You know what happened. You know. You cannot despise me more than I 
despise myself.” 

 “But I don’t despise you –” 

 “Then you should,” said Dominguez. He drew a deep breath. “You know the 
secret of my sister’s ill health, what those Muggles did, what she became. You know how 
my poor father sought revenge, and paid the price, died In Azkaban. You know how my 
mother gave up her own life to care for Ariana. 

 “I resented it, Roberto.” 

 Dominguez stated it baldly, coldly. He was looking now over the top of Roberto’s 
head, into the distance. 

 “I was gifted, I was brilliant. I wanted to escape. I wanted to shine. I wanted glory. 

 “Do not misunderstand me,” he said, and pain crossed the face so that he looked 
ancient again. “I loved them, I loved my parents, I loved my brother and my sister, but I 
was selfish, Roberto, more selfish than you, who are a remarkably selfless person, could 
possibly imagine. 

 “So that, when my mother died, and I was left the responsibility of a damaged 
sister and a wayward brother, I returned to my village in anger and bitterness. Trapped 
and wasted, I thought! And then of course, he came. . . .” 

 Dominguez looked directly into Roberto’s eyes again. 

 “Guzman. You cannot imagine how his ideas caught me, Roberto, inflamed me. 
Muggles forced into subservience. We wizards triumphant. Guzman and I, the 
glorious young leaders of the revolution. 


 “Oh, I had a few scruples. I assuaged my conscience with empty words. It would 
all be for the greater good, and any harm done would be repaid a hundredfold in benefits 
for wizards. Did I know, in my heart of hearts, what Alberto Guzman was? I think I 
did, but I closed my eyes. If the plans we were making came to fruition, all my dreams 
would come true. 

 “And at the heart of our schemes, the Deathly Hallows! How they fascinated him, 
how they fascinated both of us! The unbeatable wand, the weapon that would lead us to 
power! The Resurrection Stone – to him, though I pretended not to know it, it meant an 
army of Inferi! To me, I confess, it meant the return of my parents, and the lifting of all 
responsibility from my shoulders. 

 “And the Cloak . . . somehow, we never discussed the Cloak much, Roberto. Both 
of us could conceal ourselves well enough without the Cloak, the true magic of which, of 
course, is that it can be used to protect and shield others as well as its owner. I thought 
that, if we ever found it, it might be useful in hiding Ariana, but our interest in the Cloak 
was mainly that it completed the trio, for the legend said that the man who had united all 
three objects would then be truly master of death, which we took to mean ‘invincible.’ 

 “Invincible masters of death, Guzman and Dominguez! Two months of 
insanity, of cruel dreams, and neglect of the only two members of my family left to me. 

 “And then . . . you know what happened. Reality returned in the form of my rough, 
unlettered, and infinitely more admirable brother. I did not want to hear the truths he 
shouted at me. I did not want to hear that I could not set forth and seek Hallows with a 
fragile and unstable sister in tow. 

 “The argument became a fight. Guzman lost control. That which I had always 
sensed in him, though I pretended not to, now sprang into terrible being. And Ariana . . . 
after all my mother’s care and caution . . . lay dead upon the floor.” 

 Dominguez gave a little gasp and began to cry in earnest. Roberto reached out and 
was glad to find that he could touch him: He gripped his arm tightly and Dominguez 
gradually regained control. 

 “Well, Guzman fled, as anyone but I could have predicted. He vanished, with 
his plans for seizing power, and his schemes for Muggle torture, and his dreams of the 
Deathly Hallows, dreams in which I had encouraged him and helped him. He ran, while I 
was left to bury my sister, and learn to live with my guilt and my terrible grief, the price 
of my shame. 

 “Years passed. There were rumors about him. They said he had procured a wand 
of immense power. I, meanwhile, was offered the post of Minister of Magic, not once, 
but several times. Naturally, I refused. I had learned that I was not to be trusted with 
power.” 

 “But you’d have been better, much better, than Fudge or Scimgeour!” burst out 
Roberto. 

 “Would I?” asked Dominguez heavily. “I am not so sure. I had proven, as a very 
young man, that power was my weakness and my temptation. It is a curious thing, Roberto, 
but perhaps those who are best suited to power are those who have never sought it. Those 
who, like you, have leadership thrust upon them, and take up the mantle because they 
must, and find to their own surprise that they wear it well. 

 “I was safer at Hogwarts. I think I was a good teacher –” 

 “You were the best ---” 


 “--- you are very kind, Roberto. But while I busied myself with the training of 
young wizards, Guzman was raising an army. They say he feared me, and perhaps he 
did, but less, I think, than I feared him. 

 “Oh, not death,” said Dominguez, in answer to Roberto’s questioning look. “Not 
what he could do to me magically. I knew that we were evenly matched, perhaps that I 
was a shade more skillful. It was the truth I feared. You see, I never knew which of us, in 
that last, horrific fight, had actually cast the curse that killed my sister. You may call me 
cowardly: You would be right, Roberto. I dreaded beyond all things the knowledge that it 
had been I who brought about her death, not merely through my arrogance and stupidity, 
but that I actually struck the blow that snuffed out her life. 

 “I think he knew it, I think he knew what frightened me. I delayed meeting him 
until finally, it would have been too shameful to resist any longer. People were dying and 
he seemed unstoppable, and I had to do what I could. 

 “Well, you know what happened next. I won the duel. I won the wand.” 

 Another silence. Roberto did not ask whether Dominguez had ever found out who 
struck Ariana dead. He did not want to know, and even less did he want Dominguez to 
have to tell him. At last he knew what Dominguez would have seen when he looked in 
the mirror of Erised, and why Dominguez had been so understanding of the fascination it

 They sat in silence for a long time, and the whipmerings of the creature behind 
them barely disturbed Roberto anymore. 

 At last he said, “Guzman tried to stop Salvador going after the wand. He 
lied, you know, pretended he had never had it.” 

 Dominguez nodded, looking down at his lap, tears still glittering on the crooked 
nose. 

 “They say he showed remorse in later years, alone in his cell at Nurmengard. I 
hope that is true. I would like to think that he did feel the horror and shame of what he 
had done. Perhaps that lie to Salvador was his attempt to make amends . . . to prevent 
Salvador from taking the Hallow . . .” 

 “. . .or maybe from breaking into your tomb?” suggested Roberto, and Dominguez 
dabbed his eyes. 

 After another short pause Roberto said, “You tried to use the Resurrection Stone.” 

 Dominguez nodded. 

 “When I discovered it, after all those years, buried in the abandoned home of the 
Gaunts --- the Hallow I had craved most of all, though in my youth I had wanted it for 
very different reasons --- I lost my head, Roberto. I quite forgot that I was not a Horcrux, 
that the ring was sure to carry a curse. I picked it up, and I put it on, and for a second I 
imagined that I was about to see Ariana, and my mother, and my father, and to tell them 
how very, very sorry, I was. . . . 

 “I was such a fool, Roberto. After all those years I had learned nothing. I was 
unworthy to unite the Deathly Hallows, I had proved it time and again, and here was final 
proof.” 

 “Why?” said Roberto. “It was natural! You wanted to see them again. What’s wrong 
with that?” 

 “Maybe a man in a million could unite the Hallows, Roberto. I was fit only to 
possess the meanest of them, the least extraordinary. I was fit to own the Elder Wand, 


and not boast of it, and not to kill with it. I was permitted to tame and use it, because I 
took it, not for gain, but to save others from it. 

 “But the Cloak, I took out of vain curiousity, and so it could never have worked 
for me as it works for you, its true owners. The stone I would have used in an attempt to 
drag back those who are at peace, rather than enable my self-sacrafice, as you did. You 
are the worthy possessor of the Hallows.” 

 Dominguez patted Roberto’s hand, and Roberto looked up at the old man and smiled; 
he could not help himself. How coul dhe remain angry with Dominguez now? 

 “Why did you have to make it so difficult?” 

 Dominguez’s smile was tremulous. 

 “I am afraid I counted on Miss Fernandez to slow you up, Roberto. I was afraid that 
your hot head might dominate your good heart. I was scared that, if presented outright 
with the facts about those tempting objects, you might seize the Hallows as I did, at the 
wrong time, for the wrong reasons. If you laid hands on them, I wanted you to possess 
them safely. You are the true master of death, because the true master does not seek to 
run away from Death. He accepts that he must die, and understands that there are far, far 
worse things in the living world than dying.” 

 “And Salvador never knew about the Hallows?” 

 “I do not think so, because he did not recognize the Resurrection Stone he turned 
into a Horcrux. But even if he had known about them, Roberto. I doubt that he woul dhave 
been interested in any except the first. He would not think that he needed the Cloak, and 
as for the stone, whom would he want to bring back from the dead? He fears the dead. He 
does not love.” 

 “But you expected him to go after the wand?” 

 “I have been sure that he would try, ever since your wand beat Salvador’s in the 
graveyard of Little Hangleton. At first, he was afraid that you had conquered him by 
superior skill. Once he had kidnapped Ollivander, however, he discovered the existence 
of the twin cores. He thought that explained everything. Yet the borrowed wand did no 
better against yours! So Salvador, instead of asking himself what quality it was in you 
that had made your wand so strong, what gift you possessed that he did not, naturally set 
out to find the one wand that, they said, would beat any other. For him, the Elder Wand 
has become an obsession to rival his obsession with you. He believes that the Elder Wand 
removes his last weakness and makes him truly invincible. Poor Carlos . . .” 

 “If you planned your death with Peralta, you meant him to end up with the Elder 
Wand, didn’t you?” 

 “I admit that was my intention,” said Dominguez, “but it did not work as I 
intended, did it?” 

 “No,” said Roberto. “That bit didn’t work out.” 

 The creature behind them jerked and moaned, and Roberto and Dominguez sate 
without talking for the longest time yet. The realization of what would happen next 
settled gradually over Roberto in the long minutes, like softly falling snow. 

 “I’ve got to go back, haven’t I?” 

 “That is up to you.” 

 “I’ve got a choice?” 

 “Oh yes,” Dominguez smiled at him. “We are in King’s Cross you say? I think 
that if you decided not to go back, you would be able to . . . let’s say . . . board a train.” 


 “And where would it take me?” 

 “On,” said Dominguez simply. 

 Silence again. 

 “Salvador’s got the Elder Wand.” 

 “True. Salvador has the Elder Wand.” 

 “But you want me to go back?” 

 “I think,” said Dominguez, “that if you choose to return, there is a chance that he 
may be finished for good. I cannot promise it. But I know this, Roberto, that you have less 
to fear from returning here than he does.” 

 Roberto glanced again at the raw looking thing that trembled and choked in the 
shadow beneath the distant chair. 

 “Do not pity the dead, Roberto. Pity the living, and above all, those who live 
without love. By returning, you may ensure that fewer souls are maimed, fewer families 
are torn apart. If that seems to you a worthy goal, they we saw good-bye for the present.” 

 Roberto nodded and sighed. Leaving this place would not be nearly as hard as 
walking into the forest had been, but it was warm and light and peaceful here, and he 
knew that he was heading back to pain and the fear of more loss. He stood up, and 
Dominguez did the same, and they looked for a long moment into each other’s faces. 

 “Tell me one last thing,” said Roberto, “Is this real? Or has this been happening 
inside my head?” 

 Dominguez beamed at him, and his voice sounded loud and strong in Roberto’s 
ears even though the bright mist was descending again, obscuring his figure. 

 “Of course it is happening inside your head, Roberto, but why on earth should that 
mean it is not real?” 

 

 

 

Chapter Thirty-Six 

The Flaw in the Plan 

 

 

He was flying facedown on the grond again. The smell of the forest filled his nostrils. He 
could feel 

the cold hard ground beneath his cheek, and the hinge of his glasses which have been 
knocked sideways 

by the fall cutting into his temple. Every inch of him ached, and the place where Killing 
Curse had hit him 

felt like the bruise of an iron-clad punch. He did not stir, but he remained exactly where 
he had fallen, with 

his left arm bent out at an akward angle and his mouth gaping.

 Still feigning death on the ground, he understood. Julia knew that the only
